abstract: -- The month of March is given over to execration in the annals of every respectable or aesthetical nation. It has well sustained its reputation this year, in this country. It has been one of the dismalest and chilliest months that ever marked the calendar, and closed its unwelcome reign, yesterday, by a storm of snow, wind and rain overhead, and an ocean of slush and mud under foot, of still harrowing memory.

abstract: Ackroyd vs. Ackroyd. -- The plaintiff and defendant are brothers. The defendant is Executor and Trustee of his father's estate, and, it is alleged, the plaintiff paid him, as such, the sum of $55,000, which the defendant, as claimed, has fraudulently converted to his own use. It appears that the parties were partners in business, and the defendant claims that the money was received only as a part of the partnership funds, and not in his capacity as Trustee of his father's estate. &c.

abstract: The following document, addressed by Mr. JUDAH P. BENJAMIN, the Confederate "Secretary of State," to Hon. L.Q.C. LAMAR, the Confederate "Commissioner" at St. Petersburgh, has lately come into the possession of our Government. It is published for the information of all concerned, as serving to show the prudent and significant reserve which the Confederate authorities prescribe to themselves in refusing to enter into any engagements with foreign nations got to revive the African slave-trade.

abstract: THE WILLIAMSBURGH ABORTION CASE. -- In the Court of Sessions, yesterday, Dr. PETER W. RAY, a colored physician, was arraigned for trial on an indictment charging him with manslaughter in the second degree, in procuring an abortion on the person of MARY BURNS, a white unmarried woman, employed as a servant in a family in Williamsburgh. The deceased died in August last under circumstances which led to the suspicion that she had been improperly dealt with. Several physicians were examined as witnesses, who swore to the effect that death resulted in consequence of loss of blood, caused by premature birth, but no direct evidence was brought to show that Dr. RAY had used improper means to accomplish the object. The ante-mortem examination of the deceased having been made by Coroner MURPHY, who held the inquest, her statement was admitted in evidence, and which was to the effect that Dr. RAY had attended her during her illness, &c. The defence was a general denial. After summing up of counsel, Judge GARRISON (presiding) stated that in his opinion there was not enough evidence to convict the defendant; but being overruled by his associates, permitted the case to go to the jury. After a comparatively brief deliberation, the jury convicted the defendant of misdemeanor, in having used instruments with intent to procure miscarriage. The defendant is to be brought up for sentence on Thursday. The punishment provided by statute is imprisonment in the Penitentiary for not less than three months nor more than one year.
lead_paragraph: THE WILLIAMSBURGH ABORTION CASE. -- In the Court of Sessions, yesterday, Dr. PETER W. RAY, a colored physician, was arraigned for trial on an indictment charging him with manslaughter in the second degree, in procuring an abortion on the person of MARY BURNS, a white unmarried woman, employed as a servant in a family in Williamsburgh. The deceased died in August last under circumstances which led to the suspicion that she had been improperly dealt with. Several physicians were examined as witnesses, who swore to the effect that death resulted in consequence of loss of blood, caused by premature birth, but no direct evidence was brought to show that Dr. RAY had used improper means to accomplish the object. The ante-mortem examination of the deceased having been made by Coroner MURPHY, who held the inquest, her statement was admitted in evidence, and which was to the effect that Dr. RAY had attended her during her illness, &c. The defence was a general denial. After summing up of counsel, Judge GARRISON (presiding) stated that in his opinion there was not enough evidence to convict the defendant; but being overruled by his associates, permitted the case to go to the jury. After a comparatively brief deliberation, the jury convicted the defendant of misdemeanor, in having used instruments with intent to procure miscarriage. The defendant is to be brought up for sentence on Thursday. The punishment provided by statute is imprisonment in the Penitentiary for not less than three months nor more than one year.

abstract: Among the passengers by the steamer McClellan, from New-Orleans, which arrived here on Monday, were the celebrated high-mettled racers Panic, Ben West, Frank Cheatham and Behemoth; and these were accompanied also by a three-year old colt by Grey Medoc, and a filly by Glencoe. All of these fine animals were bought under a sale of confiscated goods for GEORGE WILKES, Editor of the Spirit of the Times of this City. They made the journey safely, and arrived in excellent condition, with the exception of Behemoth, who caught a severe cold, and perhaps may be lost. These horses, being all stallions but one, are a great acquisition to the North, and Mr. WILKES may boast of the possession of a "string" equal in merit and value to any ever possessed by one owner in the United States -- not excepting old Col. JOHNSON, the Napoleon of the Turf.

abstract: The intelligence that France had proposed to Great Britain and Russia to join her in advising the belligerents in this country to agree to an armistice, reached New-York by telegraph from Cape Race on the 25th inst. The substance of your Lordship's answer was received at the same time. Yesterday the text of the French proposal, of your Lordship's answer, and or the principal part of the Russian answer, was forwarded to New-York by telegraph from Halifax.

abstract: -- An Irishman, named HENRY TESTOR, was taken into custody yesterday, by Capt. BROWER, of the Seventeenth Precinct Police, upon a warrant issued by Coroner NAUMANN. The accused is charged with having assaulted his wife with a deadly weapon, thereby inflicting injuries upon her head and other parts of her person, from the effects of which, it is believed, she  cannot recover. But the most aggravated part of the charge against TESTOR is, that after having inflicted these severe injuries upon his wife, and while she was lying in bed unable to move on account of these cruelties, he took a step-child of his, aged about three years, and the only other member of the family, placed it upon a red hot stove, and held it there until a large portion of its body was burned to a crisp. The cries of the little sufferer brought some of the neighbors into the apartment, and the brutal father was thereupon compelled to desist from his barbarous work. Soon afterwards, however, he sought to complete his inhuman work by applying the burnt portion of the child's body to his mouth, and, with his teeth, tearing off large quantities of the crisped and blackened flesh. He then seized the child by the legs, swung it several times around his head, all the time making loud threats that he would dash its brains out against the wall. Some persons in an adjoining apartment interfered at this stage of his proceedings, and rescued the child. The offender is a currier by occupation, aged about 23, and with his wife and child, resided at No. 111 Third-street. He is held by the Coroner, to await the result of the injuries inflicted upon the two members of his family.

abstract: Yesterday's Richmond Dispatch has the following :  "On the morning of the 25th, four Federal boats were advancing toward our upper batteries at Vicksburgh. A vigorous fire was opened upon them. Two were driven back, and two passed under a rakfug fire. One received a shot from which she sunk. Part of her crew escaped to the opposite shore. The Benton was disabled, and the Albaltross towed her out of danger of our gunboats."

abstract: The latest news from Vicksburgh via Memphis and Cairo, confirms the rebel news received via Fredericksburgh, of the attempt of two of our vessels to pass the batteries at Vicksburgh, and the sinking of one of them. The attempt, it appears, was made by the rams Lancaster and Switzerland. A heavy fire was opened upon them by the rebel batteries. The Lancaster was struck thirty times, and her entire bow was shot away, causing her to sink immediately, and to turn a complete summerset when she went down. All the crew except two, however, escaped. The Switzerland was disabled by a shot in her steam-drum, but she floated past the batteries, and was taken in tow by the Albatross, one of Admiral FARRAGUT's vessels. The loss of life on board her is not known. There is also a partial confirmation of the rebel report that the expedition to the rear of Haines' Bluff had met with obstructions, and had turned back. It is said to have returned to Young's Point. There is nothing definite from the Yazoo Pass Expedition, though we have a rebel dispatch stating that our forces have again appeared in front of Fort Pemberton, and that firing was heard on the afternoon of the 24th ult.
lead_paragraph: The latest news from Vicksburgh via Memphis and Cairo, confirms the rebel news received via Fredericksburgh, of the attempt of two of our vessels to pass the batteries at Vicksburgh, and the sinking of one of them. All the crew except two, however, escaped. The loss of life on board her is not known. There is also a partial confirmation of the rebel report that the expedition to the rear of Haines' Bluff had met with obstructions, and had turned back. It is said to have returned to Young's Point. There is nothing definite from the Yazoo Pass Expedition, though we have a rebel dispatch stating that our forces have again appeared in front of Fort Pemberton, and that firing was heard on the afternoon of the 24th ult.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Hansa, last evening, we have advices from Europe three days later. She left Southampton on March 18. She brings intelligence via Havre, of further depredations by the pirate Alabama. A vessel arrived at that port on the 14th, and reported having spoken the Alabama on the 24th of February, and taken on board from her two Frenchmen belonging to the Olive Jane, from Bordeaux for New-York, which had been burnt on the 21st. On the same day the Alabama had burnt a large vessel bound from California to Queenstown -- name not given. On the evening of the 23d the light of another burning vessel was seen on board the Gil Blas. A vessel arrived at Southampton reported that the Alabama was cruising off St. Lucia, W.I. The London Times announces the reception of the ratification of the rebel 7 cent. Cotton loan of Â£3,000,000, and that it was to be brought out by certain parties named at Paris, Frankfort, Amsterdam, London and Liverpool. The Times comments on the National Banking law passed by the late Congress, and claims for Great Britain the credit of originating the idea upon which it is established. It considers the law the most important one passed, and the one which will do most to fuse and amalgamate the North. The Polish revolution seems to be progressing favorably for the Revolutionists. Polish affairs have been discussed by the French Senate, but no definite conclusion had been arrived at. The Dictator LANGIEWICZ had accredited official agents to all foreign Governments. A great battle was soon expected between the Poles, under LANGIEWICZ, and 18,000 Russians. Under the stimulus of an increased demand, a further advance had taken place in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were steady. Consols were quoted at 92 1/8@92 1/4 for money.

abstract: In another column may be found a Bill, now before the Legislature of New-York, providing that every qualified and duly registered voter of the State, now in the military or naval service, shall be entitled to vote at every general State election hereafter held in the election district where he has a residence. It is very carefully guarded against all chance for fraud or other abuse, and is adapted to the sole purpose of enabling our gallant fellow-citizens, who are engaged in defending the integrity of the Republic, to exercise the most sacred right which the Republic guarantees. The Republican majority of the Committee have reported in favor of the bill; the Democratic minority have reported against it.

abstract: The report has come to us repeatedly, during the past month, that the rebels were evacuating Richmond. And within a week or ten days past we have had stories, more or less positive, that the greater part of LEE's army had been withdrawn from the line of the Rappahannock. The conclusion drawn from these facts, supposing them to be facts, was, that the rebels are about to abandon the entire State of Virginia, and fall back upon some interior State of the Confederacy. Our Washington correspondent communicated, on Monday, a military indorsement of these statements in regard to rebel intentions, as follows:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The combined influences of execrable weather and Passion Week had their effect, not only on the attendance of last night, but on he artists who were unfortunate enough to take part in the representation. "Lucia di Lammermoor," under the circumstances, was an exercise creditable alike to the company and the audience. Fortunately, Mlle. ORTALANI-BRIGNOLI was the least affected of the troupe, and as her role is the one of most importance, she was able in a measure to redeem the evening's amusement. In the opening scena of the first act the lady was heard to great advantage, and obtained a merited salvo of applause. In the mad scene of the third act she was also excellent. Signor MAZZOLINI was hardly up to his usual standard, but was himself in the end. Signor BELLINI was too unwell to appear as Ashton, and Sigor YPOLITO assumed his role, although laboring under a cold which the first-named gentleman could hardly have excelled. Under the unfortunate circumstances of the evening, it will easily be understood that the performance was not on a par with those that have preceded it.

abstract: -- We make some further extracts this morning from the volume of diplomatic correspondence recently sent in to the British Parliament. They throw a good deal of light on the real sentiments of the British Government toward this country, as well as on the steps taken by them to bring the war to a conclusion. The reports forwarded by Lord LYONS to his Government of the state of public sentiment here on passing events, seem to be thoroughly and uniformly colored by sympathy with secession. He speaks of the meeting of Governors at Altoona precisely as it was spoken of by Northern journals in the rebel interest, and magnifies all the difficulties and shortcomings of the Government precisely as they are magnified by its enemies.
lead_paragraph: -- We make some further extracts this morning from the volume of diplomatic correspondence recently sent in to the British Parliament. abstract: A base purpose is never honorably pursued. The end and the means are always of a piece. After the interviews with "several of the leaders of the Democratic party" Lord LYONS writes, "at the bottom I thought I perceived a desire to put an end to the war, even at the risk of losing the Southern States altogether; but it was plain that it was not thought prudent to avow this desire." The British Minister, with his diplomatic appreciation of motives, had no difficulty in apprehending the real spirit and intent of the party managers closeted with him. Their errand was not at all to discourage foreign intervention; they simply wanted the thing prudently managed -- or in other words, they wanted time first, to blind, cajole and circumvent the people. "At the present moment, therefore" says his lordship, "the chiefs of the conservative party call loudly for a more vigorous prosecution of the war, and reproach the Government with slackness, as well as with want of success in its military measures."

abstract: Additional news from Vicksburgh corroborates the reports which have previously reached us of the failure of the new expedition intended to flank Haines' Bluff by way of the Sunflower. Admiral PORTER succeeded in getting through Steele's and Black Bayous, and proceeded twenty-five or thirty miles further in Deer and Rolling Forks, when he encountered a small force of rebels, who compelled him to await the arrival of infantry. Meantime the enemy obstructed the channel, and otherwise annoyed the gunboats, and when our infantry arrived the rebels had accumulated such a force as to render further progress extremely hazardous. Our loss in the skirmishing which took place before the retreat was ten or twelve killed and wounded. The rebel loss is unknown.
lead_paragraph: Additional news from Vicksburgh corroborates the reports which have previously reached us of the failure of the new expedition intended to flank Haines' Bluff by way of the Sunflower. abstract: Some weeks since we intimated that the French Minister had been conferring with prominent and influential politicians concerning foreign mediation as a means of ending the war. The accusation was repelled in various quarters as wholly incredible and as involving a serious aspersion upon the character of the representative of a friendly Power. Our venerable confrere, (it would scarcely be accurate to say cotemporary,) the National Intelligencer, was especially solemn and impressive, having the dignity of the State Department as well as its own to protect in this emergency; and it read the Press in general a grave lecture on the serious impropriety of so far impugning the character of foreign ministers as to deem them capable of such offences against the proprieties of their position.

abstract: It was long a pleasant delusion of Southern rebels and their Northern sympathizers, that the rebellion could never be conquered, because the Southern people would be fighting for their homes and their independence, while the Northern soldiers would be merely fighting for an "idea" and their pay. It was held that the Southern armies would always be filled by the irrepressible ardor of the people, while the Northern armies, after the first fever of excitement and passion, would hardly be kept in skeleton form by conscription.

abstract: -- A few days since, in replying to the very flagrant misrepresentation of the Conscription act contained in the Mozart Hall resolutions -- that every man who could not pay $300 for a substitute would be compelled to serve in the ranks -- we fell into the error of supposing, from the terms of the law, that the Secretary of War could vary this amount to meet the circumstances of each particular case. The copy of the law which we had before us at the time of writing, did not contain the clause which requires the rate of payment to be uniform for each State, though we find that this requirement is embodied in the law. But it still remains perfectly true, that the Secretary may fix the rate for any State at a lower figure than $300, if he chooses to do so. We copy in another column a letter addressed to Ex-Mayor WOOD by Senator WILSON, who was Chairman of the Military Committee in the Senate, upon this subject. It sets forth the provisions of this act very clearly, and vindicates it completely from the objections urged against it by the resolutions of Mozart Hall.
lead_paragraph: -- A few days since, in replying to the very flagrant misrepresentation of the Conscription act contained in the Mozart Hall resolutions -- that every man who could not pay $300 for a substitute would be compelled to serve in the ranks -- we fell into the error of supposing, from the terms of the law, that the Secretary of War could vary this amount to meet the circumstances of each particular case. The copy of the law which we had before us at the time of writing, did not contain the clause which requires the rate of payment to be uniform for each State, though we find that this requirement is embodied in the law. But it still remains perfectly true, that the Secretary may fix the rate for any State at a lower figure than $300, if he chooses to do so. We copy in another column a letter addressed to Ex-Mayor WOOD by Senator WILSON, who was Chairman of the Military Committee in the Senate, upon this subject. It sets forth the provisions of this act very clearly, and vindicates it completely from the objections urged against it by the resolutions of Mozart Hall.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill relative to the heads of Departments in New-York was ordered to a third reading; also, the bill to facilitate the acquisition of lands by the Croton Water Board; also, the bill incorporating the Dry-Goods Clerks' Association. The bill allowing the soldiers of the State in the service of the United States to vote by proxy was passed, by a vote of 19 to 7, after some debate.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill relative to the heads of Departments in New-York was ordered to a third reading; also, the bill to facilitate the acquisition of lands by the Croton Water Board; also, the bill incorporating the Dry-Goods Clerks' Association. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The preference of the public for MEDORI and MAZZOLENI, over the other artists of Mr. MARETZEK's troupe, was again demonstrated last evening, when "Norma" was repeated, for the third time, to a house that is said to be the best of the season. The music of this work is certainly no longer attractive in itself, and must derive any fresh importance that it has from the extraordinary vitality infused into it by the artists we have named. The applause was so enthusiastic last evening, and the condition of all the singers so excellents that we shall not be surprised if "Norma" attracts several more crowded houses.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The preference of the public for MEDORI and MAZZOLENI, over the other artists of Mr. MARETZEK's troupe, was again demonstrated last evening, when "Norma" was repeated, for the third time, to a house that is said to be the best of the season. abstract: Some further European intelligence by the City of Washington is given this morning. An important engagement is announced to have taken place between the Russians and the Poles, at Loudek, on the 16th ult., in which the Russians were defeated and compelled to retreat. Advices from Japan state that the nobles who had been connected with foreigners had been degraded, and this measure was supposed to be preliminary to a repudiation of all treaties concluded by the Japanese Government with foreign Powers.
lead_paragraph: Some further European intelligence by the City of Washington is given this morning. abstract: The schooner Jane Morley, formerly La Fouavril, of Baltimore, owned by HOKES, BEEL  Co., arrived at the steamboat wharf to-day in tow of a tug, having been sent up from the lower river, where she was captured yesterday. She had been engaged in the contraband traffic, which finds its way between the rebels in Maryland and Virginia, across the Potomac, near the extremity of the Peninsula between the Potomac and the Rappahannock.

abstract: As we have just been going through a fit of elation, for which there was no particular reason, we shall probably now for a few days experience a fit of depression equally unreasonable. Every one had last week got hold of the notion that Vicksburgh was about to fall, and that the Yazoo expedition was certain to be successful.
lead_paragraph: As we have just been going through a fit of elation, for which there was no particular reason, we shall probably now for a few days experience a fit of depression equally unreasonable. Every one had last week got hold of the notion that Vicksburgh was about to fall, and that the Yazoo expedition was certain to be successful. The Yazoo expedition has not yet proved successful, and Vicksburgh will probably remain in rebel hands for weeks to come, if not longer. But it is well to bear in mind that we have accomplished the greater part of what we seek to accomplish by taking both Vicksburgh and Port Hudson. It ought not to be forgotten, as it is too often, that the capture of these places would, after all, be but a means to an end. What we seek by assailing them is to obtain control of the 800 miles of river which stretches between them -- because with this in our possession, and with vigorous operations going on in Virginia and Tennessee, it is all but certain that the garrisons of both of them will be compelled to retire into the interior, partly through fear of being cut off, partly through want of the supplies for which they have drawn so largely upon Texas. We have got control of the river, and there is no likelihood of our again losing it; so that, in point of fact, the most important part of the operation is actually achieved. The remainder does not, in our opinion, depend on anything which can be immediately done either on the Yazoo or at Port Hudson, but on the amount of pressure which can be brought to bear on other points of the circle.

abstract: An immense gathering of the citizens of New-York was held last evening at the Academy of Music, under the auspices of the Loyal League and the hundred gentlemen who, some time since, tendered to Gen. BUTLER the compliment of a public dinner, to extend to him in this form, as most agreeable to him, a welcome to the City, and to testify their appreciation and approbation of the distinguished services he has rendered the country during the present war. The Academy was crowded to its utmost capacity. The boxes, dress circle and balcony fairly blazed with the beauty and fashion of the City, while the deep aisles of the parquet and the more remote recesses of the amphitheatre were relieved from the sombre colors of male attire by the waving plumes, the ruddy ribbons, and the glittering jewels of New-York's fairest ladies. Mrs. BUTLER, Mrs. BANKS and Mrs. FREMONT were present, sitting in the private boxes, and upon the stage were Gen. WOOL, Gen. C.M. CLAY, and a large number of our well-known citizens.
lead_paragraph: An immense gathering of the citizens of New-York was held last evening at the Academy of Music, under the auspices of the Loyal League and the hundred gentlemen who, some time since, tendered to Gen. abstract: adier-General," who writes a couple of very neat dispatches regarding a very gallant action fought by him on Monday in Southern Kentucky, is the able young engineer officer who conducted the siege of Fort Pulaski, and who has furnished one of the best monograms of the war concerning that brilliant affair.
lead_paragraph: adier-General," who writes a couple of very neat dispatches regarding a very gallant action fought by him on Monday in Southern Kentucky, is the able young engineer officer who conducted the siege of Fort Pulaski, and who has furnished one of the best monograms of the war concerning that brilliant affair. He has now whipped very conclusively the rebel force which had invaded Kentucky, and which was undoubtedly intended as a pioneer body to feel the practicability of an invasion of the State by a large army. The rebels chose a position at Somerset, on the north side of the Cumberland River, a few miles from Mill Spring, where they were so completely whipped in January of last year, in what may be called the first real and proper battle of this war. The-rebels under PEGRAM, on this occasion were smaller in number than they were under ZOLLICOFFER last year, but the scourging they received seems to have been about equally thorough in both cases. GILMORE attacked the rebels, who had a force double his, in their chosen position, fought them five hours, drove them from one place to another, and finally to the river, which they hastened in the night time to put between themselves and their pursuers. It may be that they will now wait at Mill Spring, as they did last year, to receive a finishing touch such as they then got. But whether they do or not, they are not likely to try their fortunes again north of Cumberland River.

abstract: The rebels seem to be a good deal in doubt how to deal with the Northwestern Slates. They are very anxious to deal with them separately, and very desirous so to act as to induce them to desert the cause of the Union, for which they have shed so much noble blood, and take up arms to help the dilapidated and waning power of the Southern Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: The rebels seem to be a good deal in doubt how to deal with the Northwestern States. They are very anxious to deal with them separately, and very desirous so to act as to induce them to desert the cause of the Union, for which they have shed so much noble blood, and take up arms to help the dilapidated and waning power of the Southern Confederacy. But they do not quite agree among themselves as to the tone which should be adopted as most likely to produce such a result; and the consequence is that from the depths of rebeldom there come up, conveyed by the Richmond Press, voices as discordant in tone as that of Mr. Orator Puff.

abstract: Both the official and the Press dispatches relating to the defeat of the rebels under PEGRAM, near Somerset, Ky., on the 30th ult., prove it to have been very complete. The enemy numbered over 2,600 men, and were at least two to one as compared with our force under Gen. GILMORE.
lead_paragraph: Both the official and the Press dispatches relating to the defeat of the rebels under PEGRAM, near Somerset, Ky., on the 30th ult., prove it to have been very complete. The enemy numbered over 2,600 men, and were at least two to one as compared with our force under Gen. GILMORE, PEGRAM chose his own position, after some skirmishing, and defended it with six cannon. He was driven from one position to another -- the last one being carried by storm, when the rebels were driven in confusion toward the Cumberland River, the fighting having lasted five hours. The rebel loss is put down at fifty killed and nearly four hundred prisoners, including twenty commissioned officers. They also lost nearly 450 cattle which they had captured, and two stands of colors. Our loss in killed, wounded and missing will not exceed thirty. The remainder of the rebel force succeeded in escaping across the Cumberland, but at last accounts were closely pursued by Gen. GILMORE and his victorious troops. It is also announced that CLUKE's guerrillas, which have been operating in the vicinity of Mount Sterling, have been completely dispersed of by the Tenth Kentucky cavalry.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the New-York County Tax Levy was reported favorably, and ordered to a third reading. A number of bills were passed -- among them the one to incorporate the General Sangerbund Association of New-York; the one to punish frauds in the use of false stamps and trademarks; the one relative to the trust funds in the hands of the Clerk of the Court of Appeals, and the one extending the terms of office of heads of Departments in New-York. The bill appropriating $150,000 for the Lake Ontario, Auburn and New-York Railroad was lost. During the evening session, the New-York Harbor Defence bill was made the special order for to-day.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the New-York County Tax Levy was reported favorably, and ordered to a third reading. A number of bills were passed -- among them the one to incorporate the General Sangerbund Association of New-York; the one to punish frauds in the use of false stamps and trademarks; the one relative to the trust funds in the hands of the Clerk of the Court of Appeals, and the one extending the terms of office of heads of Departments in New-York. The bill appropriating $150,000 for the Lake Ontario, Auburn and New-York Railroad was lost. During the evening session, the New-York Harbor Defence bill was made the special order for to-day.

abstract: OF THE POTOMAC.--In another part of this morning's TIMES we publish the material portion of Gen. BARNARD'S report of the Engineering Department of the Army of the Potomac, especially during its campaign on the Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: OF THE POTOMAC. -- In another part of this morning's TIMES we publish the material portion of Gen. BARNARD's report of the Engineering Department of the Army of the Potomac, especially during its campaign on the Peninsula. For some reason, which it seems very difficult to understand, the reports of the various departments of this army have been, up to the present time, carefully withheld from the knowledge of the public. Gen. MCCLELLAN, it is now understood, in spite of the very peremptory assertions of the Albany Atlas and Argus to the contrary, made no report to the War Department of the detailed movements and operations of the army under his command, though he did furnish a preliminary and partial report of operations in October last, of which the telegraph, this morning, gives a digest. The reports of Gens. HOOKER, KEYES, HEINTZELMAN and KEARNEY of the battle of Williamsburgh were given to the public some weeks since. But of the more general operations of the Army of the Potomac, while under Gen. MCCLELLAN's command, we have had no official reports whatever. Gen. BARNARD's interesting report is the first contribution which has been made to the history of that important campaign. It gives in detail a statement of all that was done by the engineer department toward the attainment of the object for which the Peninsular campaign was undertaken.

abstract: An ovation such as is rarely given men of whatever merit, was tendered Gen. B.F. BUTLER last night at the Academy of Music. The Mayor presided and welcomed the guest of the city in terms most complimentary, after which Gen. BUTLER delivered a lengthy and explicit address, giving his views as to the state of affairs, North and South.

abstract: The welcome extended to Gen. BUTLER last night, testified the profound sense entertained in this City of the brilliant and important services he has rendered the country, and of the marked ability with which he has performed the duties imposed upon him by the Government.
lead_paragraph: The welcome extended to Gen. BUTLER last night, testified the profound sense entertained in this City of the brilliant and important services he has rendered the country, and of the marked ability with which he has performed the duties imposed upon him by the Government. The Academy of Music was crowded to its utmost capacity by as intelligent and distinguished an audience of ladies and gentlemen as was ever assembled in this City; and the General was received with a degree of enthusiasm seldom extended to any popular favorite. Mayor OPDYKE welcomed him to New-York in an address rehearsing the leading incidents of his career since the commencement of the war, and pronouncing the warmest eulogiums upon each of the acts by which it has been distinguished.

abstract: Andrew Cochrane vs. James Eldridge. -- This was an action upon a judgment recovered against the defendant in the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania for $7,935 81, damages and costs. Judgment was obtained in this case by default, for want of answer, for $8,801 63, in March, 1862. Upon this judgment execution was issued and returned unsatisfied. An order for the examination of the defendant in Proceedings supplementary to execution was served, but not heeded by the defendant. Whereupon an attachment was issued and the defendant arrested.

abstract: branches of the Legislature have again passed the bill to aid the construction of the Susquehannah railroad. We trust it will promptly receive the Governor's signature. This important measure has been quite long enough made the sport of Executive vetoes. It ought long since to have become a law, for the section it is designed to favor is fairly entitled to the aid which the bill proposes to give it, and the repeated indorsements which it has received at the hands of the Legislature should be regarded as sufficient proof of the willingness of the people of the State to sanction the loan.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MARETZEK's fourth matinee will take place to-day, and extraordinary efforts have been made to render it one of the most attractive ever given. The entire opera of "Linda" will be played, and also the second act of "Masseniello." The castes of these two works embrace the names of all the artists of Mr. MARETZEK's company. If the weather is at all respectable, there will undoubtedly be one of the most fashionable and brilliant audiences of the season. The ladies only want such an opportunity to flash their Spring bonnets on an astonished and somewhat incommoded public.

abstract: We have advices from Europe three days later, by the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Canada. She left Liverpool on the 21st and Queenstown in the 22d ult. Intelligence of still further depredations by the Alabama reaches us by this arrival. The ship Washington, from Callao for Antwerp, had arrived at Southampton, and reported having been captured by the pirate on the 20th of February, but released on giving bonds in $50,000. She had on board the crews of three vessels which had been captured and burnt -- the Golden Eagle, the Olive Jane and the Palmetto. The rebel Cotton loan had caused considerable excitement in the English and French money markets. The bidding was expected to close on the afternoon of the 21st, much more having been offered than needed, particularly in London and Paris. In Liverpool the offers were not very heavy. The London Times says that very little political feeling was manifested in the matter, it being regarded simply as a cotton speculation. The Star and Daily News denounce the loan in most decided terms, as aiding and abetting the Slave Power. Mr. SEYMOUR FITZGERALD had given notice in the House of Commons of his intention to ask whether the British Government had accepted, or intended to accept, a proposition made by President LINCOLN as to measures to inquire into any just complaints of the violation of neutral rights. There was not much change in the aspect of Polish affairs. The debate in the French Senate was concluded on the 19th. It was decided to send all petitions to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, -- leaving the whole matter virtually in the hands of the Emperor. A popular demonstration in favor of Poland had taken place in Paris. The latest news from Poland is regarded as showing that the revolution is becoming general. With regard to the success of LANGIEWICZ, dispatches are contradictory. He is said in one to have defeated the Russians, and in another to have been himself defeated. The commander of the French forces in Cochin China is said to have made an urgent call for reinforcements, -- and Gen. FOREY, commanding in Mexico, is also said to have made a demand for 6,000 more men. The arrangements for a prize fight for the championship of England between HEE[???] and KING had been made. The contest is [???] down for the 8th of December. There had been but a slight advance during the week in the Liverpool Cotton marker. Breadstuffs were de[???], and Provisions dull. Consols were [???]ed at 92@52 1/[???] for money.

abstract: The inquest on the body of Mrs. SUSAN THOMAS was continued before Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, yesterday, and some of the evidence elicited was of more importance than any heretofore given. Yet, the case still remains in mystery. That portion of the intestines found with the body are to be analyzed, and for this purpose the inquest has been adjourned two weeks.
lead_paragraph: The inquest on the body of Mrs. SUSAN THOMAS was continued before Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, yesterday, and some of the evidence elicited was of more importance than any heretofore given. Yet, the case still remains in mystery. That portion of the intestines found with the body are to be analyzed, and for this purpose the inquest has been adjourned two weeks.

abstract: The report of the United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on the subject of mediation, is the best thing which has yet appeared from any source addressed to foreign nations. Mr. SEWARD said the same thing, but, unfortunately, the Foreign Secretary's florid style is not appreciated in France, and such a declaration as this, coming from a unanimous Committee and from the conservative Senate, was much needed, and will exert a most salutary influence.

abstract: There is a general prejudice against the stars and bars; though in itself a handsome banner, it is said to be too like the old Yankee concern, which has become so hateful. Fortunately, it is not the flag under which our armies have won their most signal successes; and many believe that it will be hard now to supersede the crimson battle flag with its starred St. Andrew's Cross of Blue. It has claims upon us now; for was not this the banner that waved along the lines of the Confederates when they pressed fiercely upon MCCLELLAN's hosts through the woods and marshes of the Peninsula, until its crimson flutter was a vision of terror and vengeance to the flying foe? Was not this the glorious flag that struck panic into the legions of POPE when they saw it flash upon their rear like a crimson star? It has waved defiance from the heights of Fredericksburgh, and Potomac, from the mountain to the sea, has fondly reflected its blood-red gleam. Under its shadow great soldiers have died with one last look upon its dear cross, and in the hour of victory it has seemed transfigured into something godlike when the rapturous shout of our Southern soldiery shook its fold like a storm. It will be hard to supersede this battle-flag,
lead_paragraph: There is a general prejudice against the stars and bars; though in itself a handsome banner, it is said to be too like the old Yankee concern, which has become so hateful. Fortunately, it is not the flag under which our armies have won their most signal successes; and many believe that it will be hard now to supersede the crimson battle flag with its starred St. Andrew's Cross of Blue. It has claims upon us now; for was not this the banner that waved along the lines of the Confederates when they pressed fiercely upon MCCLELLAN's hosts through the woods and marshes of the Peninsula, until its crimson flutter was a vision of terror and vengeance to the flying foe? Was not this the glorious flag that struck panic into the legions of POPE when they saw it flash upon their rear like a crimson star? It has waved defiance from the heights of Fredericksburgh, and Potomac, from the mountain to the sea, has fondly reflected its blood-red gleam. Under its shadow great soldiers have died with one last look upon its dear cross, and in the hour of victory it has seemed transfigured into something godlike when the rapturous shout of our Southern soldiery shook its fold like a storm. It will be hard to supersede this battle-flag,

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a large amount of routine business was done. The Oswego and Syracuse Railroad bill was ordered to a third reading; also the bill incorporating the Mechanics' and Traders' Exchange in New-York; also the bill incorporating the Dry Goods Clerks' Early Closing Association. The Assembly Gold bill was reported by the Bank Committee with an amendment prohibiting banks from loaning on gold, bills of exchange, or certificates of deposit in gold, under any circumstances. The New-York County Tax Levy was passed; also the bill to facilitate the acquisition of lands by the Croton Water Board; also the bill appropriating $150,000 for the Auburn, Lake Ontario and New-York Railroad; also the bill authorizing the laying of sidewalks and planting of shade-trees along the highways of the State. The bill appropriating $500,000 for the defence of the harbor of New-York was ordered to a third reading. During the evening session Senator SMITH reported sundry amendments to the Militia law. The bill appropriating $100,000 for the improvement of the Hudson River was ordered to a third reading.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a large amount of routine business was done. The Oswego and Syracuse Railroad bill was ordered to a third reading; also the bill incorporating the Mechanics' and Traders' Exchange in New-York; also the bill incorporating the Dry Goods Clerks' Early Closing Association. The Assembly Gold bill was reported by the Bank Committee with an amendment prohibiting banks from loaning on gold, bills of exchange, or certificates of deposit in gold, under any circumstances. The New-York County Tax Levy was passed; also the bill to facilitate the acquisition of lands by the Croton Water Board; also the bill appropriating $150,000 for the Auburn, Lake Ontario and New-York Railroad; also the bill authorizing the laying of sidewalks and planting of shade-trees along the highways of the State. The bill appropriating $500,000 for the defence of the harbor of New-York was ordered to a third reading. During the evening session Senator SMITH reported sundry amendments to the Militia law. The bill appropriating $100,000 for the improvement of the Hudson River was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: The ship Washington is mentioned in the foreign news as having been captured by the Alabama, but released on bond, There are two American ships Washington one belonging in Gardiner, Me., and the other in New-York. We are left in doubt as to which is the one captured. The former is of 1,226 tons burden, and the latter 1,655 classes A2 and A 1 respectively.
lead_paragraph: The ship Washington is mentioned in the foreign news as having been captured by the Alabama, but released on bond, There are two American ships Washington -- one belonging in Gardiner, Me., and the other in New-York. We are left in doubt as to which is the one captured. The former is of 1,226 tons burden, and the latter 1,655 -- classes A 2 and A 1 1/2 respectively.

abstract: Gen. JOHNSTON reviewed the troops on yesterday. The spectacle was by no means brilliant in point of pageantry, but as an exhibition of swarthy strength was imposing in the extreme. Gen. BRAGG was not on the field; he is with Mrs, BRAGG, who is lying dangerously ill at Winchester.

abstract: Last night the steamers Eclipse and Lizzie Martin were fired into below here on the Cumberland. Both escaped. Several more boats are below. The Luminary is safe at Donelson. The gunboat St. Clair, which engaged the enemy, was crippled, but was repaired to-day at Donelson.

abstract: Just before the close of the late Congress, Mr. EDWIN A. STEVENS Proposed to complete the naval battery on the stocks, at Hoboken, at his own expense, and submit it to the severest tests known to modern navigation and gunnery, provided the Government would buy it at a stipulated price, in the event of its success. Mr. STEVENS claims extraordinary power of his Battery.
lead_paragraph: Just before the close of the late Congress, Mr. EDWIN A. STEVENS Proposed to complete the naval battery on the stocks, at Hoboken, at his own expense, and submit it to the severest tests known to modern navigation and gunnery, provided the Government would buy it at a stipulated price, in the event of its success. Mr. STEVENS claims extraordinary miles an hour, turn in an incredibly short time on its own centre, throw a greater weight of metal at a broadside than any iron-clad of which we have knowledge, and be absolutely invulnerable to the shot of the most powerful pieces of ordnance known to modern war. In test of this last and vital quality Mr. STEVENS proposed to have his Battery fired upon at short range (300 yards) with any gun that might be chosen for the purpose.

abstract: -- We have already referred to the rivalry which has been established between two associations, calling themselves with equal justice Loyal Leagues, -- each striving, as we are bound to assume, to outdo the other in efforts to sustain the Government in its contest with rebellion. The first of these, of which Gen. SCOTT is President, was organized at the first great meeting held at Cooper Institute on the 6th of March, at which Messrs. BRADY, VAN BUREN, DALY and others made those eloquent appeals to the Democracy on behalf of the country which have had so much influence in arousing the loyalty and patriotism of the whole people in the prosecution of the war. This association announces, in an advertising column, this morning, its purpose to celebrate, by a public meeting on Madison-square, on the 20th of April, that grand uprising of the loyal sentiment of the Northern States which followed the attack on Fort Sumter, and which was the first in the series of those magnificent demonstrations which have, from that time to this, testified the devotion of the people to the Constitution and the Union.

abstract: A dispatch from the Army of the Potomac embodies an extract from an order issued by Gen. HOOKER, directing a general muster of all the troops, on the 10th inst., in accordance with instructions from the War Department. The muster-rolls are then to be immediately sent to the Adjutant-General of the Army, for the use of the Provost-Marshal in making drafts to fill up regiments and batteries to the proper standard. Our Washington dispatches announce the probability of this draft being ordered very soon.

abstract: If there is any one reason why the people of the Northern States are determined to persist in the prosecution of the war, it is that there should be no dismemberment of the country, no hostile nation set down by our side within the limits which we have always admitted for the American people. Thus far not even the boldest Copperhead has dared to declare himself in favor of such a dismemberment. Even VALLANDIGHAM, while proclaiming himself in favor of peace, was careful to declare that he was "for peace to save the Union." It was not safe even for him, speaking as he was, in the very den of the Copperheads in this City, to announce himself in favor of a division of the country.
lead_paragraph: If there is any one reason why the people of the Northern States are determined to persist in the prosecution of the war, it is that there should be no dismemberment of the country, no hostile nation set down by our side within the limits which we have always admitted for the American people. abstract: PROMPT PUNISHMENT OF A SHAMEFUL ATTEMPT TO DEFRAUD SOLDIERS. Officer CHARLES GARDNER, of the City Hall Police, yesterday arrested the driver of coach No. 184, named ANDREW J. SMITH, and owned by THOMAS McDONALD, for charging $1.50 for conveying two wounded soldiers from the foot of Cortlandistreet to the New-England Relief Rooms, being an overcharge of seventy-five cents.
lead_paragraph: PROMPT PUNISHMENT OF A SHAMEFUL ATTEMPT TO DEFRAUD SOLDIERS. -- Officer CHARLES GARDNER, of the City Hall Police, yesterday arrested the driver of coach No. 184, named ANDREW J. SMITH, and owned by THOMAS MCDONALD, for charging $1.50 for conveying two wounded soldiers from the foot of Cortlandistreet to the New-England Relief Rooms, being an overcharge of seventy-five cents. On observing the attempted cheat, the officer compelled a return of $1 of the money, and on taking SMITH to the Mayor's office and making a complaint against him for violating the Corporation ordinances, the Mayor promptly revoked his license. The fellow impudently presumed to excuse himself for his imfamous treatment of our country's brave defenders in this case by representing that he had conveyed soldiers about the City gratis in other instances. This is only an instance of the extortion extensively practiced upon the wounded returning home and passing through the City by our heartless hackmen. Defectives are on their track, however, and the Mayor gives the assurance of prompt punishment in every clear case.

abstract: On Monday Gen. Thumb and wife gave the first of a series of public receptions in this City at Irving Hall. As a natural consequence that place of favorite resort has suddenly become doubly famous and attractive, as was evidenced on the occasion alluded to by the impetuous throne of visitors. The kindness with which the General and his lady have consented to postpone, for a season, their European tour, and favor the Metropolis with their presence, cannot be otherwise than fully appreciated by the thousands who, although anxious to gaze upon the happy couple, had not a prior opportunity, as well as by the untold numbers who, having once seen, have sufficient inducement for again indulging their sight. The afternoon reception was announced to take place at 3 P.M., but it was a full hour after the appointed time before the lilliputians made their appearance. They came upon the stage from a side entrance, the General attired in his Napoleonic costume, and his little wife in her costly bridal robe, adorned with innumerable brilliants. The entertainment commenced with the song, "The Cottage by the Sea," sung with much effect by Mrs. STRATTON, after which the General assumed various attitudes, supposed to have been original with the great NAPOLEON. The remainder of the entertainment was diversified with song, representations, conversation and music, and was highly enjoyed by those present. In the evening the hall was largely attended. The receptions were continued every day and evening during the week. On Monday they will commence their Levees in Newark, N.J.
lead_paragraph: On Monday Gen. Thumb and wife gave the first of a series of public receptions in this City at Irving Hall. As a natural consequence that place of favorite resort has suddenly become doubly famous and attractive, as was evidenced on the occasion alluded to by the impetuous throne of visitors. The kindness with which the General and his lady have consented to postpone, for a season, their European tour, and favor the Metropolis with their presence, cannot be otherwise than fully appreciated by the thousands who, although anxious to gaze upon the happy couple, had not a prior opportunity, as well as by the untold numbers who, having once seen, have sufficient inducement for again indulging their sight. The afternoon reception was announced to take place at 3 P.M., but it was a full hour after the appointed time before the lilliputians made their appearance. They came upon the stage from a side entrance, the General attired in his Napoleonic costume, and his little wife in her costly bridal robe, adorned with innumerable brilliants. The entertainment commenced with the song, "The Cottage by the Sea," sung with much effect by Mrs. STRATTON, after which the General assumed various attitudes, supposed to have been original with the great NAPOLEON. The remainder of the entertainment was diversified with song, representations, conversation and music, and was highly enjoyed by those present. In the evening the hall was largely attended. The receptions were continued every day and evening during the week. On Monday they will commence their Levees in Newark, N.J.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 26th ult., we receive interesting news from the Isthmus, and from Central and South America. The treasure list of the Northern Light is a very light one. News had reached Aspinwall from Greytown, by the British steamer Tamar, that the Government of Nicaragua had seized all the steamers, warehouses, provisions and other property belonging to the Nicaragua Transit Company, on the ground that the Company had violated their contract, and thus forfeited it. It was understood in Aspinwall that the default in the Company was in the non-payment of five or six thousand dollars due the Government. An agent of the Company had arrived at Aspinwall to ask assistance in the matter from United States ships of war. A full statement of the circumstances attending the seizure will be found in the deposition of the agent, given in our correspondent's letter. It was considered doubtful whether the passengers coming down from San Francisco would be allowed to cross Nicaragua, in which case they would be compelled to proceed to Panama. There was no later news from Bogota. All intercourse had ceased between New-Granada and Ecuador, in consequence of the unfriendly action of the latter against MOSQUERA. There were some apprehensions of a war. News from Guatemala and Salvador is to the 12th ult. President CARRERA, of Guatemala, had reached his capital after his defeat and retreat, with some 3,000 men, leaving 1,500 men as a corps of observation near the frontier. He lost in the battle of the 24th of February at least 600 men. It was thought that a settlement would be made between the two Governments. Nicaragua had suspended friendly relations with Salvador. The news from the States further South -- Peru, Bolivia, Chili, etc. -- is without importance.

abstract: In a previous letter I alluded to the sympathy of the German people with the North in ita struggle against the rebellion. This feeling has been materially increased by the unfortunate condition of affairs at present existing here; and many are now looking anxiously to America for a return of that peace, which obtained, not by compromise, but by arms, will insure them for the future a tranquil home in the New World.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Saturday, March 14, 1863.

abstract: The Atlanta (Ga.) papers state that a few days ago some fifteen or twenty women, residents of that city, all decently dressed, collected together on one of the principal streets, and made an impressment of about two hundred pounds of bacon belonging to private parties. They did it in a quiet, yet bold and determined manner, one of them quietly taking out a Colt's revolver and standing guard while the others removed the bacon. They first offered to buy it at prices such as the Government is paying, but finding the holder unwilling to sell at such rates, announced their determination to seize it, which determination they resolutely carried out. They were soldiers' wives who had large families to support.

abstract: The Spring of 1863 has opened propitiously for the operatives at the Navy-yard. The ordinary business of repairing three-fourths of the vessels used up on squadron duty has been augmented by the addition to the constructing department of three new vessels besides those on the stocks. Over 4,500 names are on the pay roll, and the monthly disbursements are near $300,000. A Bureau of Navigation has been established separately to meet the increased wants of that branch of the service. The aspect of the premises is in process of improvement. New residences for the master and other officers are laid out. The ordnance building has been enlarged by two stories, and new launching ways occupy the hitherto unincumbered docks. The ornamentation of the ornamental square is now complete, and the guns are most artistically placed on skids within the paling; Mr. EUSTICE is casting shot for 15-inch guns on his own principle, and all the departments are filled with work. In the stream the transport Union and the steam sloop Ticonderoga are ready for sea; the Seminole and some other craft are in course of repair. The amount of work done on the premises may be inferred from the following fleet, now in course of building and completion:

abstract: -- The examination of JOSEPH COX and PETER BURNS and wife, in their participation in the robbery of WESTON, DORTIC & Co., of $10,000 in gold, came off yesterday morning before Justice PARSONS. The only witness examined was FREDERIC DE BILLIER, a member of the firm, who testified as to COX taking the gold and then absenting himself from New-York. COX, BURNS and his wife were then committed to jail, to await the decision of the magistrate as to what disposition he will make of the party -- whether to hold them here for trial or hand them over to the authorities of the City of New-York.
lead_paragraph: -- The examination of JOSEPH COX and PETER BURNS and wife, in their participation in the robbery of WESTON, DORTIC & Co., of $10,000 in gold, came off yesterday morning before Justice PARSONS. abstract: -- A correspondent of the Ohio Slate Journal, writing from Wheeling, Va., mentions the following scene which lately occurred on the Central Ohio Railroad. Bastile Olds, on returning to the Legislature, happened to get into the same car with Gen. Jim Lane, of Kansas. Taking a seat opposite him, he discovered something unpleasant to his sight, and inquired of the conductor if it was possible that Jim Lane was in the car across the aisle. An affirmative answer was given, the "martyr" faced about and kept a steady gaze out of the window. Lane, not noticing the Doctor, inadvertently changed his position, and came and sat down in the same seat. Olds now looked madder than he ever did out of the iron bars of Fort Lafayette. Amused and surprised at the strange conduct of a fellow passenger, Lane inquired of the conductor, also, who it was that was by his side. "Dr. Olds," was the reply. Burning with indignation, the General "hacked down," by turning his back upon the martyr, and thus they rode till they reached the end of the Doctor's journey.
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent of the Ohio Slate Journal, writing from Wheeling, Va., mentions the following scene which lately occurred on the Central Ohio Railroad. Bastile Olds, on returning to the Legislature, happened to get into the same car with Gen. Jim Lane, of Kansas. Taking a seat opposite him, he discovered something unpleasant to his sight, and inquired of the conductor if it was possible that Jim Lane was in the car across the aisle. An affirmative answer was given, the "martyr" faced about and kept a steady gaze out of the window. Lane, not noticing the Doctor, inadvertently changed his position, and came and sat down in the same seat. Olds now looked madder than he ever did out of the iron bars of Fort Lafayette. Amused and surprised at the strange conduct of a fellow passenger, Lane inquired of the conductor, also, who it was that was by his side. "Dr. Olds," was the reply. Burning with indignation, the General "hacked down," by turning his back upon the martyr, and thus they rode till they reached the end of the Doctor's journey.

abstract: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 2d inst., at 3 P.M.; Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, President of the Society, in the chair, assisted by Wm. B. CROSBY, BENJ. L. SWAN, and JAMES LENOX, Esqs., Vice-Presidents. The death of Hon. ELISHA WHITTLESEY, one of the Vice-Presidents, was announced, a Wereupon Rev. JOHN C. FLETCHER was called upon to read the 90th Psalm and offer prayer.
lead_paragraph: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 2d inst., at 3 1/2 P.M.; Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, President of the Society, in the chair, assisted by Wm. B. CROSBY, BENJ. L. SWAN, and JAMES LENOX, Esqs., Vice-Presidents. The death of Hon. ELISHA WHITTLESEY, one of the Vice-Presidents, was announced, a Wereupon Rev. JOHN C. FLETCHER was called upon to read the 90th Psalm and offer prayer. Three new auxiliaries were recognized: one in Iowa, one in Ohio, and one in New-York. Communications were received from agents and others, in regard to the home work, especially as to resuming operations in the Border States, distributions from New-Orleans, and the access to the Southern States for the books of this Society; from Rev. Dr. BERGNE, of the British and Foreign Bible Society, in reference to printing the Arabic Scriptures; from Rev. I.G. BLISS, of Constantinople, in regard to the depot at Smyrna, and also electrotyping she book of Psalms in the Armenian and Armeno-Turkish languages, also relating interesting cases of conversion by reading the Scriptures; from Rev. L.S. JACOBY, Bremen, sending his account of expenditures in behalt of this Society, and showing the progress of the work of Bible distribution in Germany; from Rev. JACOB CHAMBERLAIN, of India, relative to an extended tour of missionary exploration and Bible distribution in the Telugu country, Grants were made of 10,000 Testaments to the Christian Commission, for distribution from Philadelphia; 24,000 Testaments and 1,000 Bibles for the New-York branch of the Commission; 10,000 for Virginia; for the volunteers of the army in rendezvous at Cleveland, O., books to the value of $695 28; to Agent LORD, 2,000 for Illinois soldiers, and 525 for U.S. hospitals in Western Virginia. Some Spanish books were granted for Central America, and Portuguese Bibles and Testaments for distribution in foreign vessels, with a small grant of Bibles and Testaments for Mexico. Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, made some interesting remarks in regard to the Bible in Brazil, where he was. formerly Agent for this Society. An Agent was appointed for Panama and Central America.

abstract: -- Judge-Advocate Gen. HOLT, by a simple recital of the facts connected with a Union expedition into Northern Georgia, and the capture and subsequent sufferings of those engaged in it, has made out a tragic tale of thrilling interest. It appears that just one year ago, the late Gen. MITCHEL set on foot an expedition to destroy the communications on the Georgia State Railroad, between Atlanta and Chattanooga. It was one of those bold designs in which the mind of Gen. MITCHEL was fertile. Judge HOLT says, that "the expedition, in the daring of its conception, had the wildness of a romance; while in the gigantic and overwhelming results which it sought, and was likely to accomplish, it was absolutely sublime." By a circumstance that could not be known or foreseen, and the details of which are given in the report in another column, the expedition was baulked, and the two dozen men engaged in it were dispersed to the woods, where they were hunted down by bloodhounds, and all taken prisoners. Now commenced the worst barbarism of the rebels, and now, and to the end, was shown the perfect heroism of our men. One Spartan lad of eighteen, from Ohio, was tortured in a manner that would have done discredit to Spain three hundred years ago; but his fortitude under suffering was greater even than their atrocity; and after great vicissitudes, he has lived to receive honors at the hands of the President in behalf of the country. The men were thrust into a negro jail and subjected to sufferings compared with which those of the "Black Hole" of Calcutta were light, and a few days reduced them to the verge of death. Their leader, Mr. ANDREWS, of Kentucky, was hung at Atlanta; and seven others of them were carried to Knoxville and hung in the most revolting manner. "They died," says Judge HOLT, "as all true soldiers of the Republic should die in the presence of its foes." The remaining prisoners, now reduced to fourteen, learning that they also were to be hung, formed a plan to escape from the jail, which they carried into execution. Six of these, after long and painful wanderings, succeeded in reaching our lines; of the fate of two of them nothing is known; and the remaining six were recaptured and taken to Richmond, where they were confined in a wretched dungeon until a few days since, when they were exchanged; and they have lived to make depositions and testify to these facts before the Judge-Advocate General in Washington. "Thus," says Judge HOLT, "at the end of eleven months, terminated their pitiless persecutions; persecutions begun and continued amid indignities and sufferings on their part, and atrocities on the part of their traitorous foes, which illustrate far more faithfully than any human language could express it, the demoniac spirit of a revolt, every throb of whose life is a crime against the very race to which we belong."

abstract: -- Does anybody in New-York, Washington or Arkansas know what has become of the very considerable Union army which operated with such brilliancy in Western Arkansas in the closing months of last year? Five or six months ago that army was hewing its way down through that State in a style which startled all observers; and the rebels fled before it after a no less wonderful fashion. When it had chased them over the Boston Mountains and down to and across the Arkansas River, our men took an hour's sleep upon their arms, but woke up to learn that the sleepless skedaddlers were nearly a hundred miles off, at Arkadelphia, and were still flying. Immediately that BLUNT, with his Homeric heroes, had achieved these feats, he was removed from command of the conquering army -probably on the theory that he had done as much as one man should do for his country -and a gentleman of the name of SCHOFIELD reigned in his stead. Since then, that is, since the early part of December, we have heard hardly a word from the Arkansas Union army. Some might think it had been sent to reinforce ROSECRANS or GRANT; but this is not the case. It is still somewhere in the farther West, in Southern Missouri or Arkansas, we believe. What it is doing, or what SCHOFIELD means it shall do, it is hard to say; and we doubt if even Gen. HALLECK could tell.
lead_paragraph: -- Does anybody in New-York, Washington or Arkansas know what has become of the very considerable Union army which operated with such brilliancy in Western Arkansas in the closing months of last year? abstract: FOWLSBY, of the Fifth New-York Engineer corps, belonging to New-York City, was accidentally drowned whilst crossing the Chesapeake on Tuesday night. Further information can be obtained at the New-England Rooms, where his baggage now is.

abstract: Services commemorative of the mysterious descent into Hades of the Crucified Saviour were held at Trinity Church yesterday. At the morning prayer there was a large attendance, and the services were conducted by Rev. Drs. OGILBY and VINTON. Rev. Dr. DIX preached the sermon, and Rev. Dr. VINTON said the closing prayer and pronounced the benediction. The "Venite." the "Benedicite," the 6th Selection, including "De Profundis," the "Benedictus," and, after the sermon, the "Miserere," were sung, the great organ being silent, and Mr. CUTLER accompanying the choir on a small organ. In the afternoon Evening Prayer took place in Trinity Church at 3 o'clock, after which Right Reverend the Bishop (POTTER) of this Diocese administered the rite of confirmation to forty candidates.

abstract: HOOKER, ROSECRANS, GRANT, BANKS, and HUNTER -- these are the five commanders to whom the whole country has been looking with the highest hope and the greatest eagerness ever since the beginning of the year. Each of the three officers first named commands a first-class army, both as regards magnitude and efficiency. The army and navy under BANKS, and the army and navy under HUNTER, both come under the category of great, though not first-class forces. Each of the three chief armies -- that of the Potomac, that of Tennessee, and that of Mississippi -- fought a great battle in December last: Fredericksburgh, on the 13th; Vicksburgh, on the 27th, and Murfreesboro on the 31st and two following days -- the two former being repulses, and the latter one of the most valuable victories of the war. Gen. BANKS has accomplished nothing since he and his troops arrived in New-Orleans in December last; nor has Gen. HUNTER attempted or accomplished anything since he took command in South Carolina. HOOKER has spent his time and strength since Fredericksburgh, in reorganizing and disciplining his army, which was much damaged by the severe campaigns of 1862. ROSECRANS has chosen to remain on the defensive for three months, probably not feeling strong enough, under circumstances that have existed, to achieve such a decided victory as his next battle should be. GRANT has labored harder than any other General in the service since the year began. He had probably the most difficult job to do, and one that could less afford to wait than any of the others. He has kept his army actively at work, and has shown himself a man of remarkable expedients, even though fortune has decided that those expedients should not be crowned with success.

abstract: A conference of Tammany politicans was recently held in this city, at which, in view of the exigencies of the party, and the Wood-Mozart movements, it was agreed that the council fires of that section of the Democratic party should onve more be lit and that, too, at an early day. Therefore, as soon as, if not before, the Legislature has adjourned, there will be a grand gathering at Old Tammany.
lead_paragraph: A conference of Tammany politicans was recently held in this city, at which, in view of the exigencies of the party, and the Wood-Mozart movements, it was agreed that the council fires of that section of the Democratic party should onve more be lit and that, too, at an early day. Therefore, as soon as, if not before, the Legislature has adjourned, there will be a grand gathering at Old Tammany. Its principal object will be to place the party right before the country, by retracing the steps taken in following after WOOD, and, if possible, save Gov. SEYMOUR from the consequences of the damaging contact with the chief of Copperheads, and the infusion of the treasonous doctrines of BROOKS, BURR & CO. More than one month ago, I predicted that the Democratic party -- at least this section of it -- by the time the Legislature adjourned, would change its front and tone, and come out for the war and the Government, and against the rebellion. This is about to prove true and I expect before long to see the Seymour party claiming to be the only true war party. Things have for some time been shaping to this end, and the Wood party will be left to do what mischief they can, as a faction, in sympathy with the rebellion.

abstract: A letter to the Charleston Courier, from Columbia, Tenn., gives an interesting account of a narrow escape made by VAN DORN from the capture of himself and whole command. It appears that on the 11th ult., he had taken an advantageous position to make a short opposition to the advance of a superior force of the enemy, and then retire across Duck River, over which a pontoon bridge was supposed to have been completed. Upon attempting to launch it, it was discovered to be impossible, as the river had overflowed its banks, and was sweeping on with the greatest rapidity, bearing on its bosom huge logs and drift wood, hurled down with such velocity as to render the laying down of the pontoon an utter impossibility. To render matters still worse, the rope, by means of which the ferry-boat was crossed, became submerged, and another one was with difficulty stretched across, by means of which they were enabled to cross a boat, capable of carrying at each trip, occupying forty minutes, one wagon or eight or ten horses. The letter says:

abstract: The recalcitrant religionists of Baltimore, who could not worship in an edifice over which the national standard floated, recently appealed to Gov. BRADFORD to have the order of Gen. SCHENCK rescinded. The Governor replied to their request in a decided letter, which those to whom it was addressed had no desire to publish. Why they were so reluctant may be inferred from the concluding paragraphs of the document, which read as follows:

abstract: -- Every one in England is now anxious to learn something about Miss BRADDON, the authoress of the two most successful books of the season, Lady Audley's Secret and Aurora Floyd. The reception these have met with from the public has placed her at once on the topmost pinnacle of literary popularity -- that elevated position, indeed, where a writer can make his own terms with his publisher. It is shared at present in England by Miss EVANS, Mrs. HENRY WOOD, ANTHONY TROLLOPE and WILKIE COLLINS. The new market for Fiction opened by the immense circulation of the cheap Magazines, where good serial stories are the main attraction, has vastly increased the rate of remuneration awarded to authorship. In the palmy days of MARRYAT, JAMES, BULWER, HORACE SMITH and Mrs. GORE, twenty or thirty years back, when the modern novel took nearly its existing shape, from �500 to �1,000 was thought an extreme price. Now, we are credibly informed, at least one of the abovenamed writers has received more than five times the latter sum for a single work. Such success is enough to make the recipient a legitimate object of curiosity. It is now said that Miss BRADDON was once an actress, and has written one or two dramatic pieces. She first appeared as a writer of fiction in the cheap London serial, of indifferent repute, Reynolds' Miscellany. Her first great hit, Lady Audley's Secret, was commenced in a short-lived paper, edited by Dr. CHAS. MACKAY, now correspondent of the London Times in New-York, called Robin Goodfellow, and afterward continued in the Sixpenny Magazine, a paper of equal obscurity, but attracted no notice till it was published entire in three volumes, when it at once took rank among the most brilliant and original books of the day. Acting, doubtless, on the principle of making hay while the sun shines, Miss, BRADDON is now publishing two works simultaneously, "Eleanor's Victory," in Once a Week, and "John Marchmont's Legacy," in the Temple Bar Magazine.

Such success is enough to make the recipient a legitimate object of curiosity. It is now said that Miss BRADDON was once an actress, and has written one or two dramatic pieces. She first appeared as a writer of fiction in the cheap London serial, of indifferent repute, Reynolds' Miscellany. Her first great hit, Lady Audley's Secret, was commenced in a short-lived paper, edited by Dr. CHAS. MACKAY, now correspondent of the London Times in New-York, called Robin Goodfellow, and afterward continued in the Sixpenny Magazine, a paper of equal obscurity, but attracted no notice till it was published entire in three volumes, when it at once took rank among the most brilliant and original books of the day. Acting, doubtless, on the principle of making hay while the sun shines, Miss, BRADDON is now publishing two works simultaneously, "Eleanor's Victory," in Once a Week, and "John Marchmont's Legacy," in the Temple Bar Magazine.

abstract: Joseph W. Sawyer et al. vs. The proceeds of the Brig Cuba and her Cargo. -- This was a petition for the payment of freight out of the proceeds of a cargo of sugar. The Cuba was laden with sugar in Cuba for England. While proceeding on her voyage, she was captured by the rebel steamer Sumter and a prize crew was put on board. After she had been for sometime in possession of the prize crew, she was retaken by her original master and crew. The prize crew were put in irons, and the vessel and cargo were brought into New-York on the 21st July, 1862. On the 23d of that month she was libeled for salvage by the master and crew, who had thus rescued her, and on the 14th September, 1862, a decree was made, awarding the libelants two-fifths of the value of both vessel and cargo for salvage, and directing the costs of the libelants to be paid from the other three-fifths. A venditioni exponas was issued for the sale of the vessel and cargo, and the parties in interest agreed to fix, and did fix, by stipulation, the value or the vessel at $1,500, and that of the cargo at $16,500. In fixing the value of the cargo, its value at New-York was ascertained, and from that value $1,500 was deducted as pro rata freight to New-York.
lead_paragraph: Joseph W. Sawyer et al. vs. The proceeds of the Brig Cuba and her Cargo. -- This was a petition for the payment of freight out of the proceeds of a cargo of sugar.
