The prize crew were put in irons, and the vessel and cargo were brought into New-York on the 21st July, 1862. On the 23d of that month she was libeled for salvage by the master and crew, who had thus rescued her, and on the 14th September, 1862, a decree was made, awarding the libelants two-fifths of the value of both vessel and cargo for salvage, and directing the costs of the libelants to be paid from the other three-fifths. A venditioni exponas was issued for the sale of the vessel and cargo, and the parties in interest agreed to fix, and did fix, by stipulation, the value or the vessel at $1,500, and that of the cargo at $16,500. abstract: THOMAS ADMITTED TO BAIL. -- Mr. JOHN JACOB THOMAS, of Weehawken Heights, who was arrested to await the result of the Coroner's investigation upon the body of his wife, who was supposed to have died from the effects of poison, was admitted to bail on Saturday by Judge OGDEN, at the Hudson County Court. The amount of bail required was $10,000. Mr. SWEITZER. of Weehawken, became his bondsman. No new facts have been elicited since the adjournment of the inquest on Saturday. It is stated that the druggist at Hoboken is confident of the identity of Mrs. THOMAS, as the lady who had purchased morphine at his store on several occasions within the past year. The intestines found in the body of deceased, after having been brought to Jersey City, have not yet been placed in the hands of a chemist. Coroner FARREL applied to Prof. DRAPER, of New York, to make the analyzation, but he declined, on the ground that he had too much to do.
lead_paragraph: THOMAS ADMITTED TO BAIL. -- Mr. JOHN JACOB THOMAS, of Weehawken Heights, who was arrested to await the result of the Coroner's investigation upon the body of his wife, who was supposed to have died from the effects of poison, was admitted to bail on Saturday by Judge OGDEN, at the Hudson County Court. The intestines found in the body of deceased, after having been brought to Jersey City, have not yet been placed in the hands of a chemist. abstract: Under the auspices of the Young Men's Republican Central Committee, a meeting was held at the headquarters, corner of Broadway and Twenty-thirdstreet, Friday evening, the first of a series intended to counteract the poisonous effects of the Copperhead gatherings periodically held in the vicinity. A number of ladies graced the occasion by their presence. Mr. ARMSTRONG, the Mayor's Private Secretary, opened the proceedings with a brief statement of the objects to be attained.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Coroner COLLIN was notified that a German woman, name Mrs. SCHAFFER, had been found dead in her apartments at No. 147 Christie-street, under circumstances which rendered it probable tht she had died from the effects of violence.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Coroner COLLIN was notified that a German woman, name Mrs. SCHAFFER, had been found dead in her apartments at No. 147 Christie-street, under circumstances which rendered it probable tht she had died from the effects of violence. The Coroner, in company with Dr. ROBINSON, accordingly visited the premises, and made an examination of the victim. Wounds and bruises were found upon her head, and various other parts of her person, and from the appearance of the [???], and such information as could be gl[???]ned from the occupants of the adjoining pre[???]ses, there was no doubt that she had been dead since the early part of the previous night. The deceased it appears was a widow, and resided alone in the rear portion of the house. She was about moving away, and had already moved the lighter portion of her furniture during Friday, in the evening, as the neighbors say, she had a quarrel with a man named YOUNG, and his wife, who resided in the same house with the deceased. The [???]a[???]er was attacked first by YOUNG's wife, who s[???]zed her by the hair, as she was passing through an alley, with some furniture in her arms, knocked her down, and afterward kicked her several times, as she lay upon the ground. The screams of Mrs. SCHAEFFER brought YOUNG, the husband of the assailant, to the spot, and he at once began to kick and beat the victim. Several of the neighbors, it is alleged, heard the screams of the injured woman, and also the noise produced by the kicks and blows; and yet, strange to saw no one went to her assistance. The only evidence there is thus far of any notice having been taken of the matter, is the fact that a man named WOLF, residing in an ad joining building, called out to YOUNG during the progress of the affray, and asked the latter what he was doing. YOUNG answered, "If you dare come this way, I'll serve you in the same manner." WOLF therefore thought it prudent not to venture from his room. After her assailants left her, it is supposed that Mrs. SCRAEFFER managed in some way to crawl back to her apartments in the building. Yesterday morning, when the cartman, whom the deceased had engaged to remove her heavy pieces of furniture, entered her room, he found her body lying as though she had fallen over a chair in her efforts to reach a seat. The appearance of the body indicated that death had taken place several hours previously. The police were immediately notified, and yesterday afternoon they succeeded in taking CATHARINE YOUNG, the wife, into custody. She was locked up in the Tenth Precint Station-house to await the result. Coroner COLLIN will hold an inquest upon the body to-morrow.

abstract: News which we have from the Southwest this morning points to the possibility of the abandonment of the Mississippi by the rebels. Telegrams are said to have been received from Gen. HURLBUT at Memphis, Gen. ASBOTH at COLUMBUS, and Gen. DODGE at Corinth, reporting that there is a heavy force of rebel cavalry on the Tennessee River in the vicinity of Florence, and that the rebels are constructing bridges and floats for crossing the Tennessee in that neighborhood -indicating either a movement of BRAGG in that direction, or a movement of the Vicksburgh Army to join BRAGG. Meantime, Gen. GRANT appears to have given up the idea of capturing Vicksburgh by engineering strategy, and to have commenced preparations for its reaction in the regular way. He has succeeded in placing a battery of 84-pounder Parrotts in a position to reach the city easily, and was to have commenced a bombardment on the 27th ult., but was deterred by a storm. We learn from the Yazoo Pass Expedition that another attack on Fort Pemberton commenced on the 27th, but with what results is not known. It is thought that the attempt to gain the Yazoo in that direction will be abandoned.

abstract: A correspondent of a Lemberg journal, who has visited LANGIEWICZ in his camp, writes as follows: "At the entrance of the General's residence stand two powerful sithemen, with their weapons crossed. These form the body-guard of the insurgent General. On the left is a chamber of moderate dimensions, in the centre of which is a table of a long and oval shape, and around this sit and stand many men, who carry on so lively a discussion that one scarcely understands its purport. Some of these are strong and wiry, others are in the bloom of youth; but among those present there are weather beaten men, with gray beards and locks. At the end of the table, somewhat sidewards, sits Gen. LANGIEWICZ, engaged in writing. The noise does not disturb him. In this respect, according to the report of those around him, he possesses much presence of mind. He writes, and at the same time answers many questions, and also distributes various orders to his officers, who continually come and go. His answers were short and decided, as were his orders. At last he raised his head a little, and I could observe him more narrowly. Persons entirely disinterested would declare his appearance to be quite an ordinary one, but be pleased me on the instant. I will describe him as briefly as possible: He is of small stature, something over 30 years of age; thin, but muscular; the head in proportion, but with a weatherbeaten though fresh complexion; dark hair and somewhat spare beard; the eyes dark and large, but very beautiful; his entire expression is mild and decided, as with most thinkers. On his head he wore his sapphire-colored four-cornered cap, with dark lamb's wool trimming and a white feather. He wore also, large Polish boots, Polish hose, and a dark furtrimmed cloak. He wore also, a tri-colored sash, by which each of his officers was equally distinguished, while some were also ornamented with white and red sashes.

abstract: The services at Morning Prayer [???]n Trinity Church were largely attended, and were of an exceedingly impressive character. Rev. Dr. OGILBY, Assistant Minister of Trinity, read Morning Prayer (including the Lessons) to the Creed, which, with the remainder of the Molding Prayer, was intoned by Rev. Mr. LAMSON, of the American Chapel in Paris. Rev. Dr. VINTON, Assistant Minister of Trinity, intoned the Ante-Communion Service, and preached, Rev. Dr. OGILBY read the Offertory Sentences, Rev. Dr. VINTON offering the "Prayer for the Whole State of Christ's Church, Military," and pronouncing the Benediction. Instead of the Venite, the selection for Good Friday, from Psalms xxii., 69 and 40, was chanted: and instead of the "Proper Psalms," the 6th Selection, "Beati quorum," "De Profundis," and "Levavi ocutos." The first Lesson is the narrative (in Genesis,) of the offering, by Abraham, of his son, his only son, Isaac, on the same mount, Mount Moriah, upon which the great sacrifice, of which it was the type, was made in the fullness of time. The second lesson begins St. John's narrative of the Passion of our Saviour, closing with the words. "Now Barabbas was a robber." The "Introit" Anthem was by CUTLER, the organist of Trinity, to the words (Ps. xxii). "My God, my God, look upon me! why hast Thou forsaken me, and art so far from my health, and from the words of my complaint?" This, as well as all the music of the services, was sung by the choir, accompanied by a small organ in the chancel, the great organ being silent. The Epistle of the Day (Hebrews, ch. x) was read by Rev. Dr. OGILBY, and the Gospel, (St. John xix) being the conclusion of the Evangelist's account of the Passion of our Lord, was read by Rev. Dr. VINTON. The hymn sung before the sermon was that of WATTS:

abstract: The splendid river steamboat Clifton came to the Brooklyn Navy-yard on Monday, having been purchased by the Navy Department. The price is about $100,000. The Clifton formerly run to Staten Island. Crews were sent from the yard for the prize Steamers Virginia and Adler, which have also been bought for naval purposes. All these vessels will be immediatcly taken in hand for conversion into gunboats.

abstract: The following is a private letter just received MATAMORAS, Mexico, Wednesday, Feb. 18, 1863.  I have seen and learned enough since I have been here to make my soul bleed over the unhappy condition of my friends yet in Texas. They are murdered one by one. A small force could lift the yoke of tyranny from their necks and give them relief.

abstract: -- An exterior view of the iron-clad Monitor Tonawanda, in the course of construction at our Navy-yard, affords very little idea of the strength of the ship. It is only by an inspection of the interior that the means and appliances being used to give strength to the vessel are to be seen. One of the usual modes of strengthening the hulls of wooden ships has been adopted -- this is the placing of bars of iron diagonally along entire frame, which act as braces. Over these large timbers are being laid, which, immediately below the deck beams, will, with the five inches of plating, form a thickness of over five feet. These timbers taper off as they reach the water -- line, and there is not much of a thickness below it. The keel is five feet through, the different timbers composing it being bolted with copper bolts, an inch and a quarter in diameter, and long enough to be headed in both ends. They are driven with a sliding weight of 250 pounds. There will be a deck on a level with the top of the keel, under which most of the ship's stores will be carried. This will leave ample headroom for the officers' and seamen's quarters. -- Philadelphia Ledger, April 1.

abstract: Judge MCCUNN, yesterday, closed up the business of the March term of this Court by passing sentence upon several parties previously convicted. Among them was JOEL B. FERQUSON, who was convicted two or three months ago of obtaining $1,000 by false pretences from a fellow-member of the Bedford-st. Church, named CATHERINE CARTER. A stay of proceedings was granted at the time of the conviction, to give defendant's counsel opportunity to move for a new trial, but it appears that the friends of Mr. FERQUSON concluded to adopt the suggestion of the Court, and reimburse Mrs. CARTER for her loss, rather than risk his chances to another trial Judge MCCUNN, in passing sentence, alluded to the highly respectable standing of the defendant, and his possession for over 50 years of an unblemished character; the fact that both the complainant and defendant were members of the same church, and the scandal that had been brought upon the church by the affair. He was happy to hear from Mrs. CARTER that the defendant had returned the money to her with interest, and in view of this fact, and the fact that the verdict of the jury was accompanied by a recommendation to mercy, he felt that the ends of justice would be attained by the imposition of a nominal fine. The sentence of the Court was that the defendant pay a fine of 6 cents. One or two other sentences for trivial offences were passed, and the Court adjourned sine die.

abstract: -- The Subscriber, who cannot change his prices with the fluctuations of gold without incurring enormous expense in advertising the changes, is compelled to sell his Pens at old prices. Thinking his customers entitled to the benefit at the premium on gold, rather than the Wall-street debasers of the best currency this country ever had, he now offers to all remitting the amount of their orders in gold, the full premium in this City on the day when received. In this way he hopes to do the country and his customers some good without injuring himself, for the MORTON PEN cannot be made without gold. When Paper Money is sent. United States is preferred over any other. A.MORTON.

abstract: One would think that our domestic troubles are pretty numerous already, without an Indian invasion being added to the number. Such a contingency would scarcely seem possible, yet it is really very likely to happen. The Kiowas have made up their minds for it; so have the Cheyennes, and so have the Comanches. Even the names of some of the chief warriors have come to our knowledge.
lead_paragraph: One would think that our domestic troubles are pretty numerous already, without an Indian invasion being added to the number. Such a contingency would scarcely seem possible, yet it is really very likely to happen. The Kiowas have made up their minds for it; so have the Cheyennes, and so have the Comanches. Even the names of some of the chief warriors have come to our knowledge. The Cheyennes are to contribute their valiant WAR-BONNET and LEAN-BEAR; the Comanches are to be led by the heroic PRICKED-FOREHEAD, and the terrible TEN-BEARS, and the Apaches are to be marshaled by the Achilles of the Far-West, the renowned and unconquerable POOR-BEAR. We are informed that the Arrapahoes are to be generaled by the SPOTTED-WOLF, and the Kiowas by the YELLOW-BUFFALO. These, in fact, being the real Indian names of various representatives of the fiercest war-tribes of the remote bands of the Indian, who have recently come to Washington to arrange matters connected with the welfare of their several nations. Each in himself is a chief of great rank and standing. They have had an audience of the President, and have been dulylionized in Washington. Certain parties in New-York have invited them to come hither, and that invitation has been accepted by Maj. COLLEY, their agent. These are no squalid, degenerate specimens of our Indian allies, but the principal men of their respective tribes, arrayed in all the trappings and decorated with all the paint which Indian fashions require. Whether our Common Council will Japanese them or not we are not yet informed.

abstract: The Secretary of War has done an excellent thing in subjecting the lately released survivors of the expedition, dispatched last year by Gen. MITCHEL to destroy the communications on the Georgia State Railroad, to a regular legal examination by Judge-Advocate HOLT, in order that the almost incredible atrocities of the rebels in this case might authentically go forth to the judgment of the world. The Northern mind has become so familiar with the essential barbarism of the ruling spirit of the Confederacy, that those individual instances make but comparatively a slight impression upon it. It learns that twenty-two soldiers, engaged in a work accounted perfectly legitimate in all warfare, being discovered and fleeing to the woods, were hunted down by bloodhounds -- that one of them, a youth of eighteen, was stripped by a rebel officer and soldiers, and received on the bare back more than one hundred lashes of a raw-hide, because he would make no disclosures involving his comrades -- that, after being robbed of their money by rebel officers, they were thrust into the negro jail of Chattanooga, semi-subterranean, its only entrance a trap-door in the ceiling, and so small that all could not lie down together, so ill-ventilated that they had often to strip themselves entirely of clothing to bear the heat; swarming, too, with vermin, all handcuffed, and all bound to each other by trace chains around their necks; that, after enduring the most horrid sufferings, eight of them, contrary to every rule of war, were hung, and that others would have probably shared the same fate had they not managed to escape. The Northern mind, we say, has long since learned to expect such things, from what it knows to be the utter depravity of the rebel character. But the European people do not know it. They will not believe it except upon the most conclusive evidence. It is well, then, that the proof should be presented in the unquestionable form Judge HOLT has given it.

abstract: A rumor was current in Washington, yesterday, derived from rebel sources, that Charleston was attacked by our forces on Friday; that the attack was overwhelmingly successful, and that the city has fallen. There is a possibility that the rumor is true. A rebel dispatch, received via, Fortress Monroe, announces the landing of our forces on Seabrook's Island, and the driving in of the rebel pickets.

abstract: The matinee on Saturday brought Mr. MARETZEK's fourth week to a brilliant termination, and, we are surprised to hear, without any loss to the management. Mr. MARETZEK has suffered from a multitude of evils that are hardly likely to occur again. His singers have been sick, the weather has been bad, and on one occasion he was compelled from these combined causes to close the house. The religious austerities of the season have also probably had some influence on the attendance, although it must be confessed that the irreligious, who have no austerities, turned out in great force whenever the opera was attractive. The present week will probably be marked by moderation in the weather, and "perfect looseness" in the morals of the community. Unfortunately it is the last of Mr. MARETZEK's present campaign -- that otherwise sensible impresario being possessed with the amiable mania of visiting Boston. Why do people visit Boston, when Boston so frequently visits New-York, and stays on the slightest provocation? GRAU has been to Boston, and has acquired a deep bass voice in consequence. The Common sits heavily on his mind, and the east wind has taken up quarters in his throat. He is now fit for stratagems and spoils and -- Philadelphia -- whither he has gone. But how will Mr. MARETZEK, with his newly acclimated artists, withstand the dire influences of a Massachusetts Spring; and why should he ride Quixotically at the three hills when it is so much easier to stay in Fourteenth-street and grow opulent and easy? To the non-managerial intellect it seems slightly absurd to leave the Metropolis at a time when success is most marked and certain. The arrangements for the present week are as follows: To-night, PETRELLA's new opera of "Ione" will be produced for the first time In America. The work has been played in Europe with great success, and during Mr. MARETZEK's last season it was produced in Havana and created a perfect furore there. New scenery and costumes have been prepared, and the distribution includes the names of Mme. MEDORI, Mlle. SULZER, Signer MAZEOLENI, Signor BELLINI, Signor BIACHI, Signor RUBIO, Herr MULLER and Mme. FICHER. "Ione," if successful, will probably be repeated during the remaining performances of the week.

abstract: To-morrow night a grand ball in aid of the distressed people of Ireland will be given at the Academy of Music. The affair is gotten up under the auspices of many of our best known citizens, and promises to be a great success. Archbishop HUGHES, and Gen. MCCLELLAN, whose Headquarters are in this city for the present will certainly be there, and it has been intimated that both of these gentlemen will be called upon for a speech. However that may be, the attractions are sufficiently great to fill the house to overflowing; the inducement of charity to the sufferers in Old Erin being of itself more than enough to fill high the strong box at the door.

abstract: Blemishes on the face, called Moth, are very annoying, particularly to ladies of light complexion, as the discolored spots on the skin show more strongly on blondes than on brunettes, but they contribute greatly in marring the beauty on either, and anything that will remove Moth Patches without injuring the skin in texture or color, would no doubt be considered a great achievement in medical science. Dr. B.C. PERRY. No. 49 Bond -- st., having devoted his whole time and attention to Diseases of the Skin, will guarantee to remove Moth Patches, Freckles and other discolorations from the face without injury to either texture or color of the skin. His success in this, as in other branches of his specialty -- Diseases of the Scalp and Loss of Hair -- will warrant him in guaranteeing a Cure in every case. Dr. B.C. PERRY.

abstract: We surrender a large part of our space, this morning, to the unanimous report of the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War. It is an able, interesting and important document. It throws a flood of light on the history of the contest, and must go far toward settling the public judgment concerning many points on which public sentiment has hitherto been divided.

abstract: The Report of the Senate Committee on the "Conduct of the War" is a document of 64 closely printed octavo pages and would fill, if printed in full, not far from 20 columns of the TIMES. It opens by rehearsing the circumstances which led to the appointment of the Committee and by stating the leading motive which has guided their inquiries.
lead_paragraph: The Report of the Senate Committee on the "Conduct of the War" is a document of 64 closely printed octavo pages and would fill, if printed in full, not far from 20 columns of the TIMES. It opens by rehearsing the circumstances which led to the appointment of the Committee and by stating the leading motive which has guided their inquiries. They state that if the Army of the Pomtomac had fulfilled the expectations which were warranted by its numbers, its discipline, its courage and its appointments, the rebellion would long since have been closed. Their main object in their investigations has been, therefore, to ascertain why these expectations have been disappointed. They have taken the testimony of about; 200 witnesses, including about 100 Generals, and in the report they set forth, as clearly and dispassionately as possible, the historical facts which that large body of evidence establishes.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Northern Light, from Aspiawall on the 26th ult., we receive interesting news from the Isthmus, and from Central and South America. The treasure list of the Northern Light is a very light one. News had reached Aspinwall from Greytown, by the British steamer Tamar, that the...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Northern Light, from Aspiawall on the 26th ult., we receive interesting news from the Isthmus, and from Central and South America. The treasure list of the Northern Light is a very light one. News had reached Aspinwall from Greytown, by the British steamer Tamar, that the Government of Nicaragua had seized all the steamers, warehouses, provisions and other property belonging to the Nicaragua Transit Company, on the ground that the Company had violated their contract, and thus forfeited it. It was understood in Aspinwall that the default in the Company was in the non-payment of five or six thousand dollars due the Government. An agent of the Company had arrived at Aspinwall to ask assistance in the matter from United States ships of war. A full statement of the circumstances attending the seizure will be found in the deposition of the agent, given in our correspondent's letter. It was considered doubtful whether the passengers coming down from San Francisco would be allowed to cross Nicaragua, in which case they would be compelled to proceed to Panama. There was no later news from Bogota. All intercourse had ceased between New-Granada and Ecuador, in consequence of the unfriendly action of the latter against MOSQUERA. There were some apprehensions of a war. News from Guatemala and Salvador is to the 12th ult. President CARRERA, of Guatemala, had reached his capital after his defeat and retreat, with some 3,000 men, leaving 1,500 men as a corps of observation near the frontier. He lost in the battle of the 24th of February at least 600 men. It was thought that a settlement would be made between the two Governments. Nicaragua had suspended friendly relations with Salvador. The news from the States further South -- Peru, Bolivia, Chili, etc. -- is without importance.

abstract: My last of the 25th was dated at the mouth of Deer Creek, since which the entire expedition has returned to this place. The operation of reembarking the forces was commenced day before yesterday, and concluded yesterday morning, without annoyance from the enemy, who, although in the vicinity in considerable force, could not attack us without coming directly under the guns of the dreaded gunboats.

abstract: Maj. COLLEY, United States Indian Agent, has addressed the following letter to Mr. BARNUM, of the Museum. That gentleman, hearing of the presence of the Indian Chiefs in Washington, whither they had gone on matters of business connected with the Government, wrote to Maj. COLLEY, inviting to this City these distinguished representatives of the aborigines, promising them valuable presents and courteous treatment during their stay. As will be seen by the following letter, Maj. COLLEY has acceded to the proposition, and the war party of the West will soon make their bows to the white men of the East.

abstract: The Aries, prize steamer, which arrived here yesterday en route to Boston, is the identical vessel that was convoyed out of a neutral port by a British man-of-war. She is a very useful steamer, of medium tonnage, and was built in England by JAMES LANG. She escaped with a cargo recently from Charleston, which port she reached through the aid of a rebel pilot sent over to Sutherland. She is a prize to the Stettin. The Aries had a ship's company of twenty-four men, besides four passengers -- Spaniards -- who professed to own the cargo, and a pilot, SIMPSON ADKINS, well known in New-York as formerly on the steamer Marion, in the New-York and Charleston trade. This ADKINS and the Spaniards are now prisoners on board the steamer Bibb.

abstract: -- The Secretary of the Treasury has just issued a circular regulating commercial intercourse with the insurrectionary States, intended to supersede the regulations which have been in force since August last. The bearings of these regulations upon our military and naval forces in all sections of the South and on its coast are set forth in orders from the Secretaries of War and the Navy. We publish the important circular of Secretary CHASE in full, for the information of all such as have or may have commercial or business relations with those sections of the South which have been opened up to trade and intercourse; and for the guidance of officers and soldiers of the army we also give the order of Secretary STANTON. The order of Secretary WELLES is analogous to the latter, except in the substitution of naval for military terms and designations, and therefore it is unnecessary to give it.
lead_paragraph: -- The Secretary of the Treasury has just issued a circular regulating commercial intercourse with the insurrectionary States, intended to supersede the regulations which have been in force since August last. abstract: We have no definite news regarding the demonstration against Charleston, said by the rebels to have commenced on Friday last. Dispatches were received in this City from Fortress Monroe yesterday, announcing the reception of Charleston papers no date given which acknowledge an attack by our land and naval forces, but contain nothing indicating the progress made.
lead_paragraph: We have no definite news regarding the demonstration against Charleston, said by the rebels to have commenced on Friday last. Dispatches were received in this City from Fortress Monroe yesterday, announcing the reception of Charleston papers -- no date given -- which acknowledge an attack by our land and naval forces, but contain nothing indicating the progress made. A dispatch from Charleston, however, dated the 2d, which we find in the Richmond Examiner of Saturday, states that there were no signs at the time of the expected attack, and that there had been no landing in force on any of the islands below -- the skirmish on Seabrook's Island having been with a party from a gunboat. The dispatch published in the TIMES yesterday, stated that a landing had been effected on Seabrook or John's Island; but the Examiner's dispatches throw doubt upon the report. Seabrook Island is at the mouth of North Edisto River, about twenty miles south of Charleston. John's Island adjoins it toward Charleston.

abstract: The steamship City of Cork, which left Liverpool on March 23, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The mails by the Canada, which arrived at Halifax on Friday, also reached this City yesterday morning. The news by the former, though two days later, is of not much importance. By the latter we receive our Paris and London correspondence, which will be found below.

abstract: -- The letter of our Port Royal correspondent will add likelihood to the statements and rumors that have reached us from the South, that the advance upon Charleston has at last commenced. On Monday night of last week, all the troops and transports at Port Royal were ready to start, and a greater part of the iron-clads, as also a brigade of troops, had already left for the rendezvous. The Richmond Dispatch, of the 3d, announced the arrival of these troops and Monitors on Seabrook's or John's Island, which is just above the mouth of North Edisto River, to the south of Charleston harbor.
lead_paragraph: -- The letter of our Port Royal correspondent will add likelihood to the statements and rumors that have reached us from the South, that the advance upon Charleston has at last commenced. abstract: In the Assembly, yesterday, the New-York Tax Levy was favorably reported, read a third time and passed. The bill for the prevention of desertion and enticing away and harboring seamen, was favorably reported. The Senate resolution to amend the Constitution so as to provide for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals, was adopted. The resolution relating to the President's Emancipation Proclamation was referred to the Committee on Federal Relations. Nothing of importance was done during the evening session.

abstract: The prize schooner Sue, of Nassau, N.P., arrived yesterday, Acting Master RICHARD HUSTACE, in charge. She reports that she was 15 miles to the southward and eastward of the Highland Lights on the evening of the 3d inst., when she was hailed by the pilot-boat No. 9 for a pilot, and one came alongside, but on learning that the vessel was a prize, refused to take her into port, saying he got no pay for piloting such vessels. Being unable to get a pilot, the Sue was driven in the late gale 90 miles to sea. On the afternoon of the 6th, managed to get a pilot from No. 1, when to the northward of Barnegat.

abstract: The practice of carrying on private negotiations with foreign Ministers, not on behalf of the country, but on behalf of a party, to which the leaders of the Copperhead faction have been resorting, is one which, taken in connection with the secession theory, which these worthies all hold, is so full of danger in the future, that we think it ought not to be passed over without some attempt to crush it. There is, we are aware, an act of Congress of WASHINGTON's time which makes it punishable as a misdemeanor, but we need hardly say that it would be next to impossible to get a conviction under it, owing to the difficulty of procuring evidence. When two or three "diffusers of political information," or "upholders of the Constitution," march to Lord LYONS' hotel, and hold consultations with him as to the best manner of bringing foreign influence to bear upon the internal affairs of the United States, we may be sure that outsiders or reporters are not likely to be present at the interview. None of the intriguers are at all likely to turn State's evidence, and an Ambassador cannot be produced in Court. So, as far as the law goes in its present condition, these people have their unfortunate country at their mercy.
lead_paragraph: The practice of carrying on private negotiations with foreign Ministers, not on behalf of the country, but on behalf of a party, to which the leaders of the Copperhead faction have been resorting, is one which, taken in connection with the secession theory, which these worthies all hold, is so full of danger in the future, that we think it ought not to be passed over without some attempt to crush it. There is, we are aware, an act of Congress of WASHINGTON's time which makes it punishable as a misdemeanor, but we need hardly say that it would be next to impossible to get a conviction under it, owing to the difficulty of procuring evidence. When two or three "diffusers of political information," or "upholders of the Constitution," march to Lord LYONS' hotel, and hold consultations with him as to the best manner of bringing foreign influence to bear upon the internal affairs of the United States, we may be sure that outsiders or reporters are not likely to be present at the interview. None of the intriguers are at all likely to turn State's evidence, and an Ambassador cannot be produced in Court. So, as far as the law goes in its present condition, these people have their unfortunate country at their mercy.

lead_paragraph: The meeting at the Academy of Music last night in aid of the suffering poor of Ireland, was an immense success, both in point of numbers and enthusiasm. At 7 1/2 o'clock the entire edifice was filled with beauty and fashion. On the stage were the officers of the Society known as the Knights of St. Patrick; Mayor OPDYKE, who presided over the meeting; His Grace Archbishop HUGHES; Rev. Messrs. O'REILLY, MOONEY, SCHNEIDER, Hon. Judge DALY, Hon. Recorder HOFFMAN, Brig.-Gen. MEAGHER, Very Rev. Dr. STARRS, Vicar-General; Rev. THOMAS QUINN of Rhode Island, Rev. Mr. MORAN of Newark, Mayor KALBFLEISCH of Brooklyn, and several other distinguished gentlemen, both of the lay and clerical orders.

abstract: The victory of the war party in Connecticut is a stunning blow to the Copperheads. It was the first election in which the animal gave fight in its own veritable shape. Here in New-York, and all through the West, the peace policy, as a distinct issue, was carefully avoided. The whole canvass was conducted under other semblances, ...
lead_paragraph: The victory of the war party in Connecticut is a stunning blow to the Copperheads. It was the first election in which the animal gave fight in its own veritable shape. Here in New-York, and all through the West, the peace policy, as a distinct issue, was carefully avoided. The whole canvass was conducted under other semblances, -- such as questions of sustaining the suspension of habeas corpus, of upholding the President's Proclamation, of approving the management of the war -- all of which were calculated to deceive and distract the people. Successes thus treacherously gained were really of no account as a test of the real spirit of the people touching the vital point of abandoning the war. But the peace-plotters insisted that it was the peace policy itself which the people had sustained, and grew so bold as to resolve to make that the plain out-and-out issue in the Spring elections. But in New-Hampshire and Rhode Island the leaders, after casting about a little, found it would hardly answer. So far as they well could, throughout the canvass, they kept the peace question in the background. They were beaten, but, not having fully shown themselves, pretended the blow was not really aimed at them. In Connecticut, on the other hand, they came squarely into public view at the very start, and fought unflinchingly to the end. There have been few, if any, political canvasses of late years in which the issues between the contending parties were more veraciously set forth. There can be no caviling about the result. It is literally a settler.
headline: {'main': 'The Connecticut Election Its Grand Significance.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Connecticut Election Its Grand Significance.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

On the 4th inst., lat. 71Â° 30â², lon, 37Â° 30â², encountered a cyclone, commencing from northeast, which blew with great violence for 48 hours, and during which the vessel labored badly; was compeliod to throw the battery, consisting of four long 34s, overboard, to save the vessel. abstract: DORTIC & CO., bankers, of No. 19 William-street, lost the sum of $10,000, through the dishonesty of their clerk, JOSEPH COX, Jr. The affair happened about the 17th of March last. The gold was intrusted to COX by the firm to convey to their bank, instead of which he took it to the nearest railroad station, and with it made his escape. A large reward was offered, and since that time the police have been constantly on the watch to secure the fugitive. Two or three days ago, COX was arrested in Albany, and the most of the gold recovered. Yesterday he was brought to this City, and taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, where he had a preliminary examination. In answer to the question what he had to say as to his guilt, he said: "I have nothing to say; they know that I did it, and there is no use in saying anything." He was therefore fully committed for trial.

abstract: We have no definite news yet from Charleston  nothing in fact, but hints. We have the announcement from Washington that it is officially known there that our gunboats and iron clads left Port Royal on Wednesday last, and would probably reach their destination on Thursday evening. Up to 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, however, nothing further was known of their movements.
lead_paragraph: We have no definite news yet from Charleston -- nothing in fact, but hints. We have the announcement from Washington that it is officially known there that our gunboats and iron clads left Port Royal on Wednesday last, and would probably reach their destination on Thursday evening. Up to 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, however, nothing further was known of their movements. A dispatch from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac leads to the inference that they have struck a blow somewhere. It is believed, from the actions of the rebels on the other sido of the Rappahannock, that they are in possession of information unfavorable to their cause -- unusual care being taken to prevent any of their papers from getting within our lines. The mystery will no doubt be cleared up in a day or two.

abstract: About 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a stable in One Hundred and Eighty-sixth-street, near the King's Bridge road, owned and occupied by JAMES KENNY. The building adjoining, owned by Messrs. DUKE & SNOWDEN, also caught fire, and was entirely consumed. The loss will amount to about $3,000. Mrs. WHITE and two children named MCDONALD, all occupants of the last-named house, were burned to death. The bodies were removed yesterday afternoon to the Station-house, where an inquest will be held by Coroner RANNEY. The origin of the fire is at present unknown.

abstract: The Harbor Defence Commission met at 3 o'clock P.M., yesterday, the President (Mayor OPDYKE,) in the Chair. A communication from Gen. MCCLELLAN was read, expressing his willingness to appear before the Commission and submit his views as to the best means of protecting the harbor. A communication was also received from Commodore E.A. STEVENS, submitting a plan for defending the harbor and proposing to sell his famous battery for about half its cost. The proposition was regarded as a very important one, and deserving of prompt attention; the communication was therefore referred to the Committee on Water Defences, with instructions to give Mr. STEVENS a hearing and report as soon as practicable upon the merits of both his suggestions and the offer of the sale of the battery. A communication from J. MORRISON HUNTER was read on the subject of sub-marine defence. Afterward, Mr. WILLIAM SEWELL submitted a communication and charts explaining a plan for blockading the harbor against the entrance of a hostile fleet. Plans were also submited by Messrs. EDWARD S. RENWICK and S.H. DUNKIN. The Commission adjourned to 3 o'clock P.M. on next Tuesday. The Committee on Water Defences will meet at 2 o'clock P.M., tomorrow, to consider Mr. STEVENS' communication.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of bills were reported favorably among them the one relative to the exemption of household furniture from seizure, which was ordered to a third reading; the one authorizing the Corporation of New-York to construct a pier in front of the Battery, and to lease the same; and the one dividing the Seventh Ward, Brooklyn. The bill to incorporate the Dry Goods Early Closing Association ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of bills were reported favorably -- among them the one relative to the exemption of household furniture from seizure, which was ordered to a third reading; the one authorizing the Corporation of New-York to construct a pier in front of the Battery, and to lease the same; and the one dividing the Seventh Ward, Brooklyn. The bill to incorporate the Dry Goods Early Closing Association was passed; also, the bill appropriating half a million dollars for the defence of New-York Harbor; also, the bill establishing a Bureau of Military Statistics. A resolution was introduced, and laid over, requesting the Governor to call the attention of the President to the excess of three-years' men furnished by New-York, and to ask him to take this into consideration in making the draft. The Gold Speculation and National Banking bills were then debated until the recess. The Gold bill was ordered to a third reading without amendment. During the evening session, the bill allowing the Brooklyn Central Railroad to use dummy engines was referred to the Brooklyn Senators to report complete.

abstract: The first performance of a new opera, under any circumstances, is an event of great musical importence, but when, in addition to the novelty of the work itself, we are called upon to assist at the introduction of a new composer, the occasion is doubly interesting. Although Italy is the Mother of the Arts, its must be confessed that in music she has not lately had many additions to here family.
lead_paragraph: The first performance of a new opera, under any circumstances, is an event of great musical importence, but when, in addition to the novelty of the work itself, we are called upon to assist at the introduction of a new composer, the occasion is doubly interesting. Although Italy is the Mother of the Arts, its must be confessed that in music she has not lately had many additions to here family. VERDI -- her favorite child -- has for fifteen years supplied the operatic stage with works of general interest, but even he has wearied of the labor, and now writes but seldom. Of MERCADANTE, PACINI, and other platitudinous old moderns, it is useless to speak. Their works, like certain kinds of Italian wine, are good enough on the spot where they are produced, but they are much too feeble to bear transportation, and hence are comparatively unknown.

abstract: The United States steam transport Eastern Queen, Capt. COLLINS, arrived at this port last evening, from New-Orleans March 29, and Key West on the 1st inst., with passengers, to United States Assistant Quartermaster. She brings about sixty discharged soldiers from Gen. BANKS' Division. Capt. COLLINS reports that while at Fort Phillip, Southwest Pass, his vessel was boarded by the United States boarding officer, who reported having received a telegram from New-Orleans, stating that the rebels had begun to evacuate Port Hudson.

abstract: If paint and feathers, wampum and war-hoops, tomahawks and terrible fighters are sufficient to form an attraction, New-York certainly has one now. The Indian chiefs who have been resident in Washington for the past few weeks, conferring with the President and arranging matters pertaining to the interests of their respective tribes, came on to New-York last night, and are to held a grand "pow-wow" with all who please to go and see them at the Museum-to-day. Hitherto, we have had exhibitions of a few poor red men, picked up at random and of no particular standiug or ethnological importance; but, in this case, the best men of the wildest Indian tribes extant come to New-York in all the savage grandeur of their untamed wildness. Chingachgook and Uncas were nothing in comparison. These men are the roamers of the remotest valleys of the Rocky Mountains and include the fierce Camanche and the formidable Arrapahoe. One of them is known as the "Yellow Buffalo," another as the "Lone Wolf,"a third as the "Lean Bear," and so on throughout a series of odd zoological appellations. BARNUM, it appears, has had to lay in for them an immense stock of raw beef, coffee, bread, red ochre, feathers and oil, they having never yet descended to the degradation of taking their dinner at a table d'hote, and using anything so absurd as a napkin. Apart from their interest as real unsophisticated Indians, are the facts which should invest them with extrinsic interest to an equal amount, that they come to New-York to see what sort of a thing civilization is, and to cultivate friendship with our citizens. By all means let them be treated courteously and kindly, so that when they leave for the Far West they may give a good account of New-York hospitality and good taste. They will doubtless attract throngs to the Museum.

abstract: The large hall of the Cooper Institute was densely packed by an audience last evening, who assembled, according to the printed call, to express their opposition to the Conscript Act, the war for the negro, and to the Administration, and to exhibit their favor of the reunion of the States, of the Constitution, and of the rights of the poor. The meeting was highly enthusiastic, and the sentiments, as uttered by the speakers, seemed to be fully and unreservedly indorsed. Amidst the vast concourse, one -- and only one -- of the gentler sex was observed. Upon the platform were seated several persons who formerly held responsible positions under the State and Municipal Governments, also numerous other individuals of much less note. A band of music was in attendance, which interspersed the proceedings from time to time with patriotic and popular airs.

abstract: We have no doubt that Charleston, its harbor, and its approaches, are very formidably defended. The city has been threatened for two years. During all that time the inhabitants and the military authorities have been able to look down the harbor, and behold hostile cannon mounted on first-class ships, whose commanders would have eagerly seized any chance to run in and salute the town.
lead_paragraph: We have no doubt that Charleston, its harbor, and its approaches, are very formidably defended. The city has been threatened for two years. During all that time the inhabitants and the military authorities have been able to look down the harbor, and behold hostile cannon mounted on first-class ships, whose commanders would have eagerly seized any chance to run in and salute the town. For eighteen months a large army has been encamped within a short sail of the port, with the avowed design of attacking the city as soon as possible. The Northern public have ceaselessly urged the attack on Charleston, and there has been greater anxiety to see the flag raised there than in any other part of rebeldom.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "Ione," last evening, attracted a magnificent audience, and elicited an amount of approbation that justifies the use of the word furore. After the second act, the artists were called out twice; after the third act, they were called out twice again, and Mr. MARETZEK being demanded, had also to make his appearance. The opera, in fact, is a tremendous success, and deservedly so, for it is one of the best that the modern muse of Italy has given to the stage. The performance last evening was excellent in all respects.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "Ione," last evening, attracted a magnificent audience, and elicited an amount of approbation that justifies the use of the word furore. The opera, in fact, is a tremendous success, and deservedly so, for it is one of the best that the modern muse of Italy has given to the stage. The performance last evening was excellent in all respects.

Recently, some New-York capitalists have bought the location, organized a company for working it, under the title of the Erie Lead Mining Company, and are now delivering large amounts of lead with as much regularity as the best-developed mines of Europe. abstract: President of the State Educational Society, and member of the State Assembly from Tompkins County, has presented the town of Ithaca with $50,000, for the erection of a building and the establishment of a Public Library. He intends to devote the coming Summer to the execution of this munificent and public spirited donation, and will not be able, therefore, to accept the State appointment as Commissioner to the Agricultural Fair at Hamburg. This splendid gift is a noble and characteristic illustration of the intelligent and well-directed liberality which distinguishes Mr. CORNELL's public and private career.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among the bills reported favorably was one fixing the salary of the New-York Supervisors. The Brooklyn Public Market bill was reported adversely, and the report was agreed to. Majority and minority reports from the Special Committee on the Broadway Railroad bill, relative to the business, residences, etc., of the contractors named in the bill, were made, but their consideration was cut off by the special order -- the Annual Appropriation bill. Subsequently, favorable reports were made on the bills incorporating the Soldiers' Home and the Soldiers' Rest. The Broadway Railroad bill was reported complete. A motion was made to strike out the names of unknown corporators, and to insert instead the names of stage proprietors. This was lost, after a long debate. An amendment giving the franchise to the lowest bidder was also lost. The bill was finally ordered to a third reading. During the proceedings, Mr. LOW offered concurrent resolutions, which were laid over, pledging New-York to the suppression of the rebellion.

abstract: the Relief Society of Jersey City opened a fair yesterday at the City Hall, which is to continue open to-day and to-morrow, for the benefit of the sick and wounded New-Jersey soldiers. The object is one that must commend itself most warmly to every citizen of that State, and the management of the fair is in such hands as to command for it universal confidence. A fine band of music is in attendance, and the doors are open at 3 o'clook.

abstract: received a letter from LUTHER THOMAS, Surgeon of the Twenty-sixth regiment New-Jersey Volunteers, accompanied by certificates from the officers of the regiment, denying in very explicit and offensive terms the truth of a statement made by our Washington correspondent, that he had been court-martialed and cashiered. We published the substance of the letter. We have before us General Orders, No. 54, setting forth that Surgeon THOMAS was tried by a Court-martial, of which Gen. JOHN COCHRANE was President, Jan. 12, 1863, on two charges, -- 1, of being "drunk on duty," -- and 2, of "conduct to the prejudice of good order and military discipline." The specifications to the latter charge were four in number. He was found guilty on both charges, and was sentenced "to be cashiered"; -- but the President remitted the sentence and he was restored to duty. If Surgeon THOMAS in his letter to us had been content with stating the truth, he would have saved us the necessity of thus referring to the matter again.

abstract: An important discovery was made, yesterday, by the Police of the Eighteenth Precinct. About $3,000 of counterfeit money, consisting of bills and coin, was found secreted in a bale of hay in the feed-store of WM. HAUGHEY, NO. 125 East Twenty-first-street, near Third-avenue. Officer SUTTON, with three others, made a thorough search of the premise, and in addition to spurious money, they found a very finely engraved plate, intended for the alteration of bank notes; also, a crucible containing some spelter, a quantity of acids, such as are used in obliterating figures and letters, and several bottles of bank-note printing ink. The officers found no one in charge of the feed-store except THOMASS HAUGHEY, a son of the proprtetor. He protessed entire ignorance upon the subject of the counterfeits, but it was thought best to secure him, and then await the arrival of the rather, whom the son said would be in shortly. The elder HAUGHEY soon made his appearance upon a load of hay, which he had been out to procure. Upon seeing the officers on the sidewalk, he suddenly stopped his wagon and jumped off the opposite side. As soon as he struck the ground he was seen to draw a well-filled wallet from his pocket, and attempt to thrust it into a bale of hay. The officers were too quick for him, however, and they at once took both him and the wallet into their custody. An examination of the latter was made, and about $60 in bi[???]ls were found; one-half of which, at least, were counterfeit. He was taken to the Station-house and confined to await an examination. He denied all knowledge of the spurious money found on his premises. He is, however, well-known to the Police, who allege that he has recently come from Sing Sing, whither he was sent for two years for counterfeiting. His place has had a bad reputation, and the officers have been trying to get sufficient evidence to detect him for several weeks past. The counterfeit bills which were seized were upon twelve or fourteen different banks. There were over $200 in fives on the Bank of America, this City, and nearly $1,000 in tons on the Atlantic Bank of Boston.

abstract: TION. -- Our Legislature is discussing the question whether this State shall aid the General Government in carrying out the financial policy which it has adopted, or whether it shall do all in its power to thwart it. A bill is pending in the Senate consenting to the establishment, within this State, of the banks authorized by the recent act of Congress. The precise issue thus raised is stated by "Sentinel," the Albany correspondent of the World, to be simply this -- "Shall the law of the United States take precedence of the Constitution of the State of New-York?" We are a little surprised that so old and experienced a political writer should have dreamed for a moment that there could be any doubt on this point, or any occasion to discuss it. The sixth article of the Constitution of the United States declares, in very explicit terms, that "this Constitution, and the laws of the United States made in pursuance thereof, shall be the supreme law of the land, and the Judges in every State shall be bound thereby, anything in the Constitution or laws of any State to ths contrary notwithstanding." Even assuming then, that this law of the United States is contrary to the Constitution of the States, which we do not for a moment concede, it is the "supreme law of the land" notwithstanding, provided only it be in conformity with the Constitution of the United State; and upon that point no question has yet been raised. Our Legislature, we take it for granted, will not be embarrassed in regard to its duty by any such cavils as those referred to. New-York is devoted, in all her affections and all her interests, by all her memories and all her hopes, to the preservation of the Union, and she will sustain the National Government in all its efforts to accomplish that result.

abstract: Charleston is situated on a low, level point of land, at the junction of Cooper and Ashley Rivers. No portion of the city is more than twenty feet above the tide, so that upon approaching it from the harbor its buildings and the beautiful spires of its churches seem to rise directly from the water. The Cooper River joins the Ashley at a right angle from the North, and the continuation of the latter river, running nearly due east, forms the lower hadbor and bay of Charleston, which widens gradually from 2 to 5 miles to its mouth, distant about 10 miles from the city. On the opposite side of the Cooper River, where it debouches into the harbor, a short mile from the City, is Castle Pinkney, a small work, but mounting some heavy guns. Nearly opposite, on the southern side of the harbor, on James' Island, about two miles distant, is Fort Johnson. About four miles from the city, midway between Sullivan's and James' Islands, is Fort Sumter, and directly northward of it, on Sullivan's Island, at a distance of two thousand Yards, is Fort Moultrie. Between these two forts is the only channel for vessels to approach the city. Fort Sumter has three tiers of guns, and under the old Government, ranked as a fortification of the second class, in the extent of the works and the strength of its armament, but it was constructed in a very superior manner, and was supposed to be invulnerable at the time to the effects of any naval ordnance then in use. Its reduction by South Carolina, in 1861, was effected by hot shot from Fort Moultrie setting fire to the wooden roofs of the capacious buildings allotted for officers' quarters, by which ANDERSON and his garrison were literally roasted out. Care has been taken, in the reconstruction of the buildings, to avoid all chance for a repetition of such a barbecue. Fort Moultrie is a work of inferior rank, but it is admirably situated for dealing offensive blows upon an approaching enemy.

abstract: World reads FERNANDO WOOD and his Copperhead clique out of the Democratic party. It charges that ambitious political chieftain with attempting to make a platform to suit himself, without any regard to the principles, the sentiments or the welfare of the party at large. "What is more unwise," asks the World, "than to ask the Democratic party to step off its own platform upon a plank one end of which is under water in Connecticut to-day?" This is a pertinent question; but which "end" is it that went under in Connecticut? It seemed to us just before the election that the World stood on that plank pretty squarely. If it managed to get off before the polls were closed, it displayed a remarkable degree of political agility. Its rebukes of FERNANDO, at all events, are edifying, not only as eminently just in themselves, but as indicating a wholesome appreciation of the lessons taught by the recent elections in the New-England States. The Democrats are slowly, but surely, learning that any party which resists the prosecution of the war against the rebellion, is simply digging its own grave. They won't object to FERNANDO's doing it -- but they have evidently no intention to make their own bed there with him.

abstract: Henry B. Herts, Jr., vs. Henry Wood. -- This was an application for an injunction and receiver made by the plaintiff in an action for a dissolution of the firm of Henry Wood & Co., auctioneers, at No. 450 Broadway. It was shown by the articles of copartnership, and by the papers used upon the motion, that soon alter the election of James Lynch, the present Sheriff of this City, he selected the defendant, a brother of Fernando Wood, as his auctioneer; and that, in the month of December, 1861, the parties to the action formed a copartnership by an agreement in uniting for the period of three years, from the 1st day of January, 1862, that being the official term of the Sheriff elect. The plaintiff, as appeared, was a practical and professional auctioneer, and the defendant was not. The plaintiff, as alleged, for a half interest in the business to accrue from Sheriffs sales, paid the defendant the sum of $8,000, and covenanted that the defendant's share of the profits should not be less than $5,000 per year during he three years. The firm of Henry Wood & Co. continued business, as auctioneers to the Sheriff, until about the 1st day or March, 1863, when the Sheriff withheld his patronage and selected other auctioneers. The plaintiff, finding that the business for which he had bargained had been taken from him, desired a return of his money which the defendant had received, alleging that the defendant had been selected to act as auctioneer for one year only. The defendant denied this and claimed that he had been selected by the Sheriff for the full term, and that so far he had acted in good faith toward his partner, and offered to refer it to arbitrators to adjust their differences. The plaintiff declined to enter into an arrangement to arbitrate, but brought this action. It was shown that the practice of the Sheriff had been to take goods seized upon execution to the auction-room, and that they are sold by the auctioneer, who deducted his commissions and other charges from the proceeds, turning the residue over to the Sheriff, who then deducted his fees, as fixed by law, applying the balance upon the execution. That the plaintiff in this actton had the management of the Sheriff's sales, and had usually charged five per cent. as commissions, besides other items for storage and labor, amounting in all to about ten per cent. of the sales, and that the auctioneer's commissions of five per cent. were usually divided between the auctioneers and some of the deputies of the Sheriff -- a brother of the Sheriff, as alleged, being one of the deputies exacting such bonus.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer, of the 30th ult., devotes a good deal of its attention to the then approaching Connecticut election. It noticed the "sympathizing" resolutions adopted by the Democratic Convention, -- its declaration that "the lovers of the Constitution must abandon the monstrous fallacy that the Union can be restored by the armed hand alone," -- and to Mr. SEYMOUR's opinion that "it is not by force of arms that we are to have another Union, but by force of reason;" and it comments upon these demonstrations of its Northern allies in the following edifying and complimentary style:

abstract: Some additional advices form Mexico reach us by way of Havana, though nothing later than we have already had. The French forces under Gen. FOREY were still, on the 7 th of March, occupying the line twelve short leagues from Puebla, and seven from the outer posts. The Mexican vanguard was at Amozoo. The guerrillas were still very troublesome to the French.
lead_paragraph: Some additional advices form Mexico reach us by way of Havana, though nothing later than we have already had. The French forces under Gen. FOREY were still, on the 7 th of March, occupying the line twelve short leagues from Puebla, and seven from the outer posts. The Mexican vanguard was at Amozoo. The guerrillas were still very troublesome to the French.

abstract: The results of the Congressional elections in Connecticut and Rhode Island settle the fact that the supporters of the Administration will have a clear working majority in the next House of Representatives. It is probable that there will be a gain of several Administration members in Maryland and Kentucky, the only two loyal States yet to choose; but even if this prove otherwise, it will not change the preponderance. It is fixed that the great war measures of the Government, so boldly conceived and elaborately matured, will be sustained and seconded by the Representatives of the people.

abstract: We are still without news from Charleston. Up to yesterday afternoon the Government had received no definite intelligence reearding operations there. Private letters have been received from officers attached to the naval force, dated as late as the 1st inst., which speak of the attack as to take place at once, and expressing confidence in a good result. All the women and children were said to have left the city in anticipation of the attack.

abstract: An immense trade is carried on over the Rio Grande, and our informant (says the Era) knew of a train of 600 carts loaded with cotton, which was on its way to Brownsville. These loads will average about six bales each, and probably covey not less than 3,500 bales of cotton. This will be exchanged for warlike stores, blankets, ammunition, etc., which will be carried back by the same train.

lead_paragraph: The non-extension of the Eighth-avenue Railway in accordance with the terms of the charter, exercises the good people of the upper part of the City, and a series of condemnatory meetings is being held for the purpose of compelling municipal interference in behalf of the protestants against the non-action of the company and its contractors. On Tuesday night a large meeting was held at BRIGHT's Hotel, with Mr. THOS. MANSON in the Chair. The Committee on Grading reported that the contractors for the road above Eighty-second-street had promised to complete the grading during the ensuing sixty days.

abstract: another series of reports from the Committee on the Conduct of the War. They relate to the affairs at Bull Run and Ball's Bluff, and to the Missouri campaign of Gen. FREMONT. In regard to Bull Run, no facts are given that had not previously been before the public, and the same may be said concerning the brief report of FREMONT's operations in Missouri. The history of Bull Run, however, is very concisely given, and the chief responsibility for the disaster fixed, where unanimous testimony has all along placed it -- on the shoulders of Gen. PATTERSON. Gen. FREMONT is exonerated from blame in nearly all the details of his Missouri administration -- on some points no opinion is expressed; but two members of the Committee (Messrs. GOOCH and ODELL) decline to concur in this report, and prefer to submit the testimony without comment. Much light is thrown on the mysterious disaster at Ball's Bluff, and this will be the part of the report read with most interest. It is clear enough that the affair was simply the result of imperfect preparation and bad management; and for this Gen. STONE cannot be exonerated. The Committee, however, show that they were not responsible for the incarceration of this officer in Fort Lafayette on charges of treason, nor for his subsequent treatment.

abstract: APRIL 9. The case of Wm. McCormick, on trial for the murder of Policeman Williams, in Charles-street, on the 13th of October last, was concluded. McCormick was tried on the same indictment during the March term, when the jury failing to agree, after having been out all night, were discharged; a report of the trial was published at the...
lead_paragraph: APRIL 9. -- The case of Wm. McCormick, on trial for the murder of Policeman Williams, in Charles-street, on the 13th of October last, was concluded. McCormick was tried on the same indictment during the March term, when the jury failing to agree, after having been out all night, were discharged; a report of the trial was published at the time, and there was nothing material that was new elicited on the second trial. It appeared by the evidence that, on the occasion of the killing, McCormick was in Charles-street, and was intoxicated. The report of a pistol was heard by a witness, who was in a house near by, and who immediately ran out to ascertain the cause. He then saw the defendant lying upon the pavement with the policeman over him. All the policeman said was, "I am shot; he has got a pistol." The policeman was then conveyed to his house, which was near by, where he died in about five minutes, and without saying anything additional in relation to the occurrence. The defendant stated that the policeman came up to him, while on the street, and knocked him down. The jury, after having been out a short time, rendered a verdict of manslaughter in the third degree, and the Court adjourned.

abstract: Nothing definite is yet known regarding events at Charleston. The Government is said to be in possession of Richmond papers of Wednesday, but their contents have not been made known. lead_paragraph: Nothing definite is yet known regarding events at Charleston. The Government is said to be in possession of Richmond papers of Wednesday, but their contents have not been made known. Rebel papers of Tuesday have been received by way of Fortress Monroe, but they contain not a word in relation to Chareleston, and it is probable that those of Wednesday are equally reticent. We have advices from Port Royal as late as the 4th inst., and from the fleet off Charleston to the 5th. Nearly all the troops intended to cooperate with the naval forces, had left Port Royal for North Edisto Inlet, eighteen miles from the city, where it was understood they would remain a few days, awaiting the action of Admiral DUPONT -- it being the intention to defer the land attack until the success of the naval demonstration should be in a measure assured.

abstract: home from the army. Gangs of pickpockets travel regularly on the railroad trains between Washington and this City, and plunder returning soldiers of their pay. Certainly there should be a stop put to this. Nothing can be easier. Let the Railroad Companies appropriate special cars to soldiers, and allow nobody else to enter them, and there would be no opportunity for these thieves to practice their vocation. This ought to be attended to without delay.

abstract: The United States steamer Sumter, J.F. WINCHESTER, Acting Master Commanding, hence on the 23d ult. for Port Royal, S.C., has returned in distress. She left this port on the 23d ult. for Port Royal, S.C., but sustaining some damage to the machinery, put into Hampton Roads for repairs. She sailed thence on the 1st inst., designing to proceed on the voyage with the submarine battery Alligator in tow, and from the 2d to the 6th inst. experienced a succession of gales and tornadoes which were almost unparalleled in severity. Acting Ensign R. BENTSON, and FRED'K. WAY, ordinary seaman, were washed overboard, and her hatches, boats, bulwarks, and the submarine battery Alligator, were lost. The Sumter also sprung aleak and sustained considerable damage to her machinery. For three days her officers and crew had only hard biscuit to eat; but they undauntedly toiled on, and by their skill and unremitting labor saved the vessel. On the 6th inst., spoke schooner Manhassett, from Port Royal for New-York, with main boom, boat and davits gone. On the 7th inst., spoke brig Abbie Watson, from Sagua for Boston, with main boom and gaff gone.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Sumter, J.F. WINCHESTER, Acting Master Commanding, hence on the 23d ult. for Port Royal, S.C., has returned in distress. abstract: Every reader will turn with profound interest to the brief details we are enabled to give of the fight going on in Charleston harbor. Such facts as we have are obtained from rebel sources, and are to be taken with grains of allowance.
lead_paragraph: Every reader will turn with profound interest to the brief details we are enabled to give of the fight going on in Charleston harbor. Such facts as we have are obtained from rebel sources, and are to be taken with grains of allowance. But there is nothing even in what the rebels tell us that is calculated to create any uneasiness as to the hoped-for result. There is, on the contrary, encouragement in this, that the rebel authorities admit our powerful iron-clad fleet to be inside of Charleston bar, in easy range of Fort Sumter, and consequently that it has escaped the attacks of batteries lower down the harbor, placed there to embarrass the approach, and has also escaped, for the present, the torpedoes and submarine enemies that were expected to be so disastrous.

abstract: DREADFUL ACCIDENT IN A CISTERN -- TWO MEN SUFFOCATED AND TWO OTHERS NEARLY KILLED. -- A terrible accident occurred at the rear of No. 96 Oarll-street, Brooklyn, about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, involving the almost instant death of two men and the serious and perhaps fatal injury of two others. It appears that a laborer named JOHN MCGINNESS was employed to clean out a cesspool on the above premises, and in descending, in order to examine the condition of affairs, was struck senseless by the foul air, and fell to the bottom. The fact was soon made known to the neighbors, and several came to aid the man. JOHN DONNELL, who was the first on the spot, went down for the perpose of rescuing MCGINNESS, but he had descended only a few feet when he, too, was rendered senseless by the foul vapor, and sunk into the filthy mass beneath. Mr. JOHN HEAREY, engaged in cleaning the street at the time, next came to the aid of the unfortunate men, and he too, met with a similar fate. Mr. SAMUEL SLOCUM, anxious to aid his fellow-men, likewise descended, and, like the rest, sunk to the bottom. A neighbor, named KENNY, having the sad fate of the others for his guidance, procured a rope, and with the aid of a number who by this time crowded the yard, succeeded in bringing up Messrs. HEAREY and SLOCUM. The latter soon revived, and was taken to his home near by; but HEAREY, who appeared to be in a dying condition, was conveyed to the City Hospital. The dead bodies of MCGINNESS and DONNELL were subsequently hauled out. The family of the latter, consisting of wife and four children, reside at No. 94 Carroll-street, and that of the former at No. 192 Hudson-avenue. The cistern, it appears, was not only in a very filthy condition, but to add to the nastiness, the wall of an adjoining privy had broken through, making matters much worse. An inquest was held upon the bodies of deceased by Coroner HEGEMAN, and a verdict was rendered that they came to their death by suffocation.
lead_paragraph: DREADFUL ACCIDENT IN A CISTERN -- TWO MEN SUFFOCATED AND TWO OTHERS NEARLY KILLED. -- A terrible accident occurred at the rear of No. 96 Oarll-street, Brooklyn, about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, involving the almost instant death of two men and the serious and perhaps fatal injury of two others. It appears that a laborer named JOHN MCGINNESS was employed to clean out a cesspool on the above premises, and in descending, in order to examine the condition of affairs, was struck senseless by the foul air, and fell to the bottom. The fact was soon made known to the neighbors, and several came to aid the man. JOHN DONNELL, who was the first on the spot, went down for the perpose of rescuing MCGINNESS, but he had descended only a few feet when he, too, was rendered senseless by the foul vapor, and sunk into the filthy mass beneath. Mr. JOHN HEAREY, engaged in cleaning the street at the time, next came to the aid of the unfortunate men, and he too, met with a similar fate. Mr. SAMUEL SLOCUM, anxious to aid his fellow-men, likewise descended, and, like the rest, sunk to the bottom. A neighbor, named KENNY, having the sad fate of the others for his guidance, procured a rope, and with the aid of a number who by this time crowded the yard, succeeded in bringing up Messrs. HEAREY and SLOCUM. The latter soon revived, and was taken to his home near by; but HEAREY, who appeared to be in a dying condition, was conveyed to the City Hospital. The dead bodies of MCGINNESS and DONNELL were subsequently hauled out. The family of the latter, consisting of wife and four children, reside at No. 94 Carroll-street, and that of the former at No. 192 Hudson-avenue. The cistern, it appears, was not only in a very filthy condition, but to add to the nastiness, the wall of an adjoining privy had broken through, making matters much worse. An inquest was held upon the bodies of deceased by Coroner HEGEMAN, and a verdict was rendered that they came to their death by suffocation.

abstract: -- We stated yesterday morning that we now controlled the whole length of the Mississippi River, so far as its navigation by the rebels was concerned. An evening journal objects to this, so far as relates to the space of 200 miles between Vicksburgh and Port Hudson. It says that we have only three vessels there, and that these can do very little to prevent the rebels from crossing with bodies of soldiers, supplies of cattle, mails, etc. We do not think, as we expressly stated, that our fleet will be able to cut off entirely the mail communication between the east and west banks of the river; but still we control it pretty effectually so far as all other intercourse is concerned. The rebels would need steamers and transports to bring across bodies of troops and supplies of cattle, and they have none at liberty in that part of the Mississippi referred to. Beside, the only navigable stream entering the Mississippi between Port Hudson and Vicksburgh, by which supplies could be brought down from Texas, is Red River, and we have news this morning that FARRAGUT's fleet of two vessels and ELLET's ram have again swept down to that region, and have doubtless cleared the river of any craft that may have tried to creep out from any hiding-place, as the fleet cleared it a few weeks ago, on going up. It is impossible for the rebels to navigate a single league of the great Mississippi.
