abstract: Coroner WILDKY held an inquest yesterday, at No. 29 Bowery, upon the body of CHARLES F. NOLL, a soldier of the Eighth New-York Volunteers, who came to his death by means of poison administered by himself, with intent to commit suicide. He also tried to murder a young woman, named MARY STRUBE, to whom he was engaged to be married, by administering to her poison without her knowledge. Failing in this, he tried to end her existence by strangulation, but did not succeed.
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDKY held an inquest yesterday, at No. 29 Bowery, upon the body of CHARLES F. Failing in this, he tried to end her existence by strangulation, but did not succeed.

abstract: The only news we have from Charleston, this morning, is rebel news, and it must consequently be received with all due allowance. The Richmond Whig of Thursday contains a telegram from Charleston, dated the 7th, which states that ...
lead_paragraph: The only news we have from Charleston, this morning, is rebel news, and it must consequently be received with all due allowance. The Richmond Whig of Thursday contains a telegram from Charleston, dated the 7th, which states that the naval attack commenced on that day, four iron-clads being first engaged, and the attack being directed against Fort Sumter. The firing from the fleet, and from Forts Sumter and Moultrie, and from the Morris Island batteries, is represented to have been very heavy. At 2 o'clock in the afternoon all the Monitors, nine in number, and the Ironsides, were engaged, at a distance of three thousand yards from Sumter. The firing was kept up incessantly until 5 o'clock, when it gradually diminished -- the Ironsides and Keokuk having withdrawn an hour previously, apparently disabled. Another dispatch, dated the 8th, states that seven Monitors and the Ironsides were then inside the bar, though the conflict had not been renewed. The Keokuk was said to be sunk on the bench off Morris Island. One boy killed and five men badly wounded, are said to be the casualties in Fort Sumter.

abstract: The fact that a Confederate loan, to the amount of fifteen millions of dollars, has just been subscribed in Europe; that largely more offerings were made than would cover the amount asked for; and that the loan was taken at a premium, entitles the matter to graver attention than it has received in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The fact that a Confederate loan, to the amount of fifteen millions of dollars, has just been subscribed in Europe; that largely more offerings were made than would cover the amount asked for; and that the loan was taken at a premium, entitles the matter to graver attention than it has received in the United States. The Confederate loan is secured by the hypothecation of cotton. And the London Times, in chronicling the progress and success of the loan, which had no official authorization by foreign Governments, spoke of it as exclusively a "cotton speculation."

abstract: The country has at last, after a great deal of trouble and difficulty, got at the precise nature of the objects which the Copperhead party has in view; and we trust that, as everybody now understands everybody else, we can give  our undivided attention to the work of the war. Before the New-York election, as well as we could make out, they wanted peace, somehow or anyhow.
lead_paragraph: The country has at last, after a great deal of trouble and difficulty, got at the precise nature of the objects which the Copperhead party has in view; and we trust that, as everybody now understands everybody else, we can give our undivided attention to the work of the war. Before the New-York election, as well as we could make out, they wanted peace, somehow or anyhow. As the canvass progressed, and they begun, after feeling the public pulse, to want war a little -- but only a little -- and it was to be a genteel and "fraternal" war, carried on a la MCCLELLAN -- we were not to forget that the Southerners were still our brethren, and though a painful necessity might compel us to fight them, we were to kill and wound them in the way which brothers who have differences usually kill and wound one another -- whatever that may be. We were to fire low, so as only to hit their legs, and were not even to attempt that without previously firing in the air, or with blank cartridge, so as to see whether they would not disperse and take the oath of allegiance before beginning an action. And even this species of modified conflict was not to be carried on beyond the capture of Richmond. Our army was to go down there, and having carefully taken the rebel forces prisoners, and tied their hands behind their backs with pocket-handkerchiefs, we were to read the Declaration of Independence from the steps of the State-house, and then acknowledge the independence of the Southern Confederacy and come home.

abstract: The third performance of "Ione" last evening was not only superb in itself, but so far above the average of operatic performances in America, that we are disposed to regard it as one of the finest ever listened to in the Academy. To say that it created a furore, is to convey but a slight idea of the real pleasure that was manifested by the audience, which we may here add, crowded every part of the building. It is now that this work is beginning to be recognized as one of the best of the modern Italian repertoire, and it is now, certainly, that it is heard to best advantage. Artists, orchestra and chorus were alike excellent, and in the splendid finale of the third act, vied with each other to produce a result that was really astonishing. The principals were called out three times after this piece.

abstract: A grand mass meeting is to be held this afternoon on Union-square, to reaffirm the determination of loyal men everywhere to prosecute the war until the rebellion is extinguished. The day is the anniversary of the attack upon Fort Sumter -- the event which first aroused the country to the conviction that the rebellion was a reality, and not merely an empty threat. Distinguished speakers will be present, and arrangements have been made which will render the gathering one of the largest and most influential of the day.
lead_paragraph: A grand mass meeting is to be held this afternoon on Union-square, to reaffirm the determination of loyal men everywhere to prosecute the war until the rebellion is extinguished. Distinguished speakers will be present, and arrangements have been made which will render the gathering one of the largest and most influential of the day.

abstract: In the House of Lords, Monday, March 23, Lord STRATHEDEN called attention to the question of acknowledging the Southern Confederacy as an independent Power, in connection with other neutral States. Recognition, he contended, would take away the last hope of the North of subjugating the...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, Monday, March 23, Lord STRATHEDEN called attention to the question of acknowledging the Southern Confederacy as an independent Power, in connection with other neutral States. Recognition, he contended, would take away the last hope of the North of subjugating the South, and would materially influence the Federal Government in coming to an arrangement with their opponents, if those opponents were once looked on as an independent power by foreign nations. He quoted several precedents for this view, and said that the opinions of this country and of France and Holland had been sufficiently manifested by the recent loan raised for the Confederates, while military men had also expressed their conviction that the conquest of the South was impossible. He concluded by observing that if recognition was withheld, the war would never be brought to an end.

abstract: Extensive preparations are made for a successful demonstration at the second anniversary of the attack on Sumter, to-day. Six stands will be erected and eminent speakers are provided for each. The Committee, at 11 o'clock last night, were unable to give our reporter any definite information as to who would speak at any particular stand, but we learn that Maj.-Gen. FREMONT, Gen. SIGEL, Gen. COCHRAN, Gen. BUSTEED, Hon. MONTGOMERY BLAIR and Hon. A.J. HAMILTON, besides many of our most esteemed local orators, will be of the number.

abstract: -- The performances at this establishment to-night are for the benefit of Mr. THOMAS BAKER, the popular and able conductor of the orchestra, and a musician who succeeds more than any other in providing the precise kind of orchestral extracts that the public requires and relishes. It is, we believe, the first time Mr. BAKER has appealed to the public, and this circumstance, added to what we have already stated, c[???]ght, we think, to insure a full attendance. Moreover, on this occasion Miss ROSE EYTINGE, whose success on Wednesday last in Miss KEENE's role of Nellie O'Donohus was so marked, will make her last appearance in that character. The lady, so far, has been seen under circumstances that were, from their suddenness -- if from no other came -- unfavorable to the ease of the artist. Placed suddenly in a character that had been impersonated by Miss KEENE, and which even that remarkable artist could not make powerful, it is certainly high praise to say that Miss EYTINGE infused into it a quiet, graceful and earnest interest that gave abundant evidence of her delicate and unusual powers. The lady's freedom from affectation of speech and exaggeration of action, without detracting from the force that is required, are so marked that we are sure in a higher range of play, where jigs and brogues are alike unknown, she will win and merit a career before a metropolitan audience. It is a fortunate thing that her debut, although hurried, was made under the auspices of Miss LAURA KEENE, who will, as an artist of the undemonstrative school herself, appreciate Miss EYTINGE's ability, and give to her, we hope, the proper opportunities for displaying it.

abstract: William Carey vs. Eighty-seven Tons of Coal. -- This was a libel to recover freight for carrying a cargo of coal on the barge Ocean Favorite from Port Carbon, Penn., to this port. The claimant was the assignee of the bill of lading, which was executed by the libelant as master of the barge. The libelant performed the voyage and delivered a part of the cargo to the claimant and offered to deliver the rest on payment of the freight or security for its payment. The claimant refused this and alleged in his answer that the barge was the property of John Carey, the libelant's father, and was navigated for his benefit, and that the claimant had a claim for damages against John Carey for breach of a previous contract, which damages he called upon the Court to set off against the libelant's claim.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Glasgow and Africa, we have advices from Europe to the 29th ult., four days later than by the Bavaria. The news is important. A debate had taken place in the British House of Commons on the 27th regarding the fitting out of the Alabama, during which Lord PALMERSTON declared that the British Government had done, and would do all in its power to enforce the law; but it could only act on sworn depositions, and not on rumors and suspicions; and he believed that, if they had seized the Alabama, no cause would have been substantiated against her, as she had no armament, whatever might have been the suspicion of her destination. Mr. LAIRD, the builder of the Alabama, maintained that the whole transaction with respect to that vessel was most open and legitimate. Other members, however, took a different view of the matter. Considerable excitement had been occasioned in England by the publication of the circumstances attending the seizure of the Peterhoff, by Admiral WILKES, and Consols fluctuated considerably in consequence, but at last accounts the excitement had subsided, and no fears were entertained that anything unpleasant would occur. No further disturbances had occurred at Stayleybridge, but matters still looked threatening. With regard to the riots there, Sir G. GREY, in the House of Commons on the 27th, stated that he had no doubt the civil and military authorities would have no difficulty in suppressing any attempt to renew the disturbances. He stated that steps were being taken to adapt the machinery of the mills to Indian and other descriptions of cotton. The latest accounts from Poland are confused. A Vienna telegram says that LANGIEWICZ had been set at liberty on parole. He and his followers proceeded to Brunn-Moravia. The violation of the Galician frontier by the Russians will be considered "as a violation of international law." LANGIEWICZ was expected in Paris. The Liverpool cotton market was firm and unchanged. Breadstuffs and provisions were dull. Consols, 92 1/2@5/8 for money. The rebel loan was fluctuating.

Mr. LAIRD, the builder of the Alabama, maintained that the whole transaction with respect to that vessel was most open and legitimate. Other members, however, took a different view of the matter. Considerable excitement had been occasioned in England by the publication of the circumstances attending the seizure of the Peterhoff, by Admiral WILKES, and Consols fluctuated considerably in consequence, but at last accounts the excitement had subsided, and no fears were entertained that anything unpleasant would occur. No further disturbances had occurred at Stayleybridge, but matters still looked threatening. With regard to the riots there, Sir G. abstract: No event in the history of the war has so shocked the public mind as the needless exposure of 1,700 of our soldiers to the murderous onslaught of 4,000 of the enemy at Ball's Bluff, in October of the first year. Nor has any event remained in so much obscurity. All that the people have known of it is that "somebody blundered." But who it was, and why he has never been brought to account, has been a standing puzzle from that day to the present. The dealings with Gen. STONE only complicated the enigma. If he was the man in fault, why should he have been retained in the same command for three months afterward without rebuke, or any diminution of trust? When, afterward, he was so suddenly arrested, why was he suffered to lie in Fort Lafayette nearly a year without trial, or the slightest opportunity of meeting the charges against him? Why was he finally so suddenly released? And why, ever since, has he in vain sought a Court-martial or a Court of Inquiry? These questions have exercised the public mind not a little, but to no purpose. The whole chapter, from beginning to end, has been as impenetrable as the veil of Isis. There was something behind, but that was all that could be made out.
lead_paragraph: No event in the history of the war has so shocked the public mind as the needless exposure of 1,700 of our soldiers to the murderous onslaught of 4,000 of the enemy at Ball's Bluff, in October of the first year. But who it was, and why he has never been brought to account, has been a standing puzzle from that day to the present. The dealings with Gen. STONE only complicated the enigma. If he was the man in fault, why should he have been retained in the same command for three months afterward without rebuke, or any diminution of trust? When, afterward, he was so suddenly arrested, why was he suffered to lie in Fort Lafayette nearly a year without trial, or the slightest opportunity of meeting the charges against him? Why was he finally so suddenly released? And why, ever since, has he in vain sought a Court-martial or a Court of Inquiry? abstract: One of the grandest and most imposing military spectacles of modern times took place yesterday, in which President LINCOLN and the Commanding General of the army, accompanied by a large Staff, assisted; grand not alone in view of the number of troops present, but mainly because imposing in all that gives invincibility to the general appearance and movements of troops. It was a review of a portion of the Army of the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: HEADQUARTERS ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Thursday, April 9, 1863.

abstract: We have rebel reports from Charleston as late as 10 o'clock in the forenoon of the 9th inst. Up to that time, the bombardment of Fort Sumter, commenced on the 7th, had not been renewed. Official dispatches from BEAUREGARD, dated the 8th, make a positive statement that the Keokuk sunk on the morning of that day, in consequence of the injuries she received on the day previous, and the Press dispatches in the Richmond papers state that pieces of her furniture had washed ashore on the Morris Island beach. It is said also that one of the machines known as "devils," designed for the removal of torpedoes, had washed ashore -- probably the one attached to the Keokuk. The fighting appears to have been at a much closer range than at first reported. It was chiefly at a distance of nine hundred yards. It is said the Monitors cannot pass Fort Sumter without going within five hundred yards. Our vessels, at last accounts, were still in sight, and it was anticipated that the attack would be renewed on the 10th.

abstract: The anniversary of the New-York Female Auxiliary Bible Society was held in the Bible House Thursday afternoon. A large number of ladies were present, many of them those who assist in carrying out the system of continuous visitation of the poor for the purpose of aiding them and providing them with copies of the Scriptures. Rev. Dr. HOLDICH occupied the Chair, and Rev. Drs. VERMILYE, RODGERS, HOWARD, CROSBY and TYNG, took part in the exercises. The annual reports were of a gratifying character. The collections during the past year amounted to $5,466 05; $598 19 were expended for Bible distribution; $3,858 91 for the support of the Bible readers, and $1,008 95 was paid over to the American Bible Society.

abstract: In view of the probable and speedy enforcement of the Conscription act, and the consequent necessity for the reorganization of our armies, we offer for the earnest consideration of the country some views written during this war by an officer of talent, rank and experience in the regular army.
lead_paragraph: In view of the probable and speedy enforcement of the Conscription act, and the consequent necessity for the reorganization of our armies, we offer for the earnest consideration of the country some views written during this war by an officer of talent, rank and experience in the regular army. He has served on the Staffs of Gens. SHERMAN and HUNTER at Port Royal, MCCLELLAN at Antietam, and recently, GRANT in Mississippi. His plans have been submitted to Gen. GRANT, Gen. MCCLERNAND, Gen. MCPHERSON and Gen. LOGAN, as well as many others of the Western army, and received the warm approval of all those officers. Indeed, no man can have been long in the service, and not acknowledge the absolute necessity of a reorganization of our armies. This it is which the rebels possess and we lack; this it is which too often turns the scales when they are equally balanced; this it is which is likely eventually to decide the great contest in which we are engaged.

abstract: A grand mass meeting of the citizens of New-York, regardless of party affiliation, was held yesterday afternoon at Union-square. The object of the meeting was to reiterate in the ears of Southern traitors, and before the eyes of Northern sympathizers, the loyalty of New-York to the Union, its confidence in the Administration, its desire for an aggressive war-policy, its extreme abhorrence of all Confederates and absolute detestation of all Copperheads. Six stands were erected, from which sweet music was given and eloquent addresses delivered. Great enthusiasm pervaded the vast assemblage, which at one time must have numbered 30,000 persons, among whom were many ladies. The hotels and private residences in and about the Square were gaily decorated with flags; banners hung from many windows, and all things wore the look of a holiday. Cannon were momentarily discharged, brass bands continually clamored forth airs of patriotism, and shouts of applause drowned them all. For the lists of officers, the letters from distinguished men, the resolutions and the addresses we have no space, and necessarily confine ourselves to an abstract of the proceedings, which, though in some instances comparatively brief, will serve as a sufficient exponent of the loyal tone which pervaded the addresses, and the loyal spirit which was evinced by the enthusiastic thousands who responded to the call.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill authorizing the consolidation of City railroads was reported favorably; also, the Gravesend Railroad bill; also, the Newtown Double-track Railroad bill; also, the New-York Supervisors' Salary bill, which was tabled; also, the South Bergen Railroad bill; also, the bill amending the Code of Procedure, which was ordered to a third reading; also, the Brooklyn Tunnel Assessment bill, which was ordered to a third reading. The House amendments to the bill appropriating the surplus Canal revenues were non-concurred in.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on March 27, Mr. W.E. FORSTER rose to ask the noble Vicount whether the attention of Her Majesty's Government had been called to the danger to our friendly relations with the United States, resulting from the fitting out in our ports of ships of war for the service of the self-styled Confederate States, in contravention of the Foreign Enlistment act and of the policy of neutrality adopted by this country. Some persons, he said, most of whom were British subjects, were, in defiance of the Queen's proclamation and the statutes of the realm, breaking the law, and were engaged in acts which placed the country in danger of being involved in war. That was so notorious a fact that papers had been presented with regard to one of the most flagrant cases -- the fitting out of the Alabama. The first question for consideration was, whether the Government had done all that they could to prevent these breaches of the law; and the second was, whether they were impressed with the necessity of doing their utmost to prevent them for the future. So great was the danger, that he thought the House ought not to separate for the holidays without obtaining from the Government an answer upon on this point, more especially as to the future. With regard to the past, it would be more convenient if the discussion could be postponed, as additional light would be thrown upon it by the papers which had been asked for. Nevertheless, in the present state of feeling, both in this country and in America, he thought the Government ought at once verbally to give the explanation which the facts stated in the paper already published seemed to demand. On the 234 of last June, the American Minister wrote to Earl RUSSELL, and, after referring to the case of the Oreto, said:

abstract: Among the many signs of a change in public sentiment in Europe regarding Mexico, the recent prompt acquiescence of the Prussian Government to the request of the Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs for the recall of the Prussian Minister in Mexico, BARON E. DE WAGNER, is not the least significant. BARON WAGNER, by his active partizanship with the Church party, his hatred to the liberal cause, and his subserviency to the French, had made himself most obnoxious to the Mexican Government and people; and his constant disregard of all the courtesies recognized in diplomatic intercourse had made it almost impossible for any minister of foreign affairs, possessing any just sensitiveness as to his own or his country's dignity, to transact official business with him.
lead_paragraph: Among the many signs of a change in public sentiment in Europe regarding Mexico, the recent prompt acquiescence of the Prussian Government to the request of the Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs for the recall of the Prussian Minister in Mexico, BARON E. abstract: The trial-trip of the steamer Morning Star, which was launched a few days ago, took place on Thursday. A number of gentlemen were on board, and everything passed off in the most satisfactory manner. The vessel left the Pier, foot of Corlears-street, at 10 A.M., and proceeded down the Narrows to some distance below Sandy Hook, and returned to her slip at the foot of North Moore-street at about 5 P.M. The Morning Star was built by order of the New-York Mail Steamship Company and is intended to run between New-York and New-Orleans via Havana. Her hull was built by Messrs. ROSEVELT, JOYCE & CO., of New-York, and is of the following dimensions: Length at the light load line, 266 feet; length on deck, (Custom-House measure,) 273 feet; length over all, 283 feet; breadth of beam, 39 feet and 4 inches; depth of bold, 23 feet; tonnage, Custom-house measure, 2,022 tons; carpenters, measure, 2,147 tons.

abstract: The harbor of Charleston is about the only part of the great field of operations in which important active work is going on at this moment. Everywhere else matters remain in statu quo, except perhaps at Vicksburgh and on the North Carolina coast, from both of which the advices are confused and unsatisfactory. We hear nothing further of the naval bombardment of Vicksburgh, which was reported to have been opened a week ago, and as the rebels report that FARRAGUT's sihps have again appeared above Port Hudson, we may conclude that no serious bombardment was begun. All the canals, and all the naval and military expeditions designed by Gen. GRANT to turn Vicksburgh, have been given up. A rebel telegram from there, under date of Tuesday last, announces that GRANT's troops have struck their tents, abandoned the peninsula, cut the levee and turned the water into their camping ground; and that a number of transports, laden with his soldiers, have gone up the river. There have been rumors that Gen. GRANT was again about to change his base to Memphis, with the purpose of renewing his once baffled march into Central Mississippi. The season and the weather are more favorable for such an enterprise than when he attempted it before, and may afford him better success. Beside, the movement would be of unquestionably great damage to the rebel cause in deranging and destroying the agricultural operations in the heart of Mississippi, where their papers boast the largest and finest crops of wheat are growing, to relieve the now pressing hunger of the South.
lead_paragraph: The harbor of Charleston is about the only part of the great field of operations in which important active work is going on at this moment. Everywhere else matters remain in statu quo, except perhaps at Vicksburgh and on the North Carolina coast, from both of which the advices are confused and unsatisfactory. We hear nothing further of the naval bombardment of Vicksburgh, which was reported to have been opened a week ago, and as the rebels report that FARRAGUT's sihps have again appeared above Port Hudson, we may conclude that no serious bombardment was begun. All the canals, and all the naval and military expeditions designed by Gen. GRANT to turn Vicksburgh, have been given up. A rebel telegram from there, under date of Tuesday last, announces that GRANT's troops have struck their tents, abandoned the peninsula, cut the levee and turned the water into their camping ground; and that a number of transports, laden with his soldiers, have gone up the river. There have been rumors that Gen. GRANT was again about to change his base to Memphis, with the purpose of renewing his once baffled march into Central Mississippi. The season and the weather are more favorable for such an enterprise than when he attempted it before, and may afford him better success. Beside, the movement would be of unquestionably great damage to the rebel cause in deranging and destroying the agricultural operations in the heart of Mississippi, where their papers boast the largest and finest crops of wheat are growing, to relieve the now pressing hunger of the South.

abstract: The Confederate Loan has advanced to 1 3/4@2 prem., in consequence of considerable purchases on Liverpool and Manchester account. The letters of allotment are to be issued this evening. The market has assumed a more steady appearance. Apart from the consideration that the last advices from New-York denote that the conscription will probably fail, and that there is a chance of the Federal Government being without an army in three months, when the Confederate Generals would find little difficulty in occupying Washington and dictating terms of peace -- numerous parties, interested chiefly in Liverpool and Manchester, appear to consider that with the loan even at a premium of 50 per cent., the price of cotton obtained through it would only be 8 1/4 per cent. per pound, whilst the lowest estimate of the price to which cotton of the description enumerated in the prospectus might fall, in the event of peace, would be about 10d. per pound.

abstract: Hitherto the defence of Richmond has been confided to one military head, whose department embraced all the territory of Eastern Virginia and North Carolina. But a division of the department has taken place, as we learn from the Richmond papers. An official order of Adjt.-Gen. S. COOPER, dated April 1, establishes the following change: The geographical limits of the command of Lieut.-Gen. LONGSTREET, embracing the defences of Richmond and extending south to include the State of North Carolina, the whole under the supervision and general direction of Gen. R.E. LEE, is divided into three military departments, as follows: All north of the James River, for the defence of Richmond, will constitute the Department of Richmond, under Maj.-Gen. ELZEY, headquarters Richmond; all that portion of Virginia south of the James River and east of the County of Powhatan, constitutes the Department of Southern Virginia, under Maj.-Gen. FRENCH, headquarters at some central point near the Blackwater; the State of North Carolina constitutes the Department of North Carolina, under Maj.-Gen. D.H. HILL, headquarters Goldsboro.

abstract: At length we have conclusive proof that "the sea-serpent" is something more than a myth. A telegram from Posen, brought here by the European steamer of yesterday, announces "that a strong Russian column had entered that Duchy, marching by way of Pleschen, Neustadt and Vreschen, and had afterward returned to Poland." One fact is said to be worth a whole cart-load of arguments, and the foregoing fact sets at rest the controversy about the Prusso-Russian Convention. The existence and nature of that instrument are now revealed; and not only so, but we have authentic evidence that it is in actual operation, notwithstanding the denunciations of the French and English Press, the Prussian Deputies and the British Commons, and despite the remonstrances of the Governments of the Western Powers. The Prussian King, like the boy in the fable, is not to be driven from his purpose by clods. The friendly remonstrances of France and England have not produced the anticipated effect, and M. DROUYN DE LHUYS and Earl RUSSELL have discovered that if they would make an impression on the mind of the royal Brandenburgher, it must be by expostulations of a different kind.
lead_paragraph: At length we have conclusive proof that "the sea-serpent" is something more than a myth. The Prussian King, like the boy in the fable, is not to be driven from his purpose by clods. The friendly remonstrances of France and England have not produced the anticipated effect, and M. abstract: An immense mass meeting was held in Union-square yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Loyal National League -- it being the anniversary of the rebel attack upon Fort Sumter. Between twenty and thirty thousand people were present, and the greatest enthusiasm prevailed. The populace were addressed from six different stands around the Square, and among the speakers were Maj.-Gen. FREMONT, Maj.-Gen. SIGEL, Postmaster-General BLAIR, Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, Hon. SCHUYLER COLFAX, Senator WILSON of Massachusetts, Judge KELLY and BENJ. H. BREWSTER, of Philadelphia, Col. WOODFORD, Judge PIERREPONT, and others.

abstract: Several weeks ago we called attention to the fact that the rebel blockade runners might be enabled to make their exchanges in our Northern cities by means of North Carolina bonds. But we did not at that time expect to have either so prompt or so perfect a demonstration of the correctness of our views as that presented by the arrest of CRAWFORD, in this city, on Wednesday last. This man appears to have been largely engaged in the contraband trade between the loyal States and Richmond. He made extensive purchases, and among the effects found in his possession were nine North Carolina bonds for one thousand dollars, which he admitted he was going to New-York to negotiate, for the purpose of making payments for his goods. These bonds are now quoted in New-York at seventy-five to seventy-five and a half, and they consequently afford a most convenient and desirable medium of exchange for the rebel spies and contrabandists who infest our lines.

abstract: An Englishman, named JOHN WILSON, was brought before Justice OSBORNE yesterday, at the Essex Market Police Court, charged with having broken into and robbed the house of MAX S. MEYER, No. 3 Ridge-st., of money and goods amounting to about $2,000. Among the stolen property there was gold coin in $10 and $5 pieces to the amount of $1,100, and Treasury Notes to the extent of $300. The balance of the plunder consisted of silver coin, silk dresses, coats, pants and other articles of wearing apparel. Officer GASTLIN, of the Thirteenth Precinct, discovered the prisoner as he was leaving the premises with a large bundle under his arm, and believing him to be a suspicious character, he followed him a short distance, and finally took him into custody. All the stolen property was recovered from the possession of the accused, with the exception of the money. It is presumed that WILSON had ingeniously passed the latter to an accomplice immediately after the robbery was consummated. In WILSON's possession were found a set of skeleton keys, a jimmy, and other instruments usually carried by burglars. The accused, when taken before the magistrate, stated that he was an English sailor, just arrived on a packet ship from London. The police state, however, that he is a skillful and experienced English burglar, who has been some time prowling around New-York. He was committed for examination.

abstract: JOHN SLIDELL rises to the sublimity of assurance in his note from Paris to London to the effect that JEFFERSON DAVIS is not a Mississippi repudiator. Like all political gamesters, SLIDELL takes for granted that the end -- which, in this instance, is to bolster the waning prospects of the Confederate Cotton Loan -- justifies the means. He acted upon this when he planned and successfully executed the Plaquemines fraud in 1844 to cheat Mr. CLAY out of the electoral vote of Louisiana. He acted upon it when he left his seat in the United States Senate, in 1861, without instructions from his State, and then forced the State, by another fraudulent election, like that of Plaquemines, to join the rebellion. But SLIDELL, while thoroughly corrupt and unscrupulous, is not an ignorant man, in any sense, and least of all on the party politics of the South. He knows JEFFERSON DAVIS to be a Repudiator, as the whole country has known it for twenty years. In his anxiety to impose the fraudulent Cotton Loan on the Old World, however, he assumed that England and Holland, who suffered the whole loss of the Mississippi Union Bank fraud, and held two millions of Mississippi Planters' Bank obligations, were or might be ignorant of the fact.
lead_paragraph: JOHN SLIDELL rises to the sublimity of assurance in his note from Paris to London to the effect that JEFFERSON DAVIS is not a Mississippi repudiator. Like all political gamesters, SLIDELL takes for granted that the end -- which, in this instance, is to bolster the waning prospects of the Confederate Cotton Loan -- justifies the means. He acted upon this when he planned and successfully executed the Plaquemines fraud in 1844 to cheat Mr. CLAY out of the electoral vote of Louisiana. He acted upon it when he left his seat in the United States Senate, in 1861, without instructions from his State, and then forced the State, by another fraudulent election, like that of Plaquemines, to join the rebellion. But SLIDELL, while thoroughly corrupt and unscrupulous, is not an ignorant man, in any sense, and least of all on the party politics of the South. He knows JEFFERSON DAVIS to be a Repudiator, as the whole country has known it for twenty years. In his anxiety to impose the fraudulent Cotton Loan on the Old World, however, he assumed that England and Holland, who suffered the whole loss of the Mississippi Union Bank fraud, and held two millions of Mississippi Planters' Bank obligations, were or might be ignorant of the fact.

abstract: A Government dispatch boat arrived at Baltimore, yesterday, from the fleet at Charleston, bringing dispatches for the Government and a special correspondent of the TIMES. We give elsewhere an account of the operations before Charleston, as received by telegraph, and at an early hour this morning we shall publish full details in an extra edition. In the attack on Fort Sumter, our correspondent says the iron-clads met with a repulse, but not with a disaster. The attack was made on the afternoon of the 7th, and continued two hours and a half. The fleet found it impossible to pass inside of Fort Sumter, as had been arranged, on account of obstructions in the channel, and on reaching a point between Sumter and Moultrie, became exposed to a concentric fire from five different points, unparalleled in the history of warfare. This fire the vessels were exposed to for thirty minutes, during which time not less than thirty-five hundred shots were fired by the enemy. Five of the nine iron-clads were then found to be more or less disabled, and the signal was given to retire. Our vessels received each from twenty to ninety shots -- the Keokuk being the worst damaged, and sinking the next morning. She was to be blown up, to prevent her falling into the hands of the enemy. The casualties in the fleet were very few.

abstract: It having been objected against the proposal of A.T. STEWART and others to accept the franchise of a Railroad in Broadway, and pay therefor $2,000,000, or run the road at three cents fare, that this offer was made before the bill in the Senate had received important amendments, it will be seen from their offer made this day to the House, that it has been renewed, to apply to the bill as it passed the Senate; and in addition, that they propose to give bonds to complete and operate the road within the time specified in the bill; and, further, that they agree to accept the franchise for the equal benefit of all owners of street property on the several lines embraced in the bill, and, ultimately, for the benefit of the City, which may at any time be substituted in their place and stead, on making restitution for the outlay.

abstract: Capt. S. COOPER, master of the ship John A. Park, of Halliwell, who arrived yesterday by the ship Miss Nightingale, thus reports the destruction of his vessel by the Confederate steamer Alabama. He sailed from New-York for Montevideo on the 13th of February, with a cargo of lumber. On the 2d inst., being in lat. 29 15 N., long. 38 20 W., at daylight the second officer reported a steamer ahead, bark rigged, which proved to be the Alabama. A boat came alongside with an armed crew, and boarded and took charge of the ship. Capt. COOPER was taken before Capt. SEMMES, who asked him if he knew to whom the cargo belonged; and he answered he could not say, but referred for information to the bills of lading, which specified, by certificates of the British Consul at New-York, that the cargo was British property. After examination of the papers, Capt. SEMMES expressed his opinion that the cargo was not British property. Capt. COOPER was then ordered on board his own ship, and told to bring his clothes, and those of his crew, on board the Alabama. When the work of transferring the stores had been completed, the crew of the Alabama set fire to the ship. The English bark Miss Nightingale, bound for London, was in sight, and Capt. COCHRANE kindly consented to take home to England Capt. COOPER, his wife and two young men. The remainder of the ship's company, consisting of three mates, a carpenter and 16 seamen, were left on board the Alabama. The captain and the two young men were compelled to sign a parole of honor not to serve against the Confederate States during the war.

abstract: To-morrow night, at the Academy of music, a grand ball will be given in aid of the Irish Relief Fund. Great preparations are made for a saltatory demonstration of unusual attraction, and already several hundreds of tickets have been sold. The Board of Managers includes the names of many of our best known and most influential citizens, who appeal to the sympathies of our community in behalf of the suffering poor of Ireland, from whom come in every steamer the most piteous petitions for assistance. Without a doubt, the affair will be a grand success; the cause is most worthy, the managers efficient, and the public ready, as at all times, to generously respond.

abstract: The farewell of Madame MEDORI draws nigh, but prior to that regretful period we are promised an ample supply of her delicious vocalism. To-night, the brilliantly successful opera " Ione," which has drawn crowded houses at every rendition, will be...
lead_paragraph: The farewell of Madame MEDORI draws nigh, but prior to that regretful period we are promised an ample supply of her delicious vocalism. To-night, the brilliantly successful opera " Ione," which has drawn crowded houses at every rendition, will be given for the last time, with MEDORI, SULZER, MAZZOLENI, BELLINI and BIACHI in their original roles. On Wednesday, Mr. MARETZEK, the efficient manager, takes his benefit, which, we trust, will be a bumper, on which occasion will be produced, for the first and only time, "I Due Foscari." On Friday night, the farewell of Madame MEDORI, will be signalized by the reproduction of "Norma," in which opera she has created the greatest sensation.

abstract: We are enabled to give, this morning, (by telegraph from Baltimore,) the main facts, in brief, of the attack on Fort Sumter by our iron-clads, on Tuesday last. They are furnished by our Special Correspondent, ("W.S.,") who was with Admiral DUPONT at the battle, and who returns North, with official dispatches for the Government, and a detailed account of the action and its results for the TIMES. We had hoped to get the letter in season for our first edition of this morning, but it has not arrived up to 2 o'clock. Our correspondent has taken an Express Train from Baltimore to this City, and we hope to get his account before daylight, when we shall immediately issue an extra edition, which will be ready for circulation shortly after breakfast time.

abstract: -- Will not some of our Loyal Leagues do the public the favor, and the Union cause the service, of securing the repetition, in this City, by EDWARD EVERETT, of the splendid address which he recently made in Boston on the rebellion? It is one of the finest efforts of this master of eloquence, and would be heard with delight by as many of our citizens as our largest hall could hold. Mr. EVERETT's efforts on behalf of the Union during the past few years merit the grateful acknowledgments of the whole country. Not only the fervor of his patriotism, but the strength of his intellect and the eloquence of his tongue seem to increase with his years. The abundant record of his fruitful life shows no finer orations than those he has pronounced since this war began, In one most important department of this great discussion -- wide and accurate knowledge of the precedents and events of history -- he is beyond comparison at the head of all American statesmen, and in all his speeches he makes most admirable and effective use of this great advantage. We trust we shall have an opportunity to hear his latest address in this City.
lead_paragraph: -- Will not some of our Loyal Leagues do the public the favor, and the Union cause the service, of securing the repetition, in this City, by EDWARD EVERETT, of the splendid address which he recently made in Boston on the rebellion? abstract: The speeches of the Solicitor-General and of Lord PALMERSTON, which we published in full yesterday, brought by the last steamer, forbid all further doubt that there is a deliberate purpose and a settled plan on the part of the British Cabinet to violate its neutral obligations to this country. Our people should apprehend this distinctly, and our Government should take effective measures...
lead_paragraph: The speeches of the Solicitor-General and of Lord PALMERSTON, which we published in full yesterday, brought by the last steamer, forbid all further doubt that there is a deliberate purpose and a settled plan on the part of the British Cabinet to violate its neutral obligations to this country. Our people should apprehend this distinctly, and our Government should take effective measures against it quickly. The principles announced, and the spirit manifested, make it clear that the Cabinet will do nothing effectually to prevent the completion and the equipment of the fleet of new Confederate war steamers, and its sailing from the British shores; and that the same facilities will afterward be extended to them in British ports, as have given to the Alabama and the Florida such an immense advantage in making havoc of our commerce. Wrong-doing, which many peacefully inclined Americans were at first disposed to consider as mere accident or inconsiderateness arising from the novelty of the situation, now takes the shape of a definite and boldly avowed policy. It must be recognized to be just what it is, and it must be resisted accordingly.

abstract: -- Our neighbor, the World, says that, "provided his course does not tend to put his country at the mercy of the enemy, a peace man in war time may be just as good a patriot as a war man. England never had better patriots than Lord CHATHAM and Mr. BURKE; but these great statesmen were vehement in their opposition to the American war." And yet this same patriot CHATHAM rose from his dying bed to protest in his place in Parliament against peace with the American rebellion as an ignominious surrender of the rights and present possessions of the nation. We wish our cotemporary had more of the national spirit of the man it so justly praises.

abstract: -- The Leader, which has always been the recognized organ of the Tammany Hall Democracy, but which was one of the most zealous in welcoming FERNANDO WOOD to the leadership of the united Democracy last Fall, now throws him overboard with great emphasis and very little ceremony. His recent peace speech is distinctly and unequivocally repudiated. It is characterized as an attempt on Mr. WOOD's part to "subvert the regular Democratic platform and substitute for it a miserable election of his own." He is irreverently spoken of as a "restless and ambitious demagogue," as being "cursed with a prurient itch for oratory and public attention," and is informed that "his attempt to thrust his nostrums down the throat of the party are impotent and absurd."

abstract: needed the lesson in Charleston harbor to give new emphasis to the policy of concentration in future movements against the rebels. It is a year and a half since the Union power was planted on the Coast of South Carolina, and the heart of the nation leaped for joy when the landing took place at Hilton Head, for the universal thought was, this is but the first step for the reduction of Charleston. But the year and a half has sped away, and the first movement against Charleston is at length made, with a force wholly inadequate to the work.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. "Ione; or, the Last Days of Pompeii," was given at the Academy for the fourth and last time last evening. The house was crowded, and received the performance with the utmost enthusiasm. Mme. MEDORI sang with as much sustained power as ever, and MAZZOLENI and BIACCHI...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Ione; or, the Last Days of Pompeii," was given at the Academy for the fourth and last time last evening. The house was crowded, and received the performance with the utmost enthusiasm. Mme. MEDORI sang with as much sustained power as ever, and MAZZOLENI and BIACCHI were in more than usually fine voice. Mlle. SULZER, of course, came in for her share of the honors. This was Mme. MEDORI's last appearance but two. To-morrow is set apart for the benefit of MAX MARETZEK, when the opera of "I Due Foscari" will be presented for the first time in several years. The role of the old Doge will afford BIACCHI the finest opportunity he has yet had for displaying his wonderful method and the resources of his magnificent voice. The occasion is one that every admirer of Italian opera should consider himself bound to celebrate and sustain. MAX MARETZEK has done, perhaps, more than any man to establish a taste for the highest form of musical art in this country, and this season, especially, he has introduced to us the best company, and produced first-class operas in better style, than has been heard and seen in New-York for a very long while.

abstract: -- There will be disappointment felt by the people on account of the failure of the iron-clad boats to pass unscathed the fires of the forts in Charleston harbor. The popular belief has been that the Monitors were wholly impenetrable to shot and shell, and could defy any land forts that are built. We must assure all persons who have had such faith, that they have been wilfully ignorant. We have again and again, in these columns, chronicled the results of experiments with heavy guns and armor plate in England, and brought out the fact that the thickest iron armor ever proposed for ships has been shattered by some guns and pierced through and through like pine boards by others. And the conclusion at this day in England is, that no metallic plates ever invented are a match for the projectiles of modern ordnance. The repulse will teach our Government a lesson at no great cost that may be improved on before another attack on a rebel stronghold is attempted.

abstract: The steamer Roanoke brings from Havana some interesting Mexican news. The English mail steamer Conway had arrived there with advices from Vera Cruz to the 1st inst., from the City of Mexico to the 22d ult., and from Peubla to the 23d. Nothing of importance appears to have occurred in the neighborhood of Peubla, and it was considered altogether uncertain when an attack would be made by the French, or whether an...
lead_paragraph: The steamer Roanoke brings from Havana some interesting Mexican news. The English mail steamer Conway had arrived there with advices from Vera Cruz to the 1st inst., from the City of Mexico to the 22d ult., and from Peubla to the 23d. Nothing of importance appears to have occurred in the neighborhood of Peubla, and it was considered altogether uncertain when an attack would be made by the French, or whether an attack would be made at all. Gen. ORTEGA, commanding at Puebla, had issued a proclamation in French to the French soldiers, well calculated to promote desertions from Gen. FOREY's army. It was having an extensive circulation. French reinforcements had arrived at Vera Cruz, and were landed on the 25th ult. -- about 5,000 men. The guerrillas had made an attack on about 1,500 laborers working on the railroad from Vera Cruz, and had carried off all who were Mexicans as prisoners.

abstract: On opening the Paymaster's Department at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, yesterday, it was discovered that all the money (about $140,000) which was brought over on Saturday to pay off the men on yesterday had been stolen from the safe. It appears that some one provided with keys, and knowing the place well, obtained access to the pay office on Saturday night or during Sunday. Yesterday morning Capt. WAUGH, of the Gate Watch, endeavored to stop a suspicious person going out of the yard, but did not succeed, the stranger eluding his grasp. The matter is in the hands of the police.
lead_paragraph: On opening the Paymaster's Department at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, yesterday, it was discovered that all the money (about $140,000) which was brought over on Saturday to pay off the men on yesterday had been stolen from the safe. abstract: THE HOPE OF THE REBELS. -- The Marquis of Hartington, who "got himself into difficulty" in this City a few weeks ago by wearing a Secession badge at an evening party, has been making a speech to the electors of Lancaster, who have returned him to Parliament. A good part of it he devotes to the American war. He narrates some of his experiences in the South and gives his opinion of rebel prospects, mentions the condition of parties in the North and gives his ideas on our prospects, and winds up by applying the bearings of the whole upon the cotton hopes of Lancashire. He thought the rebels would never compromise, would never give in, would fight to the last, would never come back to the Union -- though he thought it possible they might be exterminated. He adopted all their last ditch declarations, and put them into excellent English.
lead_paragraph: THE HOPE OF THE REBELS. -- The Marquis of Hartington, who "got himself into difficulty" in this City a few weeks ago by wearing a Secession badge at an evening party, has been making a speech to the electors of Lancaster, who have returned him to Parliament. He thought the rebels would never compromise, would never give in, would fight to the last, would never come back to the Union -- though he thought it possible they might be exterminated. He adopted all their last ditch declarations, and put them into excellent English.

abstract: There are many in our volatile and too thoughtless population that will mourn over the news from Charleston as over an irreparable calamity. They will liken it to the defeat of an army, and believe that while it entails discomfiture and loss on the Union cause, it will correspondingly benefit the enemy. We do not recognize the propriety of any such view of the case. When an army is repulsed, as at the second Manassas or at Fredericksburgh, tens of thousands of lives are lost, and material of war of enormous value is sacrificed. The whole land is thrown into mourning for the dead, and the Government requires months of stupendous effort to restore munitions of war, as well as numbers and spirit to the ranks of the army. We find no such results as these in turning to the Charleston fight. There was no bloody conflict of hundreds of regiments of brave soldiers; no wavering of lines; no flight of shattered columns; no confused retreat, and anxiety to save a great army, upon which the safety of the nation depends. Very far from it. The selected engines of war approached the forts that sentinel the rebel harbor; they measured with them strength of defensive armor and power of offensive ordnance, and ascertaining the superiority of the enemy, they retired in good order out of harm's way. Scarcely a score of men, in all, are injured in the conflict; and only one boat sunk, whose place perhaps it is not worth while for the Government dockyards to fill. Such was the fight before Charleston -- a mere contest of strength between ordnance afloat and on shore -- and furnishing results valuable to science, but wholly inconclusive of the issue between loyalty and rebellion.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of bills were passed -- most of them of only local interest. Among them was the one allowing the Brooklyn Central Railroad Company to change a portion of its route, and the one amending the Code of Procedure. A message was received from the Governor in reference to allowing soldiers to vote by proxy, and recommending an amendment of the Constitution for that purpose. It was, after some debate, referred to the Committee on Privileges and Elections. In the evening, the Annual Supply bill was made the special order for to-day.

abstract: The Navy Department, we learn from Washington, has received merely a brief memorandum from Admiral DUPONT in regard to the movement against Charleston the reports of the various commanders of the iron-clads not having been prepared in time to forward by the dispatch-boat.
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department, we learn from Washington, has received merely a brief memorandum from Admiral DUPONT in regard to the movement against Charleston -- the reports of the various commanders of the iron-clads not having been prepared in time to forward by the dispatch-boat. The full and lucid narrative of our Special Correspondent, however, will give the public full information on the subject.

abstract: The steamship Marion, which left New-York for Key West and New-Orleans on the 26th of March last, was totally wrecked on the Double Head Shot Keys on Thursday, April 2, about 4 o'clock P.M. She had a valuable cargo and 40 passengers. Eleven of the latter arrived at Cardenas in the brig B. Young on the 6th inst. They subsequently left for Havana, from which place the intended to sail in the Creole for New-York. The rest of the passengers arrived in Havana a few hours previous to the departure of the Roanoke for New-York. The Marion will prove a total wreck. Assistance had been sent for to Nassau. The wreckers were already at work, saving part of the cargo, though in a damaged condition.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Marion, which left New-York for Key West and New-Orleans on the 26th of March last, was totally wrecked on the Double Head Shot Keys on Thursday, April 2, about 4 o'clock P.M. abstract: A special dispatch to the Boston Herald, dated Newbern, N. C., April 9, says:
lead_paragraph: The steamer Dudley Buck, from Newbern, N.C., on the 9th inst., arrived here yesterday morning. She brings news that Gen. FOSTER, with a force of 1,200 men, was yet at Washington, N.C., and surrounded by the rebels. It was expected he would have to surrender for the want of provisions. The transport Northerner left Newbern on the 7th with 800 men of SPINOLA's brigade to his assistance, by way of Tar River, and meeting a number of rebel batteries on the river, was forced to return. She had no one hurt on board.

abstract: -- A collection of choice pictures by our foremost American artists, belonging to a gentleman who has purchased them from the artist themselves, is on exhibition at LEEDS & CO.'s gallery, No. 23 Nassau-st., and comprises some of the best specimens of American landscape art. The DURANDS, KENSETT, GIFFORD, CASILEAR, SHATTUCK, BELLOWS, &c., are well worth examination, even by those not purchasing pictures. The few foreign and native figure pieces are the best of their class. We understand the whole collection is to be sold at auction on Thursday next, 16th inst., in the forenoon.

abstract: The exceedingly graphic letter of our correspondent in the iron-clad squadron will convince every reader that our attack last Tuesday upon the strongest of the rebel strongholds, though unavailing, was in no sense a disaster. It added to the glory of our navy, and involved no serious loss either of...
lead_paragraph: The exceedingly graphic letter of our correspondent in the iron-clad squadron will convince every reader that our attack last Tuesday upon the strongest of the rebel strongholds, though unavailing, was in no sense a disaster. It added to the glory of our navy, and involved no serious loss either of life or of material. In the annals of naval warfare, no instance can be found of a serious attack upon a place a hundredth part so formidable. Considering the tremendous calibre and scientific construction of the guns, and the fact that three hundred of them simultaneously belched their concentric fire upon the little fleet at the distance of only a few hundred yards, and considering, too, the infernal agents of destruction that lay beneath the water, as well as the curbs and the snares and the traps, all former attempts of the kind now seem but mere child's play. Such a Titanic job was never before undertaken on the planet. It is almost a miracle that it was carried so far with so little harm. And we have greater reason to rejoice over the escape than to grieve over the failure.

abstract: The Mexican Minister did not receive his mail today, brought by the last steamer, and we are yet without an authoritative contradiction of the French fables, put in circulation from Vera Cruz, of their military successes. It is enough for to-night to say, that Serior ROMERO confidently waits for intelligence from his Government, and has faith that the French war of conquest will yet be turned into a war of defeat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, April 14.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- BENEFIT OF MAX MARETZEK. -- This evening the opera performance at the Academy of Music is for the benefit of MAX MARETZEK. If ever impresario deserved well at the hands of the music-loving public it is be. Setting aside his indefatigable, indomitable efforts in by-gone seasons, he has within the past few weeks done enough to entitle him to the most generous measure of commendation and support. He has given us a series of lyric entertainments which, in point of genuine merit, have been far superior to anything of the kind offered to long-suffering New-York audiences for years. Without preliminary puff or subsequent ostentation, he has produced two new operas, and given a variety of old ones, with a perfection of ensemble to which we have long been unaccustomed, and his company, while not comprising any artists of overwhelming European celebrity who have outsung the freshness of their voices, has been one of the best for all practical purposes that has ever appeared at the Academy. For all this the public should prove, if not grateful, at least appreciative. What pleasure the fickle monster has received is owing to the enterprise and energy of MAX himself. The obligation is one that should be recognized and repaid, and the most effectual way of doing this will be by leaving no foot of space unoccupied in the Academy to-night. As additional inducements for every opera-goer to be there it should be stated that an opera, almost as good as new here, will be brought out in splendid style and that Madame MEDORI will make her last appearance in it. MEDORI is a great artist, whose wonderful voice and method are a revelation to all who have not enjoyed them. The opera is Verdi's "I Due Foscari," which has not been given in New-York since its production at Castle Garden in 1850. Though an early work of its composer, it possesses some of his most effective and popular characteristics. Besides MEDORI, MAZZOLENY and BELLINI have fine parts in it.

abstract: The telegraph informs us of the death, at Clifton Springs yesterday at 11 o'clock, of Commissary-Gen. BENJAMIN WELCH. Gen. WELCH was born at Kingston, Ulster County, and was 45 years of age. He studied law with the late CHARLES A. MANN in Utica, and was subsequently Editor of the Utica Democrat, and of the Buffalo Republican. He was at one time State Treasurer, and for four years Commissary-General of the State. A year ago he accepted a position on Gen. POPE's Staff. It was in the discharge of his duty in the campaign of last Summer that he contracted the disease which has now proved fatal.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Arago, we have advices from Charleston Bar to the evening of the 11th, at which time the Ironsides and six Monitors still remained inside the bar, off Morris Island, in the same positions taken by them after the ba[???]le of the 7th. Nothing of importance had transpired since the bombardment of Sumter on that day. Gen. HUNTER, with his land forces, was to return to Port Royal on the 11th. We receive by the Arago our special correspondence, giving details of events up to the time of her sailing, which will be found elsewhere.

abstract: The steamship Ocean Queen arrived at this port last evening, from Aspinwall on the 6th with California passengers and $217,601 in treasure. She brings intelligence from the United States of Colombia, and from Central and South America. The most important news is the announcement that CARRERA, the President of Guatemala, was preparing for another expedition against Salvador, and that there was a probability that all the Central American States would become involved. There is nothing else worthy of special note.

abstract: The steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 1st, and Queenstown on the 2d inst., arrived at this port yesterday forenoon. The advices are three days later. The British Parliament was not in session, having adjourned over for the Easter Holidays. Lord PALMERSTON, on the occasion of his installation as Lord-Rector of the Glasgow University, made a speech, in which he adverted briefly to American affairs, defending the policy of "neutrality." He subsequently attended a soiree of the working classes in the City Hall of Glasgow, at which he made a speech, still further defending the course of the Government. The London Herald announces, on indisputable authority, that the rebels will not contract any fresh loan in Europe this year, and probably not until after the close of the war. An account of the seizure of the Pelerhoff, furnished by LLOYD's agent at Matamoras, who was a passenger on her, is published. It takes the ground that the seizure was unjustifiable; that it was made by express orders from Admiral WILKES, and that Capt. BALDWIN, of the Vanderbilt, wished to let her go. Affairs in Poland still present a confused and indefinite appearance. It is now asserted that LANGIEWICZ is still a prisoner at Cracow. The Russian Government, in a note addressed to their representative at Paris, is said to have expressed a willingness to improve the condition of Poland, and to bestow additional liberal concessions. The National Assembly of Greece, on the 30th ult., unanimously proclaimed Prince WILLIAM, of Denmark, as King of Greece, under the title of "GEORGE the First." The Liverpool Cotton market was steady and unchanged. Breadstuffs were active, but Provisions were dull. Consols 92 1/2@92 5/8 for Money.
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 1st, and Queenstown on the 2d inst., arrived at this port yesterday forenoon. The advices are three days later. abstract: Mr. JOHN MORRISSEY, whose exhibition for the benefit of a bereaved family, several months since, realized some $1,600, has, with other prominent admirers of the manly art of self-defence, instituted a charity sparring exhibition for the relief of the suffering poor of Ireland. Some of the best professionals in the country have volunteered their services for the furtherance of the worthy object, a list of whom was given in a previous notice. The expenses of the affair will be insignificant, and doubtless in the competent hands of Mr. MORRISSEY, the pecuniary result will be most gratifying. The affair will take place to-morrow night at Hoym's Theatre, in the Bowery, and every possible arrangement has been made to secure perfect quiet and decorum. The exhibition will close by a friendly match between those distinguished proficients in the art. Messrs. JOHN MORRISSEY and MCCOOL, which of itself will be worth the price of admission.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a number of bills were reported favorably, but none of them of any great importance. Bills were passed -- incorporating the Soldiers' Rest and the Soldiers' Home, and relative to the Common Schools of New-York. A resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution so as to allow soldiers to vote, was introduced by Mr. GANSEN, and laid over under the rule.

abstract: The unsuccessful attack upon Charleston undoubtedly will be hailed with great satisfaction by the ruling classes of England as a serious damage to the National cause. This will be a mistake.
lead_paragraph: The unsuccessful attack upon Charleston undoubtedly will be hailed with great satisfaction by the ruling classes of England as a serious damage to the National cause. This will be a mistake. It is no damage in a positive sense, for little or no actual loss has been sustained. We have only failed to gain; and are simply as we were before, just as was the case with England in her Russian war, after the unsuccessful attack upon the Sebastopol forts by Admiral LYONS, and the unsuccessful demonstration upon Sweaborg by Admiral NAPIER.

abstract: in Charleston harbor has abated not a whit of Capt. ERICSSON's faith in the Monitors, as will be seen by his letter, which we publish this morning. He says that in every particular the new fighting machines worked precisely as intended, and that no change of plan is called for, though he admits that the pilot-house and the turret may have to be strengthened by additional iron-plating, which is very easily accomplished. The armor is applied to keep out hostile shot, and thus far, he says, we have fully succeeded.

abstract: The absorbing interest felt by the country in the fight at Charleston led to an undue magnification of the value of the struggle there. A few days have elapsed, and confidence with calmness has returned to the public mind. Attention is now again directed to the great armies in the field under HOOKER, ROSECRANS...
lead_paragraph: The absorbing interest felt by the country in the fight at Charleston led to an undue magnification of the value of the struggle there. A few days have elapsed, and confidence with calmness has returned to the public mind. Attention is now again directed to the great armies in the field under HOOKER, ROSECRANS and GRANT. There is hope for the Republic in these armies. Their leaders are a gallant trio -- much alike in many of the high qualities of soldiers -- hopeful in spirit, fervid in patriotism, bold in emprise and execution. In brief time the armies of these three leaders will be in motion, seeking the face of the enemy.

abstract: Later advices from North Carolina -- to the 12th -- are more favorable regarding the position of Gen. FOSTER at Little Washington. A communication had been received at Newbern from him, to the effect that he had plenty of supplies, and believed he could withstand all the force the rebels could bring against him for three weeks, if necessary. It was believed at Newbern that Gen. FOSTER could hold out until reinforced. A cavalry reconnoissance had proved that there were only some two thousand rebels between Newbern and Little Washington, instead of twelve or fifteen thousand, as before reported, and a brigade under Gen. AMORY started overland from Newbern on the morning of the 12th, to attempt a diversion in Gen. FOSTER's favor.

abstract: Not the least wonderful feature of the most wonderfnl battle in Charleston harbor, on Tuesday of last week, is that which has already been universally noticed the extraordinarily small list of casualties on both sides. There was but one man killed on the Union...
lead_paragraph: Not the least wonderful feature of the most wonderfnl battle in Charleston harbor, on Tuesday of last week, is that which has already been universally noticed -- the extraordinarily small list of casualties on both sides. There was but one man killed on the Union side, and but one boy killed outright on the rebel side. The man's name was EDWARD COBB, a Quartermaster, who came to his death by the springing of a bolt on the Monitor Nahant, by which his skull was fractured; the boy's name was AHRENS, a drummer lad, who was killed in Fort Sumter. There were also, as we learn from the rebel papers, two or three men wounded at the batteries, who subsequently died of their wounds. Beside these fatal cases, there were twelve or thirteen men wounded on our side, and apparently about as many on the rebel side.

abstract: Lord PALMERSTON is in his 80th year, but he has still no equal in jaunty impertinence. He has the face to talk to the people, of Glasgow about "those contending parties in America who sue England like rivals who sue a fair...
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON is in his 80th year, but he has still no equal in jaunty impertinence. He has the face to talk to the people, of Glasgow about "those contending parties in America who sue England like rivals who sue a fair damsel -- each party wanting us to take up her cause." Nobody knows better than Lord PALMERSTON that this simile has not the slightest basis of fact. He has read every word of the official correspondence between this Government and his own; he is not ignorant of the public opinion of this country as manifested in its public journals and popular meetings; and it is simply soulless trifling upon his part, thus to represent the questions on which hangs peace or war between the two nations.

abstract: The Board of Education, last evening, received a communication from the Secretary of the Board of Education of Melbourne, Australia, requesting an exchange of official documents. The Board acquiesced, and adopted a resolution authorizing the clerk to exchange documents with any similar bodies in other countries who may desire it. The Board adopted a resolution appropriating $26,000 for the purchase of lots Nos. 149, 151, 153 and 155 East Twenty-third-street, on which to erect a school-house for Ward school No. 40, in the Eighteenth Ward.

abstract: Yesterday the new steam gunboat Dai-Ching, which has been lying at the Brooklyn Navy-yard for over a week, was tranaferred to the Navy Department. She was built at the foot of North Secondstreet, Williamsburgh, for the Emperor of China, by...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the new steam gunboat Dai-Ching, which has been lying at the Brooklyn Navy-yard for over a week, was tranaferred to the Navy Department. She was built at the foot of North Secondstreet, Williamsburgh, for the Emperor of China, by JAMES C. JEWEYT & CO. Her dimensions are as follows: Length, 175 feet; width, 29 feet; depth of hold, 14 feet; draft of water. 11 feet; measurement, 728 tons. She has a direct acting engine, with two 20-inch cylinders and 26-inch stroke. She is an exceedingly pretty vessel, and will be put into active service at once. A smaller craft has been built by the same firm for the Chinese navy, which has not been purchased by the Government.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill fixing the salaries of the New-York Supervisors at $2,000 was ordered to a third reading; also, the bill providing for the regulation and inspection of buildings in New-York. The Assembly amendments to the bill for the promotion of enlistments were concurred in. The bill to facilitate the construction of a railroad along the upper valley of the Hudson was passed. Several other bills were passed, merely of local interest.

abstract: Our correspondent at New-Orleans, in a letter published Tuesday, presents some facts in regard to the military situation in Louisiana that are calculated to create surprise. He says that now for the first time since New-Orleans fell into the hands of the National troops is it seriously threatened by the rebels -- that the enemy is steadily concentrating his forces within striking distance of the city -- and that the war, in all probability, is about to be transferred from Virginia and the West to the Lower Mississippi.

abstract: About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a frightful accident occurred at No. 327 Broadway, whereby two women lost their lives. The particulars are as follows: ANGELINA PORTLIPPI and JOSEPHINE THOMPSON were employed by the firm of ELLIOT C. COWDIN  Co., dealers and importers of French fancy goods....
lead_paragraph: About 5 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a frightful accident occurred at No. 327 Broadway, whereby two women lost their lives. The particulars are as follows: ANGELINA PORTLIPPI and JOSEPHINE THOMPSON were employed by the firm of ELLIOT C. COWDIN & CO., dealers and importers of French fancy goods. The employers occupied the fifth story of the building. The two girls above named were through with their work at about 5 1/2 o'clock, and immediately made preparations to leave for home. When they were outside of the room where they had been engaged, they, by some means yet unknown, were suddenly precipitated through a hatchway from the fifth floor to the cellar. ANGELINA was killed immediately; her neck being broken -- in fact, her body was so bruised and mangled by the fall that she could with difficulty be identified by her most intimate friends. The other victim was also disfigured in a horrible manner. When taken up, however, she still breathed, and the Police at once conveyed her to the New-York Hospital, where she died about an hour afterward.

abstract: The Cincinnati Price Current, of the 15th inst., publishes its annual statement of the Pork-packing trade of the West. The editor says: "The result is wonderful. The number of hogs packed the present season is over four million head, being an increase over the packing of the season of 1861-2 of over a million and a quarter, namely: 1,357,787, being an increase of 40 1-10th cent. The decrease in weight is 7 1/2 percent., leaving a net increase of over 32 3-5th cent. as compared with last year. The yield of leaf lard is five pounds per hog less than it was in 1861-2, but owing to the great increase in the number of hops slaughtered, there is an absolute increase in quantity of 27 1/2 cent. over last season. In these comparisons we do not include the Tennessee packing last season. It will be seen that the great increase was in that section of the West tributary to Chicago, but of all that section, in no place was that increase so marked as in Iowa, and our correspondents in that State, say that fully one-half the hogs packed in Chicago, were shipped from thence, and explain the enormous increase in this way. The corn crop in that State, the past two years, was an unusually good one; but owing to the blockade of the Mississippi, the usual channel of outlet to a market, and the low price, the article did not admit of transportation to the East, it was therefore as a matter of necessity fed to hogs, to an extent unusual, and which would not have been the case had a market been accesible. This applies not only to Iowa, but to that portion of Illinois bordering, upon the Upper Mississippi. Owing to the great speculation in and high rate of gold, remunerative prices were obtained, and which proved of as much advantage to the feeders, as if the currency was down to a specie basis. The rise in gold affected none but those who use foreign goods, and of these the agricultural classes use but little. It will be seen that there is a large increase in all the States but Kentucky, and in that State there is a decrease, but this is not wonderful, and the surprise is that the packing along the Ohio was as large as it has been, owing to the disturbed state of affairs and the repeated menaces of the rebels along the border.
