abstract: By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Arabia, we have advices from Europe to the 5th -- three days later. The news is in some respects important. A heavy collapse in the Rebel Cotton Loan had taken place, consequent upon the suspension of J.B. SPENCE, of Liverpool, in the grain trade, and supposed to be the financial agent of the rebel Government. Although the supposition proved to be incorrect, the loan did not recover, but was at last accounts quoted at 2 3/4@2 1/4 discount. The London Times finds something to hope for in America from the inauguration of Union Leagues throughout the North. It apparently thinks the war will now soon he brought to a termination. Affairs are again threatening in Poland -- the insurrection being rapidly spreading. The peasants, nobility and middle classes are said to have joined in the movement. Some successes had been gained by the insurgents. The Liverpool cotton market was unchanged. Breadstuffs were steady and provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 92 3/8@92 5/8.

abstract: The Copperhead journals, whose general policy it always is to darken, so far as they can, every prospect of subduing the rebellion, have taken particular pains to argue down,
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead journals, whose general policy it always is to darken, so far as they can, every prospect of subduing the rebellion, have taken particular pains to argue down, or, in lack of argument, to sneer down, the likelihood that it must soon suffer serious straits from the want of food. Calculations based upon the figures of the last census tables -- conclusions drawn from the known agricultural resources of the region now within the command of the rebels -- accounts of great scarcity, which from every direction have been constantly finding their way across the lines -- and the prices current of the great staples of food as given in the principal Southern papers, have done nothing to diminish the assurance of these rebel-sympathizing prints that there is and always would be plenty of provisions in Dixie. Even the Proclamation of Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, last month, invoking the attention of his people to this great "danger," had no effect upon these "never-can-conquer" dogmatists. They have flouted straight on.

abstract: Sixteen men of Gen. abstract: We published last Friday an account of the proceedings before the Supreme Court in the case of HENRY B. HERTZ, Jr., against HENRY WOOD, the facts of which are, however, very much too interesting and instructive for us to...
lead_paragraph: We published last Friday an account of the proceedings before the Supreme Court in the case of HENRY B. HERTZ, Jr., against HENRY WOOD, the facts of which are, however, very much too interesting and instructive for us to allow them to lie buried in the obscurity of a law report. It appears that our present Sheriff, Mr. JAMES LYNCH, soon after his election, being anxious to diffuse the benefits of his office as wisely as possible, selected for his "auctioneer" Mr. HENRY WOOD, who, we need hardly say, is a brother of Messrs. BEN. and FERNANDO. There were only two objections to this arrangement; the first being that the Sheriff has no right to appoint an "auctioneer," being bound to do his own auctioneering, or pay for having it done out of his own fees; the second, that, supposing he took the power, Mr. HENRY WOOD was not a proper person to select for that duty, as he was not a professional auctioneer, and knew nothing about the business.

abstract: glad to find that the horrible reports which have been published by some journals, of the burning of the town of Jacksonville, Florida, by our forces, on the occasion of its evacuation, at the close of last month, are exaggerations. One of our cotemporaries published an account of the affair, the other day, written in the Ercles vein of wrath and fury, showing how the place was "burned, scorched and crisped, if not entirely consumed to ashes, by the devouring flames." All this, we were told by the same authority, was not done by the brave negro regiment at the post, but by the barbarous white men of New-England -- the Eighth Maine and Sixth Connecticut Volunteers. Another journal, of opposite politics, but like spirit, next took up the subject, and dwelt upon it in a style calculated to bring tears to the eyes of a crocodile -- showing conclusively the brutality of the "black hussars."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. MAX MARETZEK'S benefit on Wednesday evening, was an immense triumph fof the man and the manager. The Academy was crowded in every available part with an audience brilliant as beauty and Spring fashions could make it...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MAX MARETZEK's benefit on Wednesday evening, was an immense triumph fof the man and the manager. The Academy was crowded in every available part with an audience brilliant as beauty and Spring fashions could make it and the musical and other performances incident to the occasion went off with an eclat that has rarely been surpassed in the history of Italian opera in New-York. "I duo Foscari" is not one of VERDI's most felicitous efforts. It abounds in the instrumental noise and vocal difficulties for which most of his works are celebrated, without, like his later compositions, including a sufficiently redeeming quantity of passionate melody to make it popular. Still there are in it two or three very fine episodes, such for instance as the duet between the soprano and tenor in the second act -- sung with splendid dramatic effect by MEDORI and MAZZOLENI -- and the Doge's solo, exceedingly well rendered by BELLINI. But, whatever the opera, the house would have been full and the audience enthusiastic, to MAX had deserved well of the public and the public felt constrained to acknowledge the obligation. The singers coincided with the public, and had made preparations to testify their friendly appreciation of the professional capacity any personal good qualities of their director. These preparations they developed into action at the close of the second act, when the "indomitable," being thrust forward by kindly hands. Signor COLLETTI made him the neatest of little speeches simultaneously presenting him, on behalf of the company, with a silver tea service. MAX responded in eloquent dumb show, and received several avalanche, of overwhelming plaudits. Take it altogether, the affair was a highly flattering tribute of admiration and good will. It was a bright spot in MAX's lifetime that he can always look back upon with unalloyed pride and gratification. This evening Madame MEDOR makes her final appearance in Norma. MAZZOLENI will be the Pollio, and BIACCHI the Oroveso.

abstract: The rebel force at Charleston, prior to the late battle in its harbor, is believed to have been about 20,000, while about 10,000 more were at Savannah, an equal number at Wilmington, and detachments at other points--all
lead_paragraph: The rebel force at Charleston, prior to the late battle in its harbor, is believed to have been about 20,000, while about 10,000 more were at Savannah, an equal number at Wilmington, and detachments at other points -- all of whom could be concentrated, if needed, at Charleston, as soon as the preliminary work of a land attack was begun. The rebels will now doubtless suppose that they can release the greater part of these troops for work elsewhere. If they imagine that HOOKER is going to attack them in Virginia, they will run the troops along the two railroad lines that connect Charleston with Richmond, and thus, in less than a week, they can add thirty or forty thousand to the strength of LEE's army. Or, if they think by massing an additional twenty or thirty thousand in front of ROSECRANS, beside those that have lately been gathering there, that they can greatly outnumber and overwhelm the army of that gallant soldier, they can send them along the Charleston and Augusta, or Charleston, Savannah and Atlanta roads, and in ten days they might all be at Tullahoma. If they think they can overwhelm our forces at Newbern, simultaneous with the attempt to overwhelm them at Little Washington, they could dispatch their spare men there from Charleston in double-quick time. It is not likely they will make any attempt upon our lines at Port Royal, as that post, since Wednesday last, has been protected by a Monitor, and has probably now two or three, beside other vessels and its fortifications.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Newtown and Astoria Railroad bill was ordered to a third reading; also, the bill empowering the Mayor and Comptroller of New-York to appoint Tax-Marshals. The resolution proposing an amendment of the Constitution so as to allow soldiers to vote, was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The Annual Supply bill was passed; also, the bill relative to public instruction; also, the bill fixing the salaries of the New-York Supervisors at $2,000 per annum; also the Baldwinsville Canal bill; also the bill confirming certain ordinances of the New-York Common Council. The bill for the relief of wounded and sick soldiers was passed in the evening. It appropriates $200,000. The bill to amend the Militia act of last year was also passed. The Quarantine bill was referred to Messrs. MURPHY, LOW and SMITH, to report complete.

abstract: One can generalize better upon the effective condition of an army by its health returns than by any other single feature. A raw army in camp is invariably in a bad sanitary condition; the mortality lists of a demoralized or dispirited army are always frightful. The most favorable military health returns are from well-disciplined, high-toned armies, inured to the soldier's life.

abstract: From Fortress Monroe we have the gratifying, intelligence, this morning, that Gen. FOSTER, shut up in Little Washington, N.C., by the rebels, has been relieved. A river steamer, loaded with troops and supplies of provisions and ammunition...
lead_paragraph: From Fortress Monroe we have the gratifying, intelligence, this morning, that Gen. FOSTER, shut up in Little Washington, N.C., by the rebels, has been relieved. A river steamer, loaded with troops and supplies of provisions and ammunition, succeeded in running past the rebel batteries on the Tar River on the 14th, and reached the wharf at Washington in safety. All fears that Gen. FOSTER will be obliged to surrender himself and command may now probably be dismissed.

abstract: It seems to have been contemplated by the framers of the Conscription act of the late Congress that it wuuld not be possible to arrange all the details for putting it in operation before the 1st of July next. The 10th section of the act provides that the general enrollment of the militia for the purpose of drafting "shall only embrace those whose...
lead_paragraph: It seems to have been contemplated by the framers of the Conscription act of the late Congress that it wuuld not be possible to arrange all the details for putting it in operation before the 1st of July next. The 10th section of the act provides that the general enrollment of the militia for the purpose of drafting "shall only embrace those whose ages shall be, on the first day of July thereafter between twenty and forty-five years." And the 11th section provides that "all persons thus enrolled shall be subject for two years after the first of July succeeding the enrollment, to be called into the military service of the United States, and to continue in service for three years or during the war." It seems from this reading that persons liable to military duty under the Conscription act, cannot be called into the service previously to the "first of July."

abstract: There are no such unerring indices of the actual condition of the internal affairs of the Confederacy as the official documents of its rulers. Other rebel representations almost invariably are fashioned to suit the sanguine wish rather than the hard reality; but the...
lead_paragraph: There are no such unerring indices of the actual condition of the internal affairs of the Confederacy as the official documents of its rulers. Other rebel representations almost invariably are fashioned to suit the sanguine wish rather than the hard reality; but the responsible men in power have to deal with stern facts, which cannot be kept back or glossed over without ruin. Of course the authorities will always do their best to encourage, just as do the officers of a sinking ship; but, nevertheless, they must give some adequate conception of the real danger, or they will go under on the spot.

abstract: We trust our State Legislature will lose no time in taking steps so to amend the Constitution as to permit citizens of the State, while absent in the military service of the nation, to note by proxy. The required amendment...
lead_paragraph: We trust our State Legislature will lose no time in taking steps so to amend the Constitution as to permit citizens of the State, while absent in the military service of the nation, to note by proxy. The required amendment can be passed by this Legislature, -- and also by the next; and can then be submitted to the popular vote soon enough to secure to our soldiers in the field the exercise of their right of suffrage in the Presidential canvass of November, 1864. It is due to them and to the country, that they should have this right: and the Union men of our Legislature should see to it that nothing is left undone which they can do to secure it to them.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday impanneled a jury in the case of the two young women, ANGELINA PORTLIPPI and JOSEPHINE THOMPSON, who died from falling down a hatchway, on Thursday evening, at No. 327 Broadway -- a full account of which was published in the TIMES of yesterday. After the jury had viewed the bodies, the Coroner thought it best to postpone the further investigation of the matter until 10 o'clock this morning to enable the jurors to visit the premises where the accident occurred. An employe of the firm of COWDIN & Co. has furnished us with the information that he was the only person who witnessed the calamity; that at about 5 1/4 o'clock P.M., on Thursday, be went to the fifth loft where the packing is done; that while he was there he saw the two girls come out of the work-room, and jump on the sliding-door over the hoistway, (then closed,) one saving to the other. "Come, let us take a ride." They then pressed their backs against the wall, which caused the sliding-door to move so quickly that both lost their balance and were instantly precipitated through the hoistway.

abstract: The steamship British Queen arrived at this port last night, from Havana on the 11th inst. There is some additional intelligence from Mexico, but nothing of importance. Two French men-of-war had arrived from Vera Cruz, which port they left on the 4th. They reported that nothing new had occurred -- a report which was considered in Havana as auguring badly for the French. The steamship North Star, which had put into Havana, damaged in the same gale in which the Marion was lost, had continued her voyage to Aspinwall on the 10th.

abstract: OR SEAWEED. -- It has been discovered by the chemists of France that Kelp or Seaweed has been found to contain the properties necessary to give tone to the stomach, and impart a vigorous and healthy digestion. By distillation and analysis it is found to contain Iodine, Hydro-Potassium, Iron, Lime, and the Hypophosphites, and other very important chemical agents, which act on the food in the stomach, similar to the gastric juice, causing it to dissolve, and a perfect digestion is the result. It is remarkable how it produces strength and vigor to the system, making the most slender fleshy and robust, with a hale and hearty constitution.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Rome and Oswego, the Malden and the Newtown and Astoria Railroad bills were ordered to a third reading. The Assembly amendment to the New-York Harbor Defence bill, increasing the appropriation to $1,000,000, was non-concurred in, and a Con-...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Rome and Oswego, the Malden and the Newtown and Astoria Railroad bills were ordered to a third reading. The Assembly amendment to the New-York Harbor Defence bill, increasing the appropriation to $1,000,000, was non-concurred in, and a Conference Committee was appointed. The bill authorizing dummy engines on the Brooklyn Central Railroad was passed. The bill authorizing the Mayor and Comptroller of New-York to appoint thirty Tax Marshals was lost. The resolutions introduced by Mr. LOW, pledging the State to support the Administration in the vigorous prosecution of the war, were adopted. The Senate refused to consider a resolution for final adjournment.

abstract: There is to be another mass meeting of our loyal citizens on Monday next at Madisonsquare. It is called under the auspices of the original Loyal League, whose Chairman, Gen. SCOTT, has consented to preside on the occasion. The day selected for this meeting...
lead_paragraph: There is to be another mass meeting of our loyal citizens on Monday next at Madisonsquare. It is called under the auspices of the original Loyal League, whose Chairman, Gen. SCOTT, has consented to preside on the occasion. The day selected for this meeting is the anniversary of that grand uprising of the loyalty of the Northern States which immediately followed the infamous and treasonable attack on Fort Sumter, and which first gave the world to understand that whatever political or partisan differences might have prevailed among the people of the loyal States, they were all laid aside the moment the flag of our common country was insulted and the existence of the nation put in peril. The gathering two years ago on Union-square was the most important event in the history of the war thus far. The meeting of Monday, we trust, will be equally significant, and equally important in its influence and results.

abstract: The address which JEFF. DAVIS has just published to the people of the Confederate States is a singular compound of boasting and despondency. It would be hard to tell, unless one knew the obdurate character of the rebel President, whether he meant to cheer his people by assurances of final success, or alarm...
lead_paragraph: The address which JEFF. DAVIS has just published to the people of the Confederate States is a singular compound of boasting and despondency. It would be hard to tell, unless one knew the obdurate character of the rebel President, whether he meant to cheer his people by assurances of final success, or alarm them to extraordinary efforts by presages of imminent disaster. Friend and the of the Confederacy can alike derive comfort from the rebel exhibit of the situation; and the address should be hailed with as much satisfaction North, as South of Mason and Dixon's line.

abstract: An agent of the Northern Government came over here to treat for the construction and equipment of vessels-of-war for the Federal Navy. He obtained plans and estimates, with which he returned to Washington, and from that city he wrote to Mr. LAIRD, proposing that he should build a ship-of-war for the Federal Government, "with guns and everything appertaining." Shortly afterward Mr. LAIRD received another application, from the same quarter, for "two iron-plated steamers," and when he replied that the firm could not accept orders to be completed in so short a time, he was favored with a communication regretting his decision, and trusting that he might still be induced to undertake "one or more of the gunboats." After this we might well leave the case of the Alabama to drop. As far as our merchants are concerned, we know that commerce has no predilections, and that, in point of fact, the dealings of the Federals in our markets have been very much larger than those of the Confederates. Whatever, therefore, may be the opinions prevailing in this country, the Northerners cannot complain, for they have been supplied far more liberally than their opponents, while as to the proceedings of our Government they have been as impartial as possible. Though the Federals had unhesitatingly applied for Alabamas of their own, yet the Confedrate Alabama would have been stopped on their representations if our Government had been enabled to act in time. As it happened, the vessel escaped, but those who best know the difficulties attending such matters will be the least disposed to wonder at the event.

abstract: Counterfeit Treasury notes, altered from "twos" to "fiftys," were extensively circulated in this City and Brooklyn yesterday and last evening. The figure "two" on the upper corners is covered by pasting the number "fifty" over it, and the word "two" around the edges is carefully erased with green paint.

abstract: The nomination of a brother-in-law of the Prince of Wales to the throne of Greece-following, as that arrangement did, with suspicious haste on the abrupt withdrawal of the Greek Legation from London -- brings into strong relief one of the most striking pictures of recent diplomacy in England. We shall not weary our readers with all the details, but it is worth while to take a hurried glance at some of the transactions of the British Foreign Office, in the matter of finding a successor for King OTHO, during the last six months. We shall discover in the retrospect a clue to the hesitating acts of the Provisional Government at Athens.

abstract: One of the most singular and least expected consequences of the rebellion has been to sink into oblivion nine-tenths of the traitors who brought it about.
lead_paragraph: One of the most singular and least expected consequences of the rebellion has been to sink into oblivion nine-tenths of the traitors who brought it about. Only three or four of the whole batch of conspirators who stampeded from Washington during the two or three months which preceded the inauguration of Mr. LINCOLN, have ever been heard of since. DAVIS, who was elected President before the events of the war had brought other names into prominence, still keeps his head above water, while BENJAMIN, who became Secretary of State, and who is a dextrous man of affairs, is also still occasionally heard from through his intercepted correspondence. But, with these exceptions, we hardly recall a man of the old Southern political regime who is now prominent. Where are now Cobb, Toombs, Wise, Hunter, Yancey, Keitt, Clingman, Rhett, Hammond, Miles, Lamar, Barksdale, Reuben Davis, Percy Walker, Savage, Edmondson, and a host of others, who have sunk so far out of sight that their names even cannot be recalled without the aid of a directory. They have all fallen into a degree of insignificance which cannot be fathomed. We occasionally read of the doings of the rebel Congress and Legislatures, but scarcely an allusion is ever made to one of these ancient worthies.

abstract: The Lynchburgh Republican says that in the interior of some of the Southern States flour is so scarce that children three and four years old have never seen biscuits. The father of a family, being on a visit to Savannah, took home with him some biscuits for his boys, aged three and five years old. Observing the eldest with a coal of fire on the top of his biscuit, he asked him what he meant. "To make the darned critter poke his head out," answered the boy; "that's the way, dad, to make terrapins crawl." The father laughed a hearty haw-haw, and left. It is to be hoped this contraband news will not reach the enemy, whom it would greatly rejoice.

abstract: COUNTERFEIT POSTAGE CURRENCY. -- JOHN KEENAN, keeper of a grogshop at No. 127 Cedar-street, who was arrested several days ago by Deputy Marshal BORST for passing counterfeit 50 cents postage currency, was examined before U.S. Commissioner WHITE on Friday, and committed for trial. Officer BORST secured 24 specimens of the counterfeit, which were found to differ from the genuine in the following particulars. In the counterfeit, the words "postage currency" on the top of the face of the paper are blotted; also the words "post office" on the right hand side at the bottom. On the reverse side, the checked border is also blotted and darker than the genuine. The heads of WASHINGTON on the face are also poorly done. The genuine are engraved on steel, whereas the counterfeits are lithographed. They are manufactured in this City and Philadelphia, and Officer BORST has obtained a clue to the counterfeiters, which will probably secure their arrest in a few days.

abstract: The sale of Mr. HALL's pictures, on Wednesday evening, was very successful, the collection bringing, exclusive of frames, over $7,000. "A Bunch of Purple Grapes" brought $185; "The Mimic Bull Fight," $450; "Raspberries in a Cabbage-leaf," $130; "Branch of Currants," $150; "El Aguador," $280; "The Glass of Organt," $360; "Three Peaches," $81. The collection numbered about one hundred works.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, among the bills passed was the one to reimburse the Manhattan Company the money expended for gold to pay the interest on the State debt, and Mr. MURPHY's Quarantine bill. Concurrent resolutions authorizing the Superintendent of the Banking Department to inquire into the condition of the Savings Banks were offered by Mr. MUNROE, and laid over under the rule. The bill providing for compensation to the members of the New-York Common Council was ordered to a third rending.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, among the bills passed was the one to reimburse the Manhattan Company the money expended for gold to pay the interest on the State debt, and Mr. MURPHY's Quarantine bill. Concurrent resolutions authorizing the Superintendent of the Banking Department to inquire into the condition of the Savings Banks were offered by Mr. MUNROE, and laid over under the rule. The bill providing for compensation to the members of the New-York Common Council was ordered to a third rending.

abstract: The frigate Re D'Italia, building by WM.H. WEBB, for the Italian Government, was launched at 9 1/2 A.M. yesterday, from the yard foot of Sixth-street. The decks were crowded with visitors, including a large number of ladies, and upon the adjacent piers and roofs was gathered an immense concourse. The vessel glided smoothly from the blocks and nearly reached the Williamsburgh shore. She was towed to the pier at the foot of Thirteenth-street, in close proximity to the Novelty Iron Works, which establishment will proceed at once to put in her machinery.The dimensions of the frigate are: Length, 294 feet; breadth of beam, 55 feet; depth of holds, 33 1/2 feet. Her engines will be of the horizontal back-action class, of eight horse power. She is to be iron-clad, the plates for the purpose having been imported from France, and will carry a rifled battery of thirty-two guns. She will be bark-rigged, and is expected to be completed about the 1st of October. Mr. WEBB is also building another frigate for the same Government, intended as a consort to the Re D'Italia, which will be ready for launching in about three months.
lead_paragraph: The frigate Re D'Italia, building by WM.H. WEBB, for the Italian Government, was launched at 9 1/2 A.M. yesterday, from the yard foot of Sixth-street. Her engines will be of the horizontal back-action class, of eight horse power. abstract: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday upon the bodies of ANGELINA PORTLIPPI and JOSEPHINE THOMPSON, the two women who lost their lives on Thursday evening last, by falling through the hatchway of No. 327 Broadway. The jury rendered a verdict that the deceased came to their deaths from an accidental fall.
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday upon the bodies of ANGELINA PORTLIPPI and JOSEPHINE THOMPSON, the two women who lost their lives on Thursday evening last, by falling through the hatchway of No. 327 Broadway. abstract: The Buffalo Express has a curious story to tell about a former Buffalonian, ARNOLD HARRIS, who went to the war as a private in the Twenty-first regiment, and who now holds the rank of Lieutenant in the United States navy. While in the army he led a detachment which surprised the rebel pickets at Matthias Point, on the Rappahannock, and afterward was appointed commander of the Island Belle. The bravery which he displayed in this capacity caused Secretary WELLES to select him to go to Richmond to endeavor to counteract the schemes of GEORGE N. SANDERS, who was then known to have gone to Europe to open negotiations for the construction of a navy for the rebels. The Express says:

abstract: A letter has been received in this city from an officer of the Massachusetts Forty-fourth regiment, dated inside the fort, Washington, N.C., April 10, which announces the death, at 10 o'clock A.M. that day, of Dr. ROBERT WARE, Surgeon of the Forty-fourth. Dr. WARE had been sick of fever for some days previous to his death. The writer expresses confidence in their ability to hold out until reinforcements arrive. The letter confirms thereport that two companies of the Forty-fourth had fallen into an ambuscade. Capt. RICHARDSON was wounded. Two or three of his men were also wounded, and it was found impossible to remove them, and they remained in the hands of the enemy. The rebels were firing at the fort on the 10th, but only two shots took effect inside, and no person had been injured by their firing. The rebels do not appear willing to run any risks, and they keep at a respectable distance from the fort An officer, who arrived at Newbern from Washington on the 11th, having run the blockade, reports that Gen. FOSTER is in good spirits, and confident that he can hold out as long as the rebels can. So far his men are all safe. The expedition which went out under Gen. SPINOLA, some 8,000 strong, to reinforce Gen. FOSTER, had returned. Gen. SPINOLA encountered the rebels in considerable force at Blunt's Creek, nine miles from Washington, and after a slight skirmish faced about and went back to Newbern. In this affair Capt. BELGER, of a Rhode Island battery, and some seventeen of the Seventeenth Massachusetts, were wounded. These were the only casualties on our side. Gen. WESSEL was to start on Sunday morning with his brigade, on the same issue. The Massschusetts Third, Massachusetts Twenty-third and Fifth Rhode Island regiments had been dispatched by steamers, to attempt to run the blockade, and relieve Gen. FOSTER.

abstract: -- In his marvelously impertinent speech before the House of Commons, a few days ago, when the question of the responsibility which should attach to the British Government for allowing the Alabama and kindred craft to be equipped in and dispatched from English ports to prey upon our commerce, was under discussion, Lord PALMERSTON stated that, while the contest in Spain, between the Carlists and Queen ISABELLA was raging, it was his duty, as one of the officers of the Crown, to see that no supplies of arms left England for the revolutionists. Two or three ships were fitting out on the Thames at that time which he was morally certain were intended to go in aid of Don CARLOS. It was found impossible, however, to establish the fact legally, and the Government did not feel itself warranted in seizing them. There Lord PALMERSTON dropped the parallel, claiming that it was complete, and that his case was established. Unless legal proof were lodged with the officers of the Crown that steamers were building to play the part of privateers for the Conrederates, no steps could be taken to arrest their construction or delay their departure from British ports.
lead_paragraph: -- In his marvelously impertinent speech before the House of Commons, a few days ago, when the question of the responsibility which should attach to the British Government for allowing the Alabama and kindred craft to be equipped in and dispatched from English ports to prey upon our commerce, was under discussion, Lord PALMERSTON stated that, while the contest in Spain, between the Carlists and Queen ISABELLA was raging, it was his duty, as one of the officers of the Crown, to see that no supplies of arms left England for the revolutionists. Two or three ships were fitting out on the Thames at that time which he was morally certain were intended to go in aid of Don CARLOS. It was found impossible, however, to establish the fact legally, and the Government did not feel itself warranted in seizing them. There Lord PALMERSTON dropped the parallel, claiming that it was complete, and that his case was established. Unless legal proof were lodged with the officers of the Crown that steamers were building to play the part of privateers for the Conrederates, no steps could be taken to arrest their construction or delay their departure from British ports.

abstract: On Friday evening, a large and enthusiastic meeting of loyal Union people of both sexes, was held at the Bleecker Building, for the purpose of giving expression to views tending to sustain the Government. W.L. ORMSBY, Jr., was the first speaker, and made a very spirited and characteristic address, in the course of which all the prominent political topics of the day were ably and lucidly discussed, and his sentiments heartily indorsed and loudly applauded by the audience. Mr. ORMSBY was followed by ROBERT M. POER, who made a stirring and patriotic speech, which met the hearty approval of every one present. Mr. ANDERSON, of the Union Glee Club, was upon the platform, and during an interval, sung, with fine effect, "The Sword of Bunker Hill."
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, a large and enthusiastic meeting of loyal Union people of both sexes, was held at the Bleecker Building, for the purpose of giving expression to views tending to sustain the Government. Mr. ANDERSON, of the Union Glee Club, was upon the platform, and during an interval, sung, with fine effect, "The Sword of Bunker Hill."

abstract: When the public peace was for a time somewhat disturbed here on Thursday last, it was suggested to us, and to the rest of the city Press, by many citizens, to refrain from any present notice of it, on account of the misrepresentations and exaggerations to which a publication would give rise.
lead_paragraph: When the public peace was for a time somewhat disturbed here on Thursday last, it was suggested to us, and to the rest of the city Press, by many citizens, to refrain from any present notice of it, on account of the misrepresentations and exaggerations to which a publication would give rise. In assenting to the suggestion, in company with all the other papers, we felt that we were only paying a decent respect to the opinions of gentlemen certainly as well qualified to judge as ourselves, equally interested, to say the least, in a correct judgment, and entitled to deference on other grounds.

abstract: The accounts received from Poland are of the most contradictory character. The other day it was announced that the defeat and flight of LANGIEWICZ had given a death blow to the insurrection, and that many of the chiefs were abandoning the cause as hopeless. Now it is reported that the Dictator's disaster and disappearance have had no such effect, and that the warlike conflagration is extending and becoming fiercer. These contradictions may, perhaps, be reconciled. The contest is not carried on by the Poles with great armies, but with numerous guerrilla hordes; and when any of these bands are cut off or scattered by the Russians, then rumor will have it that because the struggle has ceased in a particular district, therefore the insurrection is crushed; while, on the other hand, it is said to be spreading and gathering strength as often as the scene changes and the strife is renewed in a fresh quarter.

abstract: -- We are sorry to observe that our efforts last week to keep from the rebels the information as to the numbers and effective force of HOOKER's army, which was concealed under the shape of a medical report, have been frustrated. The report was published yesterday in the Commercial Advertiser, and came to us also last evening in the Baltimore American and other papers. We are sorry that these two loyal and honest journals should have given the report publication, after our suppression of it, and our warning of its dangerous character; as it conveys information about our army which we have no doubt HOOKER would give ten thousand dollars to obtain about the rebel army. The War Department might as well have sent JEFF. DAVIS a list of all the regiments in the Army of the Potomac, with the number of effective men in each -- to which might have been added the time and line of the campaign about to be opened in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: -- We are sorry to observe that our efforts last week to keep from the rebels the information as to the numbers and effective force of HOOKER's army, which was concealed under the shape of a medical report, have been frustrated. abstract: -- A correspondent of the Chicago Times, writing from above Vicksburgh, says: "An important work has been progressing nightly, for two weeks or more, that I have hitherto forborne mentioning, lest it might be deemed contraband. As others now seem to know as much or more concerning it than myself. I mention it. A powerful battery is being erected on the extreme point of the main levee, opposite the lower part of the city of Vicksburgh, that will be so thoroughly casemated as to defy the rebels; will mount the heaviest Parrott guns in the department, capable of throwing almost all kinds of projectiles; and that will have a range embracing almost every building in the city. With these guns it will be possible to destroy the depot, courthouse, and other public buildings, and to devastate the whole city. All work is done on it at night. It is not desirable to drew the fire of the rebel batteries until all preparations are complete, when an artillery duel worth witness is inevitable. The ram Lancaster, that was sunk by the rebels a week ago, is now said to have been so utterly worthless and rotten that her destruction in this manner is in reality our gain, by preventing a much greater catastrophe in some future action. The public are expected to be duly thankful for this small grain of comfort, and bless their lucky stars it was no worse. The Switzerland's repairs was completed two days ago. FARRAGUT's gunboats have taken her as convoy, and gone down the river to rejoin the fleet at Port Hudson.
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent of the Chicago Times, writing from above Vicksburgh, says: "An important work has been progressing nightly, for two weeks or more, that I have hitherto forborne mentioning, lest it might be deemed contraband. A powerful battery is being erected on the extreme point of the main levee, opposite the lower part of the city of Vicksburgh, that will be so thoroughly casemated as to defy the rebels; will mount the heaviest Parrott guns in the department, capable of throwing almost all kinds of projectiles; and that will have a range embracing almost every building in the city. With these guns it will be possible to destroy the depot, courthouse, and other public buildings, and to devastate the whole city. All work is done on it at night. It is not desirable to drew the fire of the rebel batteries until all preparations are complete, when an artillery duel worth witness is inevitable. The ram Lancaster, that was sunk by the rebels a week ago, is now said to have been so utterly worthless and rotten that her destruction in this manner is in reality our gain, by preventing a much greater catastrophe in some future action. The public are expected to be duly thankful for this small grain of comfort, and bless their lucky stars it was no worse. The Switzerland's repairs was completed two days ago. FARRAGUT's gunboats have taken her as convoy, and gone down the river to rejoin the fleet at Port Hudson.

abstract: of France and England, formidable as they undoubtedly are for an open sea fight, could accomplish much less in an attack on fortifications than our iron-clad Monitors. The frigates are high above water, and for that very reason their iron coating is much thinner than that of our Monitors, since so much surface, coated with ten or twelve inches of iron, would sink the ship. They expose, perhaps, ten times as much perpendicular surface, and that much less protected, while their decks, if I am not mistaken as to their construction, are surrounded by walls like those of other ships.
lead_paragraph: of France and England, formidable as they undoubtedly are for an open sea fight, could accomplish much less in an attack on fortifications than our iron-clad Monitors. abstract: The steamship Marion was wrecked, on the 2d inst., on a sunken rock off Water Cay, and near the Double-head Shot Cay. She was worked off the rock soon after she struck, and was found to leak so badly that the captain was compelled to run her ashore. She had a full cargo and about fifty passengers for New-Orleans.

abstract: We have very little war news this morning. A report was given currency in one of the morning journals yesterday, that a portion of Gen. HOOKER'S army, under Gen. STONEMAN, had driven the rebels out of Culpepper and Gordonsville, and occupied the latter place, but we learn from Washington that there is nothing authentic to sustain such a report.
lead_paragraph: We have very little war news this morning. A report was given currency in one of the morning journals yesterday, that a portion of Gen. HOOKER'S army, under Gen. STONEMAN, had driven the rebels out of Culpepper and Gordonsville, and occupied the latter place, but we learn from Washington that there is nothing authentic to sustain such a report. There is a movement of some kind going on, however, if we are to believe the evidence contained in the following paragraph, copied from the Richmond Dispatch, of the 15th: "It was reported by parties who came down on the Central train last night, that a rumor prevailed at Gordonsville yesterday that a fight was in progress at Kelly's Ford, in Culpepper County. It is not unlike that HOOKER is again endeavoring to throw his forces across the Rappahannock, with a view to a forward movement."

abstract: -- In the Prize Court, yesterday, an interesting question of international law was raised. It grow out of the capture of the brig Josephine, near the mouth of the Mississippi, soon after the taking of New-Orleans. It is alleged that that cargo, consisting of cotton, belonged to a native of France, not at the time a resident of the United State, and that he was not in any respect aiding or assisting those in rebellion against the United States; further, that after the rebellion broke out, and the port of New-Orleans was blockaded, the vessel could not leave; and that, when the United States gunboats were making their way up to the city, the vessel was ordered up some distance above New-Orleans by the authorities there. Supposing that the port would be open when the United States forces took possession of New-Orleans, the Josephine watched an opportunity, and passed through one of the bayous to the mouth of the Mississippi, to await an opportunity to sail. There she was captured, and was sent to this port in charge of a prizemaster. It is now claimed that the vessel and cargo were not liable to seizure and confiscation. The matter was argued by F.C. BREWSTER for the claimant, and by the District-Attorney for the captors. -- Phil. Ledger, April 18.
lead_paragraph: -- In the Prize Court, yesterday, an interesting question of international law was raised. abstract: A few evenings since I had the pleasure of spending an evening with an old personal friend, an influential planter, residing some--miles from New-Orleans. He is one of the noble representatives of what was once the true Southerner. Throughout this rebellion he has from necessity remained silent, but his heart has been with the Union, and his secret aspirations have been that the National Government would speedily crush out this rebellion.
lead_paragraph: NEW-ORLEANS, Thursday, April 2.

abstract: If there is anybody whom a South Carolinian hates more than a Yankee, it is a Georgian; if there is anything he despises more than a free negro, it is a North Carolinian. The Georgians and North Carolinians, moreover, living contiguous to the Palmetto State, the former on the west and the other on the east, the chivalry's detestation and contempt for them is livelier and more personal than for the Yankees, who live a great distance off, and regarding whom your average South Carolinian knows very little. The term a "Georgia Yankee" has long been an epithet of reproach in South Carolina, as applied to the people on the other side of the Savannah River; while they say that if you come by rail from the North, you can tell when you pass from North into South Carolina, even with your eyes shut; -- you can distinguish between the abject gait of a North Carolinian and the proud stride of your genuine son of Chivalry -- between the whining, cowardly accents of the former, and the proud, defiant tone of the latter. The South Carolinians never were willing to be considered a part of this American nation -- they were a nation by themselves. They hold that the world is constituted of two peoples -- South Carolinians and outside barbarians. If this war were over, with the Confederacy triumphant to-morrow, we verily believe that South Carolina would declare war against Georgia and North Carolina before the close of the week.
lead_paragraph: If there is anybody whom a South Carolinian hates more than a Yankee, it is a Georgian; if there is anything he despises more than a free negro, it is a North Carolinian. The Georgians and North Carolinians, moreover, living contiguous to the Palmetto State, the former on the west and the other on the east, the chivalry's detestation and contempt for them is livelier and more personal than for the Yankees, who live a great distance off, and regarding whom your average South Carolinian knows very little. The term a "Georgia Yankee" has long been an epithet of reproach in South Carolina, as applied to the people on the other side of the Savannah River; while they say that if you come by rail from the North, you can tell when you pass from North into South Carolina, even with your eyes shut; -- you can distinguish between the abject gait of a North Carolinian and the proud stride of your genuine son of Chivalry -- between the whining, cowardly accents of the former, and the proud, defiant tone of the latter. The South Carolinians never were willing to be considered a part of this American nation -- they were a nation by themselves. They hold that the world is constituted of two peoples -- South Carolinians and outside barbarians. If this war were over, with the Confederacy triumphant to-morrow, we verily believe that South Carolina would declare war against Georgia and North Carolina before the close of the week.

abstract: THE LAUNCH OF THE ITALIAN FRIGATE RE D'ITALIA. -- The iron-clad frigate Re d'Italia, built by W.H. WEBB for the Italian Government, was launched yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, according to announcement. In order to give their friends and the Italian Captains in the City an opportunity to witness the launch, the well-known house of Messrs. F. BERTHOUD & Co. chartered the Starlight steamtug for their accommodation. An elegant dejeuner was served up on board, and a profusion of champagne, with the music of a brass band, filled up the intervals of the trip, to the complete satisfaction of all concerned.
lead_paragraph: THE LAUNCH OF THE ITALIAN FRIGATE RE D'ITALIA. -- The iron-clad frigate Re d'Italia, built by W.H. abstract: Earl RUSSELL on the seizures of British vessels by our cruisers will attract attention. It is fairer and juster than might have been anticipated. The affair of the Peterhoff is not specially mentioned in it, but it was probably primarily called out by that case, as it is of as late a date as the 3d instant. His positions briefly are, that our Government has no right to seize English vessels sailing bona fide between a British port and Matamoras or Vera Cruz, unless such vessels attempt to touch at some blockaded port, or are carriers of contraband for the rebels. But, the British Government cannot claim for vessels navigating between Great Britain and the ports of Mexico, adjacent to our coast, any general exemption from the belligerent right of visitation by our cruisers. After these negative statements, he affirms that it is the right of the belligerent to capture all vessels reasonably suspected of violating international law, by carrying contraband, or attempting to run the blockade under cover of a lawful voyage; and that the belligerents in this war cannot be denied the exercise of those rights which have always been claimed by England herself. These sentiments we believe to accord with British precedent, as well as with justice and international law; and we are glad to witness their expression at this moment by the Foreign Office.
lead_paragraph: Earl RUSSELL on the seizures of British vessels by our cruisers will attract attention. It is fairer and juster than might have been anticipated. The affair of the Peterhoff is not specially mentioned in it, but it was probably primarily called out by that case, as it is of as late a date as the 3d instant. His positions briefly are, that our Government has no right to seize English vessels sailing bona fide between a British port and Matamoras or Vera Cruz, unless such vessels attempt to touch at some blockaded port, or are carriers of contraband for the rebels. But, the British Government cannot claim for vessels navigating between Great Britain and the ports of Mexico, adjacent to our coast, any general exemption from the belligerent right of visitation by our cruisers. After these negative statements, he affirms that it is the right of the belligerent to capture all vessels reasonably suspected of violating international law, by carrying contraband, or attempting to run the blockade under cover of a lawful voyage; and that the belligerents in this war cannot be denied the exercise of those rights which have always been claimed by England herself. These sentiments we believe to accord with British precedent, as well as with justice and international law; and we are glad to witness their expression at this moment by the Foreign Office.

abstract: We learn, by an arrival at this port, that, on the 4th inst., in the Bahama Channel, the British gunboat Signet was fired into by the United States gunboat Connecticut, under the supposition that she was the Alabama. Explanations subsequently took place, and the affair was amicably adjusted.

abstract: In spite of all the efforts of Confederate journals North and South to conceal the fact, or deprive it of importance, no doubt remains that very serious bread riots have taken place in Richmond and other Southern towns. In these riots the women have been the leaders; and that fact alone proves that absolute hunger must have been the cause of them. Women do not get up street riots, break open provision shops, and pillage bakeries and flour stores from political sympathies, nor from resentment against high prices. When their children are in peril of starvation, they become capable of anything. Nothing short of that extremity can have provoked the demonstrations admitted by the rebel papers to have taken place in Richmond, in Raleigh, in Salisbury and many other Southern towns.
lead_paragraph: In spite of all the efforts of Confederate journals North and South to conceal the fact, or deprive it of importance, no doubt remains that very serious bread riots have taken place in Richmond and other Southern towns. abstract: On Saturday night the sixth season of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society, under the competent management of Mr. LUTHER B. WYMAN, was brought to a successful termination by the giving of the fifth concert of the current season. The house was, as it always is, crowded, the night being fair and the Spring bonnets of every household having ere that time been bought and trimmed and made presentable. The programmes of these concerts are always most entertaining, evincing a thorough familiarity on the part of the writer with the hidden gems of musical composition, combined with a happy appreciation of the popular mood and want.

abstract: To-night is the last of MAX MARETZEK's season of opera at the Academy. Approriately the season closes with a benefit to the new and really admirable tenor whom Mr. MARETZEK has done the New-York public the pleasure of introducing to its notice and consideration. Signor MAZZOLINI has in the short time he has been here earned an enviable reputation -- a reputation which will compete in the memory of opera-goers with that of SALVI and BRIGNOLI. Less cultivated than the one, not so great as the other, he is more dramatic than either, and is withal an artist of great accompliments and pleasant, unassuming demeanor. In his honor the vast extent of the Academy ought to and will be crowded. The entertainment for the occasion is Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera," in which the principal parts will be sustained by MAZZOLINI himself, Madame GUERRABELLA, Mlle. BRIGNOLI, Mlle. SULZER and Signori BELLINI and COLLETTI, MAX MARETZEK will conduct in person. After "Il Ballo," MAZZOLINI will sing in costume the grand scena composed expressly for him by PASANI, and called "The Garibaldian." This patriotic effort must unquestionably call forth the wildest demonstrations of enthusiasm.

abstract: Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ, with an energy only surpassed by the gravity of the undertaking, has attempted a second season of German opera in the City of Churches. The works given were BEETHOVEN's grand "Fidelio," FLOTOW's charming "Martha," and "Der Freischutz." The casts included the well-known names of Mme. JOHANNSEN and Mme. VON BERKEL, and Messrs. QUINT, WEINLICH, GRAEFF and HART, with an efficient and well-trained orchestra, and a chorus composed of excellent singers, members of the Liederkranz and other musical organizations, the whole being under the able conduction of Mr. AHSCHUTZ, and the low price of fifty cents charged for admission. The "Fidelio" had a good-sized corporal's guard, the "Martha" not so many, and "Der Freischutz," probably on account of the red devils, the blue goblins and the fireworks, a somewhat better house than either of its predecessors. Consequently, the manager closed the week with a heavy balance against him; the artists are in the dumps, from obvious causes, and the long list of operatic failures is increased by one. By good rights, the people of Brooklyn should henceforward be tabooed by honest managers, and be visited only by the charlatans who, from time to time, treat them with mutilated operas, second rate singers and double prices; but Mr. ANSCHUTZ, whose soul, thank heaven, is above his pocket, proposes to give them another chance to encourage honest merit and faithful service. To-night "Fra Diavolo," Wednesday "The Merry Wives of Windsor," and on Friday "Joseph and His Brethren," will be given with the same artists, the same strong chorus, the same grand orchestra, and at the same low prices, a fine ballet troupe being thrown in gratis. We trust the people of Brooklyn, than whom no one is more familiar with works of merit, and before whom no humbug can without detection appear, will evince by a generous patronage their appreciation of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's fidelity, enterprise and generosity -- for that he is faithful his works prove, that he is enterprising his renewal of what has thus far proven a disaster affirms, and that he is generous his disposition to overlook the repeated slights imposed upon him by the most intelligent of people certainly establishes. If with the attractions presented by the manager in this instance do not succeed in arousing a spirit of enthusiasm in Brooklyn operatic and musical circles, we shall be greatly disappointed, and that city will forever more be given up.
lead_paragraph: Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ, with an energy only surpassed by the gravity of the undertaking, has attempted a second season of German opera in the City of Churches. The "Fidelio" had a good-sized corporal's guard, the "Martha" not so many, and "Der Freischutz," probably on account of the red devils, the blue goblins and the fireworks, a somewhat better house than either of its predecessors. Consequently, the manager closed the week with a heavy balance against him; the artists are in the dumps, from obvious causes, and the long list of operatic failures is increased by one. By good rights, the people of Brooklyn should henceforward be tabooed by honest managers, and be visited only by the charlatans who, from time to time, treat them with mutilated operas, second rate singers and double prices; but Mr. ANSCHUTZ, whose soul, thank heaven, is above his pocket, proposes to give them another chance to encourage honest merit and faithful service. To-night "Fra Diavolo," Wednesday "The Merry Wives of Windsor," and on Friday "Joseph and His Brethren," will be given with the same artists, the same strong chorus, the same grand orchestra, and at the same low prices, a fine ballet troupe being thrown in gratis. We trust the people of Brooklyn, than whom no one is more familiar with works of merit, and before whom no humbug can without detection appear, will evince by a generous patronage their appreciation of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's fidelity, enterprise and generosity -- for that he is faithful his works prove, that he is enterprising his renewal of what has thus far proven a disaster affirms, and that he is generous his disposition to overlook the repeated slights imposed upon him by the most intelligent of people certainly establishes. If with the attractions presented by the manager in this instance do not succeed in arousing a spirit of enthusiasm in Brooklyn operatic and musical circles, we shall be greatly disappointed, and that city will forever more be given up.

abstract: On Saturday forenoon Mr. WEBB launched from his yard, foot of Sixth-street, the wooden frigate Re d'Italia, which is to be clad with iron. Over 10,000 persons lined the New-York and Williamsburgh shores, while the immediate vicinity of the ship-yard was studded with some of our most distinguished citizens, among whom we noticed the Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Mr. FOX, the Italian Minister and Consul, Signors BERLENATTI and ANFERA, some members of the Italian Opera troupe, the British and French Consuls, Capt. BLAKE of the Hatteras, and several foreign officers. The Italian consignee, to whom vessels of that nation are consigned, chartered the steamboat Starlight, on board of which all the Italian Captains in town were invited. Dodworth's and another band were present, and performed the old Sardinian hymn, but Maestro VERDI's "New Italy March" was not heard. The launch was most successful, the vessel going clear to the Williamsburgh shore. The utmost enthusiasm was manifested by all present. Miss COGGSWELL christened the vessel.

abstract: publish in another column a letter from Gen. CORCORAN, explaining the circumstances under which Lieut.-Col. KIMBALL, of the Ninth New-York Regiment, met his death. It seems from this statement that Col. K. was not in the discharge of any official duty when he demanded the countersign of Gen. C., and that he refused, with great excitement and insolence of manner, to make any explanation or give any information as to the reason of his demand. We take it for granted the whole matter will receive inquiry at the hands of a military court. This is demanded alike by the importance of the case and by the state of public feeling in regard to it.

abstract: Everything indicates a magnificent response to the call for the grand mass-meeting this afternoon, in commemoration of the first great stand made by the people against the rebellion. Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT identified far...
lead_paragraph: Everything indicates a magnificent response to the call for the grand mass-meeting this afternoon, in commemoration of the first great stand made by the people against the rebellion. Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT -- identified far beyond any other man living with the glory of American history -- will preside, as the very embodiment of the ruling spirit of the hour. The occasion will be a new attestation to the Confederacy and to the whole civilized world that the Republic shall live.

abstract: It seems to be the general belief that the attack upon Charleston will not be at once renewed. We trust this expectation will prove to be well-founded. We have more than once pointed out in these columns that nothing would be gained, in a military point of view, by the capture of Charleston, beyond the complete closing of the port to Confederate supplies. Even if our iron-clads had destroyed or silenced all the forts and batteries, and bombarded the town into submission, the great and grave fact of the war, the presence in the field of at least three large rebel armies, well organized, well disciplined, and full of fight, would still remain to be disposed of.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. A dramatization of the last sensation novel Aurora Floyd was produced at this theatre, last evening. It was not Miss Braddon's "Aurora Floyd," but as an original creation of the actress, it was vividly conceived and admirably represented. The character...
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- A dramatization of the last sensation novel -- Aurora Floyd -- was produced at this theatre, last evening. MATILDA HERON portrayed the part of the heroine in a highly effective manner. It was not Miss Braddon's "Aurora Floyd," but as an original creation of the actress, it was vividly conceived and admirably represented. The character for which Mr. SHEWELL was cast -- John Mellish, the Yorkshire squire -- was, in consequence of his sickness, given to Mr. HARRY PEARSON, who played it very finely, and Mr. GEORGE JAMIESON gave a graphic and powerful sketch of Stephen Hargreaves, the "lofty." The piece is terribly too long. Human endurance has its limits, and they do not extend beyond 11 o'clock. When the curtain falls at nearly 12, it is almost superfluous to suggest to a manager a liberal application of the scissors.

abstract: The news from which Eastern Virginia is important. A dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated yesterday, states that heavy firing and been going on for twenty-our hours on the Nansemond River, occasioned by our gunboats shelling the rebels who were attempting to plant batteries at various points to command the river. On Saturday night...
lead_paragraph: The news from which Eastern Virginia is important. A dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated yesterday, states that heavy firing and been going on for twenty-our hours on the Nansemond River, occasioned by our gunboats shelling the rebels who were attempting to plant batteries at various points to command the river. On Saturday night a gallant affair occured. The Eighty-ninth New-York and the Eighth Connecticut regiments, aided by the gunboats, captured a rebel battery of six pieces, together with two hundred and fifty prisoners, belonging to the Forty-fourth Alabama regiment. Gen. DIX and Staff are now at Suffolk, having left Fortress Monroe on Saturday morning.

abstract: When the mass meetings around the square had been adjourned, the delegates to the Union meeting, by invitation of the League, were entertained and welcomed at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The Chair was occupied by CHARLES GOULD, Esq., and Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON made the welcoming address. Responses were made by Gen. HARRINGTON, for Delaware; Mayor CHAPMAN, of Baltimore, for Maryland; and Mr. USHER, for Pennsylvania. Among the prominent men of this City present were Mayor OPDYKE, Judges BONNEY and WHITE, WAIDO HUTCHINS, ETHAN ALLEN, JONATHAN STURGES, and many others. The entertainment, which was excellent, detained the company until a late hour in the evening.

abstract: If immense numbers, irrepressible enthusiasm and eloquent oratory ever gave impressiveness and complete success to any public demonstration, it was realized at Madison-square yesterday. As an expression of patriotic spirit and purpose, it was all that the most sanguine could hope or the most distrustful desire. We were about to term the demonstration a new uprising, but that would hardly be right; for, since the first, there has been no actual sinking. This is, rather, a new emerging from the clouds, and the loyalty of the people again beams out as resplendent as ever. It is a glorious inauguration of the third year of the war. It demonstrates what no man of clear insight ever doubted -- that the heart of the people, however overshadowed by disappointments, and disturbed by the arts of faction, still remains essentially staunch and true. Even those who have had the most misgiving ought now to take fresh assurance that the cause of the Republic is safe beyond all contingency; for it is certain that, under a gracious Providence, so long as the spirit of the mighty North thus continues unextinguished, the old flag is sure of final triumph.

abstract: known until recently was the famous Boston "mob of gentlemen," costumed in broadcloth, with stovepipes on their heads, pumps on their feet, and white kids on their hands. But they have done better than this in Georgia. The Atlanta Intelligencer describes the recent riot in that city for procuring food as being gotten up and put through by ladies. "A number of ladies," it is said, "were seen perambulating our streets until they came up to a provision store," which they entered, preceded by a "tall lady, on whose countenance rested care and determination." She demanded the price of bacon, and being told it was $1 10 per pound, she remonstrated; but the shopkeeper remained inexorable, when the "tall lady" drew a long navy repeater, and the rest of them plundered the store, "giving preference to the bacon." The editor says that the "scene moved the sympathies of his soul," and that a number of gentlemen, "feeling a deep sympathy for these ladies," raised a small sum of money for them.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Conference Committee on the Harbor Defence bill made a report agreeing to the appropriation of a million dollars for the New-York harbor and frontier defences, to be under the direction of the Governor, the Comptroller, and United States Senator MORGAN. The Conference Committee on the Canal bill also made a report, which is against the proposition to enlarge the locks west of Montezuma this year. The bill making an appropriation for the purchase of arms was ordered to a third reading. Resolutions directing a survey of the canal locks, with a view to the reenlargement, were adopted. A number of bills were passed, among them the Annual Supply bill as agreed upon by the Committee of Conference.

The bill making an appropriation for the purchase of arms was ordered to a third reading. Resolutions directing a survey of the canal locks, with a view to the reenlargement, were adopted. A number of bills were passed, among them the Annual Supply bill as agreed upon by the Committee of Conference.

abstract: We are not surprised to learn that the Confederate Loan, lately negotiated in Europe with so much eelat, is already limping on the Exchanges, and is regarded as the lightest of fancy stocks. From a premium of 5 per cent....
lead_paragraph: We are not surprised to learn that the Confederate Loan, lately negotiated in Europe with so much eelat, is already limping on the Exchanges, and is regarded as the lightest of fancy stocks. From a premium of 5 per cent., at the closing of the books, it has fallen in a few days to 2 per cent. below par, and is reported dull and declining. It went up like a rocket and must come down like a stick.

abstract: years has proved so prolific in canards as the French invasion of Mexico. Times without number, we have been called upon to contradict the most absurd stories about the progress of French arms in the neighboring republic, put forth with all gravity of style and particularity of detail. Three or four times recently we have had reports positively asserting the capture of the cities of Puebla and Mexico by the French army. These reports originate, it appears, with the French Consuls stationed at Mobile and San Francisco; and so methodically and periodically do they come from these quarters, that we are disposed to believe interested parties have a special purpose in deceiving the American and European public.
lead_paragraph: years has proved so prolific in canards as the French invasion of Mexico. abstract: The funeral of the late Lieut.-Col. E.A. KIMBALL, of the Ninth regiment, HAWKINS' Zouaves, will take place at 3 o'clock P.M., to-day. An imposing civil and military procession (see advertisement) will escort the remains to their last resting place. The procession will start from the City Hall Park at 3 P.M., passing through Chatham-street and the Bowery to Bond-street, through Bond to Broadway, and down Broadway to the South Ferry. The remains lay in state at the Governor's Room, City Hall, yesterday, under guard of a detachment from the Sixty-ninth regiment, and were visited by a large number of citizens and friends of the brave and lamented officer.

abstract: The news from Vicksburgh this morning is highly important. On the night of Thursday, the 16th instant, five gunboats and three transports  ran past the rebel batteries, carrying down a large number of Gen. GRANT'S troops, who are thus placed in a position either to cooperate with...
lead_paragraph: The news from Vicksburgh this morning is highly important. On the night of Thursday, the 16th instant, five gunboats and three transports ran past the rebel batteries, carrying down a large number of Gen. GRANT'S troops, who are thus placed in a position either to cooperate with Gen. BANKS in the reduction of Port Hudson, or to attack Vicksburgh from below, as may be required. The gunboats were the Benton, the Tuscumbia, the Lafayette, the Pittsburgh, the Carondelet, and the Gen. Price. All got safely by with the exception of one transport, which caught fire opposite the batteries, and was destroyed. We do not hear, however, that any lives were lost in consequence. The only gunboat hit was the Benton, which had one man killed and two wounded.

abstract: The feeling of disappointment that has, for some time, existed over the supposed failure of our army and gunboats before Vicksburgh, was suddenly removed yesterday by the news from the Southwest.  We publish an extraordinary piece of news relating to the war in Mexico. The United States transport George Washington, which arrived at this port, yesterday, from NewOrleans, brings us papers from that city, ...
lead_paragraph: The feeling of disappointment that has, for some time, existed over the supposed failure of our army and gunboats before Vicksburgh, was suddenly removed yesterday by the news from the Southwest. It is announced that on the night of Thursday last, the gunboats Tuscumbia, Lafayette, Benton, Pittsburgh, Carondelet and Gen. Price, with three transports, ran the rebel batteries at Vicksburgh, and all went out safely below except one transport, which was burned.

abstract: QUESTION. -- The Common Council, at the session of last evening, took action that will effectually squelch the Broadway Railroad schemes that are being engineered through the Legislature at Albany. Both houses, by a vote of ten in the Aldermen, and fifteen in the Councilmen, adopted a resolution permitting the Harlem Railroad Company to extend their track from Union-square down Broadway to the South and Fulton Ferries; and this has been done, not in pursuance of any scheme of fraud, such as that pending before the Legislature, but under regulations and provisions securing an uninterrupted flow of revenue into the treasury of the City for the relief from taxation of our already over-burdened citizens.
lead_paragraph: QUESTION. -- The Common Council, at the session of last evening, took action that will effectually squelch the Broadway Railroad schemes that are being engineered through the Legislature at Albany. abstract: of Mississippi is in a very bad plight at present. We have news, this morning, by way of New-Orleans, from the extreme southern part of the State -- by way of Memphis from the extreme northern part of the State, and also from Vicksburgh and the river boundary on the West. White men are operating against her in the North, black men in the South, and iron-clad and cotton-clad gunboats in the West. Our gallant white troops, our gallant black troops, and our gallant gunboats, all report victories in their respective spheres. Our white troops near Corinth have attacked the rebels, and after a very brisk fight have driven them "from Bear Creek to Crane Creek;" and as Bear Creek forms in that region the dividing line between the States of Alabama and Mississippi, we may suppose that the rebels have been driven clear out of that part of the State. Our black troops at the other end of Mississippi landed at Pascagoula, hoisted the Union flag, whipped a batch of JEFF. DAVIS' men, took a set of colors as a trophy, and, then learning that an immense lot of rebels were coming against them, like sensible and well-disciplined blacks, got aboard the steamer, and returned to the place from whence they came. The western line of the State, however, is worse off than either its northern or southern.. Half-a-dozen powerful gunboats have run the Vicksburgh batteries, and formed a junction with FARRAGUT's men-of-war and ELLETT's ram; and they now ride the river, ready to level their guns at any Mississippi rebel who shows his head.

abstract: this morning, from Vicksburgh, Corinth, New-Orleans, Suffolk and Little Washington, show that things are again rather lively. The rebels have completely failed at both of the points at which, they assumed the offensive -- at Suffolk and Little Washington while success has crowned each of our offensive efforts. All fears for our garrisons in North Carolina may now be dismissed. After besieging the small garrison at Little Washington for nearly a fortnight with a large force, they have given the job up, have abandoned all their batteries, and retreated. It may be that they heard of the forces coming against them from South Carolina, and it may be that our demonstrations on the Rappahannock have warned them to suddenly concentrate all their forces there.

abstract: COBURN, of Maine, accompanied by Hon. CHARLES HOLDEN, of Portland, Me., of the Executive Council, and Mrs. MOODY, of Saco, Me., (the latter of-whom has been ten months in the army hospital at the seat of war,) visited the Maine soldiers to-day at Fort Schuyler and David's Island. abstract: We are glad to see some indication of decided progress on the part of the British Government toward an honest observance of its neutrality obligations in respect to rebel privateering. A year ago last February, the...
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see some indication of decided progress on the part of the British Government toward an honest observance of its neutrality obligations in respect to rebel privateering. A year ago last February, the Florida was launched, pierced for six guns and provided with magazines, was manned with a crew of Englishmen with hardly an exception, took on board a cargo of one hundred and seventy-three tons of arms, and notwithstanding the perfect notoriety that she was to engage in privateering business, she was allowed to sail without the slightest hindrance; and all the answer the remonstrances of Mr. ADAMS could elicit from Earl RUSSELL was "a polite expression of regret." Four months afterward the Alabama was in like manner launched; her whole manner of construction and peculiar adaptation to war purposes, as well as the notorious fact that the whole direction of her building and outfit, and shipping of the crew, were in the hands of the agents of the rebel Government, showed conclusively that she was intended to prey upon the commerce of the United States; the remonstrances of Mr. ADAMS in this case only led in about a month to a shain attempt to stop her, when it was too late. Now, after an interval of eight months, the little propeller Alexandra, with no gunports at all, or any of the visible appurtenances of a man-of-war, presenting simply the appearance of a schooner-rigged steam-yacht, is no sooner launched than she is seized by order from the Foreign Office. No men had been shipped for her, no arms had been taken on board, and not even her engines had been set. So far as we can judge, the evidence against her was not a fiftieth part so palpable as that in either of the other two cases, and yet Earl RUSSELL hurries his officials, post haste, to put the "broad arrow" on her mast.

abstract: Public sentiment is unanimous and emphatic in approbation of the action of the Common Council on the subject of a railroad in Broadway. Under other circumstances the feeling would probably be different.
lead_paragraph: Public sentiment is unanimous and emphatic in approbation of the action of the Common Council on the subject of a railroad in Broadway. Under other circumstances the feeling would probably be different. But whatever may be the wishes of individuals, the public understand perfectly that we are to have a railroad in Broadway. The Legislature will not adjourn until the right to build one has been conferred upon GEORGE LAW and his associates. The large majorities for the measure in both Houses render it certain that the friends of the bill have the power to pass it over the Governor's head -- even if he should veto it, which he is not likely to do: and it is well understood at Albany that while they may take a recess, they will not adjourn until the success of this measure is put beyond a doubt.
