abstract: telegram from Washington, yesterday morning, told us that the question of the prize steamer Pettrhoff had been brought up at a Cabinet meeting, and that it was understood that the result was a determination to leave the matter of the vessel and her mails to be determined by the Court. The report of the proceedings in the case, yesterday, in the District Court, here, told a somewhat different story. The District-Attorney, on behalf of the Government and under instructions from the State Department, and from the President himself, moved the Court for an order directing the mail found on board to be delivered to the British Consul unopened, to be by him forwarded to Matamoras, whither it purported to be destined. The motion was opposed by the counsel for the naval captors, but the Court, after due consideration, held that the District-Attorney had the control of the suit, and could withhold any evidence which he saw fit. Accordingly, the mail was delivered up to the British Consul unopened.
lead_paragraph: telegram from Washington, yesterday morning, told us that the question of the prize steamer Pettrhoff had been brought up at a Cabinet meeting, and that it was understood that the result was a determination to leave the matter of the vessel and her mails to be determined by the Court. The report of the proceedings in the case, yesterday, in the District Court, here, told a somewhat different story. The District-Attorney, on behalf of the Government and under instructions from the State Department, and from the President himself, moved the Court for an order directing the mail found on board to be delivered to the British Consul unopened, to be by him forwarded to Matamoras, whither it purported to be destined. The motion was opposed by the counsel for the naval captors, but the Court, after due consideration, held that the District-Attorney had the control of the suit, and could withhold any evidence which he saw fit. Accordingly, the mail was delivered up to the British Consul unopened.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the education and came of indigent deaf mutes was reported favorably, ordered to a third reading and passed. The bill increasing the compensation of Commissioners of Jurors in Kings County was ordered to a third reading, and subsequently passed. The Assembly amendments to the Militia bill were concurred in. The bill amending the Excise law was lost, and a motion to reconsider was tabled. The New-York Building and Lien act was passed; also, the amended Tax bill; also, the Mott Haven and Fourth-street Ferry bill. The Staten Island Ferry bill was ordered to a third reading. During the afternoon session. Mr. GANSON's concurrent resolutions proposing amendments to the Constitution, allowing soldiers to vote, were tabled. Nothing of importance was done in the evening session.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill for the education and came of indigent deaf mutes was reported favorably, ordered to a third reading and passed. During the afternoon session. Mr. GANSON's concurrent resolutions proposing amendments to the Constitution, allowing soldiers to vote, were tabled. Nothing of importance was done in the evening session.

abstract: An Imperial manifesto has been issued granting a full and entire amnesty to all the Poles in the Kingdom and the Western Provinces who lay down their arms and return to their allegiance by the 13th of May, ordinary crimes and military offences excepted.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURGH, Sunday, April 12.

abstract: The steamship Persia arrived at this port, yesterday, with advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 11th, and Queenstown on the 12th inst. The news is interesting. The steamer Jopan, alias the Virginia, which recently escaped from Greenock, in England, had been spoken off the French coast by a vessel, which took from on board her seventeen men, two of whom had been wounded by an explosion in her machinery. The new pirate proceeded to sea on the 9th, having received a large supply of arms and ammunition. The English Government has been catechised in the House of Lords regarding the gunboats being built for the "Emperor of China." The Liverpool Chamber of Commerce had called upon the Government to make the Foreign Enlistment act more stringent. All work had been suspended upon the seized steamer Alexandra, by order of the Government, until an investigation of her case could be had. It was asserted that the Messrs. LAIRD, of Birkenhead, had been interrogated by the Government relative to the gunboats said to be building by them for the rebels and that they gave formal assurances that they were for the Emperor of China. It was also reported that Government officials were making inquiries in Liverpool relative to the Alabama. England, France and Austria sent simultaneous dispatches to Russia on the 10th, regarding the Polish question, which are understood to be couched in friendly terms; but which, at the same time, convey a warning. Meantime, we have accounts of the continued spread of the revolutionary movement, and the latest dispatch [???] Queenstown brings the announcement from St. Petersburgh of an Imperial manifesto graving amnesty to all Poles who lay down their arms and return to their allegiance by the 13th of May, with the promise of refoms in the administration of the Government. The Liverpool Cotton market had ssuffered a slight decline. Breadstuffs and Provisions were tending downward. Consols 92 3/8 a. 2 1/4 for money.

abstract: The report of which I made mention in my last, that Gen. COMONFORT had suffered a defeat at the hands of the French, is repeated. The French war steamer Berthelot, which arrived here from Vera Cruz on the 12th inst., brings the news that Gen. COMONFORT was marching toward Puebla to assist Gen. ORTRGA, when he was defeated by the French Gen. BERTHIER.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA, Saturday, April 18, 1863.

abstract: By the arrival at this port late last night of the steamship Eagle, from Havana on the 18th inst., we have advices from Mexico to the 12th, by a French steamer from Vera Cruz. The news from Puebla is very different from that given by us yesterday, by way of Matamoras. According to this French accounts, COMONFORT, in an attempt to join ORTEGA in Puebla, had been defeated, with considerable loss; and ORTEGA had attempted a sally in the direction of the Capital, but had been driven back. ORTEGA is also said to have offered to capitulate, which offer was refused by the French commander, who insisted upon an unconditional surrender. One curious item of the news is that in answer to the prayer of a deputation of women that he would not bombard the city, FOREY had promised not to do so, he having sufficient appliances to compel the garrison to surrender. In this connection we may mention a significant rumor which prevailed in Havana, that FOREY had suffered a defeat. The Havana news by the Eagle is without special interest.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port late last night of the steamship Eagle, from Havana on the 18th inst., we have advices from Mexico to the 12th, by a French steamer from Vera Cruz. abstract: In the Senate yesterday, among the bills passed was the one incorporating the Hudson and Harlem River Canal Company, and all the canal claims and canal bridges bills. The Assembly's amends to the New-York Tax bill were non-concurred in, and a Committee of Conference was appointed. Lieut.-Gov. JONES received a unanimous vote of thanks for the satisfactory manner in which he had presided over the Senate. The amendments to the Code bill, made by the Assembly, were concurred in. The bill extending certain streets in New-York was ordered to a third reading. In the evening, all the Assembly's amendments to the Broadway Railroad bill, with one exception, were concurred in. The Cross-Town Railroad bill was ordered to a third reading. The resolutions proposing amendments to the Constitution allowing soldiers to vote, were reported unfavorably.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, among the bills passed was the one incorporating the Hudson and Harlem River Canal Company, and all the canal claims and canal bridges bills. abstract: In March last a family, consisting of father, mother and ten children, arrived in this City from England. They had a few dollars left on their arrival, which were soon expended. They purchased two old chairs, two stools, a table, stove and a few other things absolutely needful, and rented the attic of one of our tenement houses. The mother was soon taken with inflammatory rheumatism, and to-day lies on an old bunk, helpless. The place is infested with vermin, and the rats crawl into the children's beds at night and gnaw them! The father has enlisted, but has not yet received any pay and probably will not for some time to come. Every penny was expended some days since, and now they are entirely dependent on charity. They have known better days and are respectably connected; are Protestants, and possess a copy of the bible presented to them by their minister prior to leaving for this country.
lead_paragraph: In March last a family, consisting of father, mother and ten children, arrived in this City from England. They had a few dollars left on their arrival, which were soon expended. abstract: A cold, cheerless rain commenced falling this morning, and our tickle, treacherous Virginia roads are again almost impassable. So we add forty-eight hours more to our suspense. But two such storms within a week are no more than we had on the Peninsula a year ago, and after we are once well started, we shall take such things as they come. But let us get started.

abstract: -- A man named MORRIS SHAY, residing in South Seventh-street, Jersey City, died yesterday morning under circumstances which lead to the supposition that he has been foully dealt with. About 12 o'clock on Tuesday night deceased was found by officer SNOW lying in Newark-avenue in a stupid condition, with blood flowing from a wound in his head, a gash on one cheek, his nose bruised, one eye entirely closed, and the other partially so. He was conveyed to the Station-house, and an attempt was made to raise him, and upon being questioned, the only remark he made was: "I did not deserve it." Under the supposition that he was intoxicated, he was placed in one of the cells, and on Wednesday morning, being found in the same condition, he was removed to an upper room, and a physician was called in, but there being no change, he was finally sent home, and died yesterday morning. It was ascertained that deceased had attended a wake on Tuesday night. Coroner FARREL will hold an inquest to-day.
lead_paragraph: -- A man named MORRIS SHAY, residing in South Seventh-street, Jersey City, died yesterday morning under circumstances which lead to the supposition that he has been foully dealt with. abstract: There appears to be a good deal of misapprehension prevalent amongst our cotemporaries as to the legal ground taken by the British with regard to the fitting out of Southern cruisers in their ports. It is constantly taken for granted in what is written on the subject on this side of the water, that they admit their Government to be bound by international law to prevent the building and arming of ships for the use of belligerents, in a quarrel to which England is not a party, and that, consequently, their failure to arrest the Florida and Alabama were open breaches of solemn obligations to the United States, for which they are fairly liable in damages.

abstract: TRIAL OF IGNATZ RADSKY FOR THE MURDER OF SIGISMUND FELLNER. -- Several witnesses were examined yesterday, and the case for the prosecution was closed, no evidence having been brought forward to show that the deed was committed within the limits of Kings County. The defence intimated that they had no evidence to offer -- depending, mainly, upon the weakness of the testimony for the prosecution. The case will, therefore, be summed up to-day and given to the Jury.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, committed from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: William Birdsall vs. Salem T. Russell. -- This action was brought to recover two bonds, of $1,000 each, alleged to have been stolen. On Friday, the 2d day of November, 1860, the plaintiff, as alleged, sent a tin box to the Fulton Bank, and left it in care of the parties at the bank counter. On Monday, the 5th of November, the box could not be found at the bank, and was never heard of afterward. The box contained five bonds of the Cleveland, Norwalk and Toledo Railroad, payable to bearer, two of which are the subject of this suit. The plaintiff immediately, as alleged, advertised the loss in various newspapers in this City and other places, and distributed handbills among the brokers of the City, notifying them of such loss. He also notified the agent who paid the coupons, directing him not to pay those belonging to the missing bonds. After the payment of the next coupons in February, 1861, it was discovered that although none had been received of the numbers stolen, yet there had been paid five duplicate coupons of other numbers. The supposed stolen bonds, were then found in possession of the defendant, with an alleged change of the numbers, which were written in red ink. A newspaper containing the notice of the lose was found to have been taken by the broker who bought them. This cause had once been submitted to a jury, which disagreed. Upon the present trial the Court declined to submit it to the jury, but dismissed the complaint after the plaintiff had rested his case.
lead_paragraph: William Birdsall vs. Salem T. Russell. -- This action was brought to recover two bonds, of $1,000 each, alleged to have been stolen. On Friday, the 2d day of November, 1860, the plaintiff, as alleged, sent a tin box to the Fulton Bank, and left it in care of the parties at the bank counter. On Monday, the 5th of November, the box could not be found at the bank, and was never heard of afterward. The box contained five bonds of the Cleveland, Norwalk and Toledo Railroad, payable to bearer, two of which are the subject of this suit. The plaintiff immediately, as alleged, advertised the loss in various newspapers in this City and other places, and distributed handbills among the brokers of the City, notifying them of such loss. He also notified the agent who paid the coupons, directing him not to pay those belonging to the missing bonds. After the payment of the next coupons in February, 1861, it was discovered that although none had been received of the numbers stolen, yet there had been paid five duplicate coupons of other numbers. The supposed stolen bonds, were then found in possession of the defendant, with an alleged change of the numbers, which were written in red ink. A newspaper containing the notice of the lose was found to have been taken by the broker who bought them. This cause had once been submitted to a jury, which disagreed. Upon the present trial the Court declined to submit it to the jury, but dismissed the complaint after the plaintiff had rested his case.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Mayor OPDYKE signed the resolutions, adopted by the Common Council Tuesday night, authorizing the Harlem Railroad Company to extend their track through Broadway to the foot of Whitehall-street. It will be remembered that the subject caused quite a lively state of affairs in the Chambers of the Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen on the night of its discussion, and that many attempts were made by a Deputy Sheriff to serve injunctions on members to impede the progress of proceedings. The injunction order, as originally made out by Judge HILTON, was further modified by him yesterday so as to permit the Mayor to sign the paper. The order restraining the Clerk of the Common Council from taking any action in connection with the matter, is still in full force. But as the duty of the Clerk is merely clerical, it is presumed there can be no question as to the validity of the grant.

abstract: The theatrical world and the play-going public generally were startled by the announcement in yesterday's papers of the death of Mr. BLAKE, the comedian. Last week, on Thursday, he took his farewell benefit at Laura Keene's Theatre, announcing that it was not to be final farewell, but only a temporary good-bye, till his return from a series of representations with a traveling company. The company to which he referred opened in Boston on Monday, and Mr. BLAKE on Tuesday played the part of Sir Peter Teazle, in "The School for Scandal." On Wednesday he was seized with an attack " of bilious colic, which shortly resulted in his denth. Mr. BLAKE was not far from 58 years of age. He was born in Halifax. N.S. His first appearance in New-York was made at the old Chatham Theatre in 1824; he was afterward stage-manager of the Tremont Theatre in Boston, of the Walnut-street Theatre in Philadelphia, and of the Broadway Theatre in this City. For a long time he was connected with Mr. WALLACK's Theatre, but at the time of leaving New-York he was a member of the Laura Keene Company. In early life Mr. BLAKE was what is techically called a "light" comedian. In person, he was then finely formed and his face was singularly handsome. He is said to have excelled in such parts as Hurry Dornton in "The Road to Ruin," and Captain Absolute in "The Rivals." He became extremely corpulent, however, as he increased in years, and wisely changing his line of business while yet in the full enjoying of his best powers, he gained a reputation as an exponent of "serious and comic old men," which has never been surpassed upon any stage where the English language is spoken. He was the most spontaneous and natural that the present generation has ever seen, and his pathos was singularly dignified and tree from effort. It may truly be said, without derogating from the undoubted abilities of several living actors, that it will be impossible to fill the void his death has caused. There is no performer of matured powers, or in process of development, who, in a wide range of characters, can be expected to approach him in originality and finished excellence.

abstract: In deference to the suggestions of Mr. BREWER, the Permanent Secretary of the Loyal Paper-Makers' Association, we deferred the publication of the doings of the aforementioned Association until now. abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Miss LUCILLE WESTERN has been creating something very like a sensation by her bold and spirited performance of the three-fold character of The French Spy, in the drama of that name. She looks the character amazingly well, and plays it with a dash and vigor that have rarely, if ever, been equalled. This evening, for her farewell benefit, she essays a part which will still more tryingly task her versatile powers as an actress. She will appear as Don Caear de Bazan, and there can be little doubt she will do it with immense effect.

abstract: The special significance of the stupendous demonstration on Monday was in its ratification by the people of the pledge of the Loyal Leagues to sink all party spirit and all party questions. This pledge is a practical one; and it will be worthless unless it has practical effect. Every loyal man should see well to it, that he makes it good both in word and act. To that end he must studiously cultivate liberality of judgment.

abstract: GRAND DIVISION SONS OF TEMPERANCE -- QUARTERLY MEETING. -- The quarterly meeting of the Grand Division of Eastern New-York Sons of Temperance, was held at the hall, No. 187 Bowery, Monday, closing last evening -- N.G. PARIS, G.W.P., presiding, assisted by WM.J. SPENCE, G.W.A., and JOHN DAVINS, G.S. A large delegation of members were present. Reports were received from a large number of subordinate Divisions, showing the condition of the Order within the jurisdiction of the Grand Division, considering the present excitement of the public mind, occasioned by the war, to be much more favorable than had been anticipated. Delegates from other States were present and rendered favorable accounts of the progress of the Order in their respective States -- particularly so was that the case in Massachusetts, as reported by P.G.W.A. HENSHAW. From the report of the G. Scribe, it appeared that the total number of Divisions represented was 30; number of members in 22 Divisions, 1,263; receipts for initiations, (fees, and dues, $1,393 39; paid for benefits by 13 Divisions, $858 31; cash on hand, invested, &c., in 19 Divisions, $10,913 76; new members admitted in 21 Divisions, 118; number of ladies admitted in 19 Divisions, 103; total number of ladies in 19 Divisions, 1,322; number of boys organized in temperance associations during quarter, 587.

abstract: Milton Bradley vs. Chas. F. Taylor. -- The plaintiff in this action alleged that in December, 1861, the defendant employed him as an assistant, at $600 per annum, to aid in the business of a practicing physician, which was the defendant's profession; that by the terms of their contract, either party was to have three months' notice of a desire to terminate the relation, but the defendant discharged the plaintiff without such notice.

abstract: Wednesday night, Mr. BRADY favored his friends with a hop and a gymnastic entertainment, at the rooms of the Gymnasium, on Eighth-street. The exercises opened with vaulting by pupils of Mr. BRADY, which was followed by feats of leaping, climbing and ground and lofty tumbling, all of which was very creditably performed. That portion of the entertainment closed with a performance on the treble trapez by a pupil. The feats were witnessed by a large assemblage of both sexes, who testified their admiration and appreciation by frequent and hearty applause. The dancing commenced at 11 o'clock, and did not terminate till a late hour. The entire affair was admirably managed by a Committee of young gentlemen, and everyone present seemed to be thoroughly delighted. Mr. BRADY may certainly congratulate himself on having so successfully entertained his friends.

abstract: John Moffat vs. Julia A. Moffat, widow of the late William B. Moffat, et al. -- This action was commenced in 1854 by John Moffat, claiming an interest as partner in the business owned by his son, of manufacturing and selling "Moffat's Life Pills and Phoenix Bitters," and was tried before Justice Bosworth, at a Special Term of the Court, in 1857, then occupying the attention of the Court for over two weeks. On the trial the parties to the action were examined as witnesses in their own behalf, and the trial resulted in a judgment in favor of the defendants.
lead_paragraph: John Moffat vs. Julia A. Moffat, widow of the late William B. abstract: The great billiard match for the championship and $1,000 last night at Irving Hall, at the four-ball carom game, DUDLEY KAVANAGH beats GOLDTHWAITE 218 points. The largest run was made by GOLDTHWAITE -- 130 points; KAVANAGH's largest run was 125 points. Another match for $1,000 was made between the same parties on the spot. The match was 1,500 points up, and lasted five hours and a half, concluding at 1 1/2 A.M.

abstract: At a late hour on Tuesday, EARLE's Hotel, corner of Canal and Centre streets, was the scene of some excitement, occasioned by the discovery that one of the clerks in the establishment, named E.H. HOWARD, had stolen from a safe in the office, about $22,000 in cash, with which he had escaped. The facts connected with the robbery, so far as we have been able to learn them, are as follows: HOWARD has been for some years in the employ of the Messrs. EARLE. He was formerly a bell-boy in the hotel, but being an active lad, and withal industrious and honest, so far as the proprietors could discover, they recently promoted him to the position of a junior clerk in the office of the hotel. At an early hour on Tuesday morning he entered upon his duties as usual, and at that time the key of the iron safe in the office was handed to him by one of the proprietors. Some hours afterward HOWARD was missed, also the key of the safe. An examination of the latter was made, when it was found to be carefully locked. The proprietors were notified of these circumstances, but they having full confidence in HOWARD's honesty, attributed his disappearance to some legitimate but unexplained cause. Late in the afternoon two boys called at the hotel and delivered the key of the safe, and also a note signed by HOWARD, and dated in Brooklyn. The note stated that the writer had been suddenly called away on account of the illness of a relative, but he would return that evening. The safe was then opened and three packages of money, amounting in all to over $22,000, were found to be gone. All but about $40 of this sum belonged to guests of the hotel, who had deposited their funds in the office for safe keeping. The Detective Police were immediately notified of the robbery, and every effort is being made to effect the arrest of HOWARD.

abstract: A party of several ladies and gentlemen, representing the Sanitary Commission and the Woman's Central Relief Association of Brooklyn, visited Fort Schuyler yesterday, and, after looking through the various wards and other departments of the hospital, expressed themselves highly pleased with the beneficent plans and perfect system prevailing there. The HUTCHINSONS were specially invited to join the party, and gave the soldiers a rich and rare treat by singing some of their beautiful and patriotic songs.
lead_paragraph: A party of several ladies and gentlemen, representing the Sanitary Commission and the Woman's Central Relief Association of Brooklyn, visited Fort Schuyler yesterday, and, after looking through the various wards and other departments of the hospital, expressed themselves highly pleased with the beneficent plans and perfect system prevailing there. The HUTCHINSONS were specially invited to join the party, and gave the soldiers a rich and rare treat by singing some of their beautiful and patriotic songs.

abstract: A general investigation in regard to the prize cases that have been disposed of in this port during the past two years, is now in process in this City. The preliminary movement was made on Wednesday. Mr. JOURDAN, the solicitor of the Treasury, held an interview with several of our well-known merchants and other citizens, and to-day is appointed for the real work of the investigation -- the taking of testimony -- to begin. The inquiry is to include the whole subject, and the acts of all persons who have had anything to do, directly or indirectly, with the prize cases -- their adjudication and the sale of the goods, either as agents of the Government or as private individuals -- will be passed in review. The comparatively large expenses of disposing of the prize goods here, as well as the numerous charges of fraud that have been freely made, have led to the investigation. Many thousands of persons have been connected with the sales, as buyers and otherwise, and all of these may be called on as witnesses.

abstract: The new steamboat Dictator, built by JOHN ELLIS & SON for the New-Jersey Steamboat Company, to run between this City and Albany, was launched from the foot of Tenth-street, East River yesterday, at noon. This is said to be the longest steamboat ever built. Her dimensions are as follows: Length, 407 feet; extreme breadth, 83 feet; depth of hold, 10 1/2 feet. She is intended to draw but five feet of water when fully loaded, and will thus be able to cross the bar at all stages of the water. She has three saloon decks, with 300 state-rooms, and will be able to accommodate 1,000 passengers. A large concourse of people assembled to witness the launch, comprising a goodly number of ladies and many of our prominent citizens, among whom were Ex-Mayor WESTERVELT, Hon. DANL. DREW, Capts. COMSTOCK, JEWITT, ELDRIDGE, BRIGGS and ST. JOHN, J.T. SANFORD, of Philadelphia, and others. The launch was in every way successful, and free from accident,

abstract: A shooting affray occurred at a late hour on Wednesday night at the Twenty-eighth Precinct Station-house, which has created considerable excitement in that part of the City. The returns, which were made to the Police Inspectors yesterday morning, showed that the night previous a man named THOMAS MURPHY had been accidently shot in the neck by a pistol, in the hands of JOSEPH SANDS, a Policeman of that Precinct, and that the occurrence took place after two attempts had been made by MURPHY's friends to rescue him from the custody of the officer, who had his prisoner (MURPHY) in custody, and was on the way to the Station house. This account seemed to make out a case, which, if not purely accidental, was at least a justifiable act on the part of the officer.

abstract: It is to be hoped that whenever the draft is made, enough men will be called for not simply to supply the actual wants of the army in the field, but to form a large and efficient reserve, to be kept under instruction and sent forward as fast as it is required.
lead_paragraph: It is to be hoped that whenever the draft is made, enough men will be called for not simply to supply the actual wants of the army in the field, but to form a large and efficient reserve, to be kept under instruction and sent forward as fast as it is required. We believe this war is the first great war of modern times in which the whole army has been sent to face the enemy as fast as it was raised, without the slightest provision for the subsequent filling up of the gaps caused by casualties or disease. The first large army which was raised after the fall of Fort Sumter went to the seat of war en masse, in the belief then prevalent that the rebellion could be crushed by one great blow. The possibility that another army still might be required before the struggle was over, or even that the one then going to the field would ever need reinforcements, did not occur to anybody. So we went through the first campaign expending men with a sort of oriental extravagance. There was nothing of which we were not more careful than of soldiers. State rights, Governors' prerogatives, the election of officers, every popular crotchet, or delusion, or doctrine, or tradition, had hecatombs of privates offered up at its shrine. Every battle saw thousands disappear from the ranks, every march its hundreds, by bullet, by desertion, and by disease. The result was that at the close of our first campaign we needed, not reinforcements, but a new army, and accordingly called 600,000 fresh men into the field.

abstract: We republish from our second edition of yesterday the following comprehensive and detailed report of the great billiard match between Mr. GOLDTHWAITE, of Boston, and Mr. KAVANAGH, of this City. The intense interest occasioned in sporting circles, and in many a private parlor, by this match, indicates very clearly that public confidence in the good effects of the game is on the increase, and that one more of the healthful recreations of life is removed from the exclusive possession of the "doers of evil," and brought within the pale of honorable custom and social recognition

abstract: A FATAL ACCIDENT. -- Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of EDWARD O'NEIL, who was killed by being run over by a train of the Harlem Railroad, near One Hundred and Thirty-first-street. The deceased was attempting to draw the pin which connected the locomotive with the tender, when, by some means, he slipped and fell upon the track. The train passed over him, and he was crushed to death almost instantly. The deceased was a native of Ireland, aged 26 years.

abstract: Speaking with the diffidence becoming a non-professional critic on military affairs, we are disposed to regard this work as one of the most important on the science of war, considered with reference to our situation, and present and future condition, that the existing rebellion has called forth.
lead_paragraph: Speaking with the diffidence becoming a non-professional critic on military affairs, we are disposed to regard this work as one of the most important on the science of war, considered with reference to our situation, and present and future condition, that the existing rebellion has called forth. The object of the writer is to examine the operations of the last two years by the great principles of war, "which cannot be violated with impunity," and to test, by a military examination of those campaigns, how far and in what manner they confirm those maxims which, like similar truths or morals, too often receive rather a general mental assent, than implicit submission to their dictates. The author possesses many qualifications for his task. His acquaintance with military history is very extensive; he claims no exclusive source of information, and laments the want of more accurate maps and official documents necessary for a strictly scientific judgment. There is no traee of personal feeling or hero-worship in the book. In the first division the principles of strategy concurred in by all the great masters of the art are expounded and illustrated to the comprehension of any non-technical reader. The second portion is a detailed examination of the geography of the Southern Confederacy; the scene of action for reducing to practice the principles already discussed. Their special application to the theatre of war then follows. The work continues with showing that the results of last year's campaign agrees with the conclusions to be drawn from the admitted data, and winds up with suggestions for the operations of 1863. Good maps illustrate the author's positions, and enable the reader to comprehend them thoroughly. A view of the great physical features of the country show that three great zones, or theatres of war, are distinctly marked out by natural lines of separation on the "debateable land" of the North and South. The first, or left zone, extends from the seaboard to the Alleghanies and the Blue Ridge; the right zone, comprising the country west of the Mississippi; and the central, interposes between the two others, extending north and south from the Ohio to the Gulf of Mexico. From natural causes these zones require each distinct military organizations --armies, bases of operation, supplies, &c. In importance, they diminish toward the West -- the first, or Eastern division, being incomparably the most serious point either of attack or defence, and the main field for decisive measures. While the West and the Central have no one essential strategic position, the reverse is the case in the East. Here we find a chain of mountains like a wedge driven from the North right into the very heart of the theatre of war -- it is the only elevated front of it -- and dominates it in all directions, like the bulwark or citadel of a fortress, which, in this case, may represent the whole South. Occupy the fortress, but leave the citadel untouched, and it will be the same as if nothing had been taken. In these mountains the Southern armies can rally, and maintaining here a central position, with the facility of debouching at any place, they can throw themselves with their whole force on all the surrounding fragments of our armies and beat them in detail. The possession of the mountain region is, therefore, a necessity for the holding not only of the left zone, but also of the whole theatre of the war. This once secured, we hold the key of the whole Southern Confederacy. Our armies are then in the central position and able to throw themselves on the fragments of the Southern armies with their united forces." Instead of the prosecution of a grand central plan like this, the author fin[???]s in the discussion of last year's campaigns a failure to understand the great principles of wars of invasion. A glance at the map is sufficient to show the number of places, isolated from each other, occupied by Union troops, where they are practically locked up in large bodies and debarred from exercising any influence in the general result. The invading armies should not care for towns or for occupation it should have but one object -- the finding and a[???]i[???]ilating of the enemy's armies. In a word, instead of one grand war and plan of operations, half-a-dozen small wits or petty plans were substituted. It must be remarked that the defence admirably profited by the rude lesson it received at Fort Don[???]lson, and from that moment its action became more and more correct, and in accordance with the rules to concentrate the main force always on the decisive point, and to act on interior lines. The following passage will show the originality of M. SCHALK's views: "The facilities offered by the navy by sea and river gunboats, had the most deteriorating effect on the operations. It was almost taken for granted that without them operations were impossible, and with them irresistible. The consequence of this gunboat mania was and is still, that the best lines of communications, but the least decisive line of operation, were invariably chosen. The large rivers on the seacoast attracted the Union Generals like magnets. If ever a circumstance conducts them into the interior of the country, immediately these rivers and the thought of safety and gunboats draw them back. As far as gunboats are concerned, they ought to play a very secondary part, merely to serve as a kind of diversion, but never to intrust large operations to, or confide to their guns the safety of a large army." Writing in January of the present year, the author reviews the probable occurrences of the coming campaign, and it is creditable to his foresight that a rebel attack on Gen. FOSTER and the army at Newbern, is pointed out as the very first step likely to be taken. He thinks that the rebels cannot afford to make any mistakes, but if they adhere to a correct defence and are less exhausted than is reported, the plan of invasion indicated by the position of the Unionarmies (in January) is not favorable to decisive results.

abstract: Gen. REYNOLDS reports from Liberty the particulars of the McMinnville affair. The main mounted force, under Cols. WILDER and MINTY, arrived at McMinnville at 1 o'clock on Wednesday morning, taking the place almost entirely by surprise. A rebel force, under GRIGSBY, was in front of the town, but Gen. REYNOLDS amused them while Col. WILDER went into the place. GRIGSBY escaped.

abstract: On Thursday, the work of laying the track for the Broadway Railroad was commenced at three different points, viz.; Union-square, at the corner of Fifteenth-street, and near the Battery. But a short distance of the track was laid, however, in consequence of the injunction issued by the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the work of laying the track for the Broadway Railroad was commenced at three different points, viz.; Union-square, at the corner of Fifteenth-street, and near the Battery. But a short distance of the track was laid, however, in consequence of the injunction issued by the Supreme Court. A gang of men employed by the opposition or George Law Company also commenced laying a track, for the purpose of obtaining the right of way. The points selected were the junction of Fourteenth-street and Broadway, just above the point where the Harlem track had been laid; and also a place below the Harlem track, and near the Battery new tracks were laid, so that, if the Harlem track that had been commenced was extended, it would compel the removal of the bars that were laid in its line. The bars or rails are about ten feet in length, and are temporarily fastened in the pavement -- the work having been performed at each end in not more than twenty minutes time. The rails laid by the Harlem Company are permanent, and the line it proposes to occupy is obstructed by the temporary railway of the opposition Company. An injunction prevents any further operations. Considerable excitement was occasioned yesterday around the City Hall, from information received that copies of the injunction would be served on the members of the Common Council. The following order, which was issued by Judge BARBOUR at his house, upon the application of the grantees of the Broadway Railroad bill, was served by Deputy Sheriff RAY yesterday, on the Mayor, Mr. VALENTINE, Clerk of the Common Council; Mr. ALLEN CAMPBELL, President of the Harlem Railroad Company; J.C. BUCKHOUT, Engineer of the Road; Deputy Street Commissioner TWEED, and some of the officers of the Croton Aqueduct Board:

abstract: A visit to the Government ship-yards in this vicinity enables one to form some idea of the magnitude of our naval operations. The tremendous iron frigates Puritan and Dictator, the huge ram Dunderberg; the iron-clads Miantanomah and Onondaga; the wooden vessels Metacomet, shamrock, Shamrock, Chenango, Mackinaw, Peoria, Nyack, Maumce; and, in Jersey, the iron-clads Manhattan, Mahopac, and Tecumseh, are all in various stages of progress. The following brief account of their condition embraces all that is necessary to know:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Assembly resolution to adjourn sine die at 1 o'clock was laid on the table, but a resolution was subsequently adopted to adjourn finally at 9:30 to-day. The Assembly resolutions proposing an amendment to the Constitution, so as to allow soldiers to vote, was referred to the Committee of the Whole.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Assembly resolution to adjourn sine die at 1 o'clock was laid on the table, but a resolution was subsequently adopted to adjourn finally at 9:30 to-day. The Assembly resolutions proposing an amendment to the Constitution, so as to allow soldiers to vote, was referred to the Committee of the Whole. The Senate refused to concur in the Assembly amendment to the Tax bill regarding County Treasurers, and it was reported that the Assembly refused to appoint a Conference Committee -- thus leaving the bill pending in the Senate. The Cross-town Railroad bill was passed, 18 to 9; also the bill providing relief for indigent families of volunteers. The Assembly amendment to the Broadway Railroad bill, changing the Company from a Corporation to an Association, was concurred in -- 17 to 14. In the evening the Assembly amendments to the Bank bill were concurred in. Mr. DEAN's Bank Capital Tax bill was passed. A message was received from the Governor vetoing the Soldiers' Proxy Vote bill, but it was passed over the veto. The Harbor Defence bill freely passed.

abstract: The British bark John Griffin, of Nassau, N.P., Capt. CHASE, from Cardenas the 9th inst., with sugar to J.E. WARD & CO., arrived yesterday. On the 10th inst., off Double Headed Shots, she was boarded by a boat from the steamship Morion, ashore there, and took from her the mate and twenty-three of her crew. The report the steamer a total loss. A part of the cargo has been saved, in a damaged state.

abstract: The United States vs. Two cases of Wooden Smoking-pipes. This action was tried with another one involving the same questions. They were brought to forfeit the goods for alleged fraudulent undervaluation. The goods were imported in December, 1861, from Paris. On appraisement at the Custom-house here their value was advanced about twenty-five per cent., and thereupon these actions were brought to forfeit them. They were valued at about $1,200.

abstract: The pirates Florida and Alabama are both heard of again in the manner least welcome. An arrival at Halifax, from St. Thomas and Bermuda, brings intelligence that the Florida, in addition to the Star of Peace before reported, has recently captured the bark Lapwing, from Boston, and the bark M. J. Colcord, of New-York.
lead_paragraph: The pirates Florida and Alabama are both heard of again in the manner least welcome. An arrival at Halifax, from St. Thomas and Bermuda, brings intelligence that the Florida, in addition to the Star of Peace before reported, has recently captured the bark Lapwing, from Boston, and the bark M.J. Colcord, of New-York. Two guns and eighteen men were put on board the former, but the fate of the Colcord is unknown. A vessel arrived at Boston, from Cape Haytien, brings the report that the Alabama, on the 26th ult., chased two vessels on shore in Turk's Island passage. One of them went to pieces, but the cargo of the other would be saved.

abstract: At 2 o'clock P.M., just as the officers had seated themselves for dinner, the first advance of the iron-clad fleet was announced to the commandant of the cost. Their anchorage had been within the bar of Ship Channel, off the southern end of Morris Island, some four or five miles from Sumter.
lead_paragraph: At 2 o'clock P.M., just as the officers had seated themselves for dinner, the first advance of the iron-clad fleet was announced to the commandant of the cost. Their anchorage had been within the bar of Ship Channel, off the southern end of Morris Island, some four or five miles from Sumter. Upon inspection, it was judged that good time would be allowed for the conclusion of the meal, and, after communicating the movement by telegraph to headquarters in Charleston, dinner was comfortably dispatched. At 2 1/2 o'clock, after examination of the approaching armament from the terreplein, the order for the "long roll" was issued. The whole garrison knew that the hour of trial was at hand, and the greatest enthusiasm and alacrity prevailed. The men rushed to their guns with shouting and yells of exultation. The regimental band was ordered to the rampart. The garrison flag (the Confederate States) was already flying defiantly from the staff at the northern apex of the pentagonal fortress. The blue and white banner of the Palmetto State was given to the wind on the southwest corner of the work, and the elegant black and white color of the First Regiment South Carolina artillery (regulars) was run up at the southeast angle, in the face of the coming foe. A salute of thirteen unshotted guns was fired, and the band broke forth with the stirring strains of "Dixie."

abstract: The trial of RADZKY for the murder of FELLNER, which has been pending a long time in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, was concluded yesterday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The trial of RADZKY for the murder of FELLNER, which has been pending a long time in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, was concluded yesterday afternoon. On Friday Mr. SIDNEY STEWART summed up on behalf of the prisoner; and, during the course of his argument, contended that if the murder was committed at the boat-house in Gowanus Bay, as held by the prosecution, but which they had failed to prove, then the case was beyond the jurisdiction of the criminal authorities of Kings County, and the prisoner was triable in New-York County. His theory was, that FELLNER had been piled with wine at the house occupied by Miss PFLAUM and Mrs. MARY in East Broadway, and that the was murdered there and by them -- that RADSKY had nothing to do with the actual commission of the deed, but might possibly have had a guilty knowledge of the fact.

abstract: THOMAS DIMS, well-known as the first of the persons sent South from this city under the provisions of the Fugitive Slave law, arrived here, last night, with his family. He came direct from the vicinity of Vicksburgh, having escaped from that city only three weeks ago. It will be remembered that the master of SIMS resided in Savannah, Ga., and that, under the order of the United States Commissioner, SIMS, at early dawn, was escorted by the police, under City Marshal TUKEY, protected by military, the whole under the direction of United States Marshal FREEMAN, to Central Wharf, where he was placed on board a vessel which conveyed him to Savannah. Ever since that time he has been held as a slave.

abstract: Cotton and tobacco took quite a tumble yesterday from their lofty eminence. The former could scarcely attract a buyer at 25 cents; while of the latter, if you said tobacco to a fellow, ten to one you get a clip between your two eyes. Well, we expected a tumble, but not quite so soon, and we expect a tumble in provisions shortly. There is more to eat in the land than many think for, and if Government paws could be kept off, it would soon come to light. Stand from under.

abstract: The Literary Messenger for March, which we find on our table, has a number of interesting articles. The opening article, "History of the War," which has been continued through many numbers back, reaches a thrilling epoch in the present number. The disaster at Rich Mountain, the fighting on Cheat River, the fall of Gen. GARNETT, &c., are well related. Then comes the movements which preceded the great battle of Manassas; and having brought us back to the threshold of that sanguinary conflict the narrative is suspended until the next number.

abstract: The possibility of making truly Scientific Lectures popular and profitable seems to be demonstrated in the success of Professor RICHARD's course on "The Atmosphere." It has run as well in Brooklyn as it did here; and closed with the plaud of the people on Thursday evening last. He is to deliver there, the Eclectic course of two Lectures, which he gave at Clinton Hall, and they are announced for Monday and Wednesday nights next. It is a public benefit thus to elevate the tone of our popular entertainments, and we bid the lecturer God speed.

abstract: The steamer Tubal Cain, which was captured on July 24, 1862, while attempting to run the blockade, has been reseized by the Federal authorities in this City, under peculiar circumstances. When the vessel and cargo was sold, it appears, prominent parties purchased her and put a cargo on board, with the object of running the blockade. Information of this extraordinary treasonable adventure, however, was communicated to Washington, and the vessel was at once seized. She is now lying at a dock on the East River, and her decks are guarded by a patrol from the Fourth Artillery. A few days since laborers were employed to remove her cargo. They found a considerable quantity of military caps and clothing concealed in the vessel. Yesterday morning arms were discovered in trunks with "false bottoms," and kegs of powder, as alleged, were found concealed in barrels of flour. Only two officers were found on board the steamer when she was reseized, whose names are reported to be SUTTON and BLOOME, and they have been sent to Fort Lafayette.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Tubal Cain, which was captured on July 24, 1862, while attempting to run the blockade, has been reseized by the Federal authorities in this City, under peculiar circumstances. abstract: The extensive soap and candle factoy of ALLAN HAY  Co., No. 39, First-avenue, was entirely consumed by fire last evening. The fire originated in the rear of the building, from some cause at present not ascertained, and spread with such rapidity that the roof fell in about half an hour afterward.
lead_paragraph: The extensive soap and candle factoy of ALLAN HAY & CO., No. 39, First-avenue, was entirely consumed by fire last evening. The fire originated in the rear of the building, from some cause at present not ascertained, and spread with such rapidity that the roof fell in about half an hour afterward. The firemen were promptly on hand, but could only confine the flames to the building, and save those adjoining. The entire stock, as well as the edifice itself was completely destroyed. Messrs. HAY & CO. estimate their loss on stock to be $100,000, and on machinery to be $45,000. The building is also owned by them, the loss on the same being estimated at $30,000. These amounts are partially covered by insurance, to the extent of $75,000, divided among the following Companies: Merchants', Exchange, Pacific, Excelsior, Williamsburgh City, Stuyvesant, Relief, Brevoort, Lenox, Commercial, Commonwealth, New-Amsterdam, Phenix, Brooklyn, Atlantic, American, Jersey City, American Exchange, Rutger's, Importers and Traders', St. Mark's, Citizens' and Bowery.

abstract: For a long time past, the Bar in this city has been extremely desirous that the State Supreme Court should be roorganized. There were many cases on the docket of the old Court which could not (it was thought) be properly brought before the Provisional Court, on account of the different between the laws governing the United States Circuit and District Courts, and those of the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Gen. SHEPLEY, Military Governor, has yielded to the wish of the Bar, and has reestablished the Supreme Court.

abstract: SUPPOSED DEATH BY FOUL MEANS. Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, commenced an inquest on Friday night, upon the body of MORRIS SHAY, an old man residing in South 7th-st., who died on Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: SUPPOSED DEATH BY FOUL MEANS. -- Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, commenced an inquest on Friday night, upon the body of MORRIS SHAY, an old man residing in South 7th-st., who died on Thursday morning. About 11 o'clock on Tuesday night last, deceased was found lying insensible on the side-walk in Newark-av., with a gash on his cheek, and his eyes blackened and swollen from bruises. He was removed to the station-house, and when an attempt was made to rouse him the only words he uttered were: "I did not deserve it." He was sent home, and died on Thursday morning. A young woman named Brown, residing at No. 255 Newark-av., testified that about 11 o'clock on Tuesday night last, while standing in front of her house, she saw two men engaged in a fight, and one of them fell to the ground; the other man then rushed after her, when she escaped into the house; soon afterward she saw the same man walking up the street, on the opposite side. It was also shown that deceased had attended a wake that evening, and was intoxicated. The inquest was adjourned until Wednesday evening.

abstract: Among our European news of Wednesday were some curious extracts from a correspondence which the Liverpool Mercury pretends to have brought to light, purporting to be an account of the doings of Federal agents ...
lead_paragraph: Among our European news of Wednesday were some curious extracts from a correspondence which the Liverpool Mercury pretends to have brought to light, purporting to be an account of the doings of Federal agents in England, and instructions sent to these agents from some mysterious power or person on this side of the water -- most probably from that well-known and highly influential body, "the New-York mob." It is evident at a glance that the object of this tremendous revelation is to neutralize the effects of the Union and emancipation agitation now going on in all parts of Great Britain, as well as the demonstrations of sympathy with the North which the middle and lower classes have everywhere made, by representing the whole movement to be the work of paid Federal agents, or the direct result of Northern bribery. Allegations to this effect were made by the London Times some weeks ago, but they were promptly and flatly contradicted by Mr. ADAMS, in his reply to one of the Anti-Slavery deputations. It has consequently been thought advisable to make "exposures" of Northern intrigues, with the aid of names, and dates, and circumstances, and we have the whole story thus before us.

abstract: The British Government seems for the present to be fixed in the policy of non-intervention in our affairs; not on principle, or because it accords to our Government the same respect which it would under like circumstances exact for itself; but because, in the words of its own spokesmen, the time has ...
lead_paragraph: The British Government seems for the present to be fixed in the policy of non-intervention in our affairs; not on principle, or because it accords to our Government the same respect which it would under like circumstances exact for itself; but because, in the words of its own spokesmen, the time has not yet arrived when intervention will be profitable to British interests. A strong and constantly increasing pressure, however, is still brought to bear upon the Government by the aristocratic, and the wealthier commercial classes, in favor of a persistent attempt to mediate between the rebel Government and that of the Republic -- this mediation to be pressed upon us at the first sign of exhaustion, whether from the calamities of war or those of internal faction. This project of a mediation, which is to be purely pacific and diplomatic, is urged in communications to newspapers and in pamphlets, and more and more finds encouragement. A book has finally appeared in London upon the subject, which is written with no little ability, and from a point of view which will cause it to be received with favor in England. From this volume, which is entitled The American Question and How to Settle It, we may learn very clearly what British mediation means.
headline: {'main': 'What British Mediation Means.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What British Mediation Means.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Ever since the "Union Ferry Company" doubled their rates of fare between New-York and Brooklyn, and announced as a reason therefor the "high price of coal," but forgot to reduce the fare as coal went down, the market value of that article (the coal, not the Company) has been a subject of anxious solicitude to a large class of people on Long Island, and we might add also on Manhattan Island; for as all great geniuses have their imitators, so the brilliant idea of the Ferry Company was taken up on this side the river, and from that day to this the "high price of coal" has been the jocular plea for all sorts of extortion. It is not strange, therefore, especially in view of the experiences of the past Winter, when the "high price of coal" was really no joke, that the community should be casting their eyes anxiously toward the Anthracite valleys of Pennsylvania, and that the rumors which daily come to their ears from the Lehigh, the Wyoming, or the Schuylkill, of "strikes among the miners," should create nervous apprehensions for the future. In order that the readers of the TIMES might have some correct idea of what the strikes really amount to, and the results that are likely to flow from them, and also of the general condition and prospects of the coal business for the coming season, one of its corps of reporters was dispatched to Pennsylvania, and after spending a week in the mining regions he is prepared to give the following as the result of his observations. abstract: On Wednesday, Jan. 14, 1863, the gallant Lieutenant Commanding THOMAS MCKEAN BUCHANAN, United States Navy, lost his life by a ball, shot from a rifle-pit near the mouth of the Teche. He was Commander of the fleet, and was highly beloved and appreciated by those under him. He was a gallant and brave officer, and all praise is due him who avenged his death; for we can well say that the navy lost one of its bravest officers and the American Union one of its truest sons. None knew him but to love him, for he was courageous, generous and kind. Lieut. BUCHANAN went to New-Orleans but a few short months ago, and was among the first to display heroic and gallant traits of character. His name is identified with the exploits of the New-London, on the Lake, and he has also been in command of the Creoic and Gray Cloud, and his name is held in fond remembrance by the distressed people of the Lake shore, to whom he had shown many acts of kindness. He never forgot those who were the first to come forward and put themselves under the protection of the Union flag, and avow themselves supporters of the cause.

abstract: We have an account this morning, from the Army of the Potomac, of a dashing raid into Port Royal, on the south side of the Rappahannock, on Thursday morning last. An expedition, consistof the Fourteenth, Brooklyn, and Nineteenth Indiana, crossed the river on pontoons at Port Conway ...
lead_paragraph: We have an account this morning, from the Army of the Potomac, of a dashing raid into Port Royal, on the south side of the Rappahannock, on Thursday morning last. An expedition, consistof the Fourteenth, Brooklyn, and Nineteenth Indiana, crossed the river on pontoons at Port Conway, suprised a detachment of rebel cavalry at Port Royal, captured twenty or more of them, burnt a number of army wagons, and brought away several horses and mules. On the approach of a superior force of the enemy, our men retired across the river, and returned to camp in safety. The rain-storm ceased on the Rappahannock on Friday night, and the roads are again rapidly drying.

abstract: Some persons have been led to magnify the recent advance of the rebels into Southeastern Missouri, as the beginning of Gen. STERLING PRICE's contemplated invasion of Missouri. This notion seems quite unreasonable. STERLING PRICE has been in Arkansas only a very few weeks. He found in that State no army equal to so serious a work as an immediate invasion of a State so strongly defended as Missouri. He found only the shattered and demoralized wreck of HINDMAN's beaten forces, who, according to HINDMAN's admissions in his intercepted correspondence, were dispirited, poorly armed and worse fed. STERLING PRICE is not the man to move post haste with such a mob into a campaign against the experienced and gallant Union army in Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Some persons have been led to magnify the recent advance of the rebels into Southeastern Missouri, as the beginning of Gen. STERLING PRICE's contemplated invasion of Missouri. abstract: If it be true that "April showers bring forth May flowers," then the path of this army through Virginia ought to be strewn wiht roses, and every bayonet be encircled by a garland of the beauties of the floral kingdom, for we are having showers enough to bring forth a whole continent of May flowers.

abstract: On Wednesday night last, the trustees of Ply-Church Society held a special meeting, at which the perceptible effect of constant hard work upon the pastor (Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER) was the subject of discussion. After some little conversational debate, it was moved and carried unanimously that Mr. BEECHER be granted a leave of absence of four months from the 1st of June, and that his expenses during a trip to, in and from Europe, be defrayed by the Society.

abstract: -- The Alta California announces the death, on March 25, of Dr. JOS. R. DEPREFONTAINE, commercial editor of that paper. Dr. DEPREFONTAINE was born in Philadelphia, and had reached his 54th year. Graduating in medicine about the year 1827, he was commissioned by the Government to vaccinate the Indian tribes on the plains, and in that capacity spent some years, traversing nearly the whole of the basin of the Rocky Mountains, and associating with the hardy trappers of that period. In 1835 he reached the Pacific shores on official duties, passing through Oregon, and in 1837 he visited the whole of the country east of the Sierra Nevadas. He was for many years prominent in the politics of Missouri, and likewise was long connected with the St. Louis press. He went to California to reside in 1852, and had since maintained his position as a first-class commercial writer, first on the Placer Times and Transcript, and having in charge for several years past the commercial department of the Alta California.

abstract: CONVICTION OF RATZKY FOR THE MURDER OF FELLNER.--The trial of IGNATZ RATZKY, indicted for the murder of SIGISMUND FELLNER, the diamond merchant ...
lead_paragraph: CONVICTION OF RATZKY FOR THE MURDER OF FELLNER. -- The trial of IGNATZ RATZKY, indicted for the murder of SIGISMUND FELLNER, the diamond merchant, which occupied the attention of the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer the entire week, was finally concluded on Saturday. The case was given to the jury about 11 o'clock A.M., under the chafe of the Court, and in about 15 minutes thereafter they came back with a verdict of "Guilty of murder in the first degree." The prisoner confidently anticipated an acquittal. He had, during the week, paid the strictest attention to the evidence as given by the witnesses, and to the remarks of counsel on both sides, but seldom exhibited any uneasiness. When the verdict was rendered he maintained the same demeanor that he did during the week, but after his removal to a neighboring room, and in the presence of his wife, he could maintain his composure no longer, and sunk upon the floor in a fainting fit, which was succeeded by dreadful convulsions. During the intervals of his paroxysms he would exclaim, "Oh, my God, how can I stand this?" "My heart will break;" and similar expressions, indicating intense agony of mind. He finally become senseless, and his limbs grew rigid, in which state he was conveyed to a carriage and taken to jail, The prisoner will not be brought up for sentence until the June term -- meantime an effort will be made to set aside the verdict.

abstract: The funeral ceremonies of WILLIAM R. BLAKE, the comedian, took place yesterday, at 2 P.M., at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, (Episcopal,) in Hammond-street. The service was performed by the pastor, Rev. Dr. COOK, and was listened to by a very large congregation. In fact, the attendance was so great that scores of people were unable to gain admittance to the edifice. The ceremonies were very impressive and at times many of those present could not refrain from tears. The coffin which contained the remains was of rosewood, studded with silver nails, and bore a plate with an appropriate inscription. The lid was strewn with delicate white flowers. The solemn service having been concluded, an opportunity was given the assemblage to take a final view of deceased, after which the coffin was borne to the hearse, to be conveyed to Greenwood Cemetery. The hearse was followed by a large number of carriages, containing the relatives and friends of the departed.

abstract: We have advices from New-Orleans to the 19th lnst., by the arrival at this port of the United States steamer Fulton. The most important news relates to the operations of Gen. BANKS' army in the Teche Country, full details of which are given elsewhere. The reports are of the most satisfactory character. Gen. BANKS reached Vermillionville, after a spirited fight at the crossing ...
lead_paragraph: We have advices from New-Orleans to the 19th lnst., by the arrival at this port of the United States steamer Fulton. The most important news relates to the operations of Gen. BANKS' army in the Teche Country, full details of which are given elsewhere. The reports are of the most satisfactory character. Gen. BANKS reached Vermillionville, after a spirited fight at the crossing of the Vermillionville Bayou, a short distance from the village, and expected to reach Opelousas by the night of the 19th, with his entire command. It appears that he had previously fought a severe engagement at Bethel Place, at which the rebels had strong fortifications -- the struggle lasting two days, and ending in the retreat of the rebels. Gen. GROVER had also fought a battle, in which he defeated the enemy and captured a large number of prisoners. It is further reported that the rebel fortifications at Bute la Rose had been reduced by our fleet, and that the place was in our possession. The rebels had destroyed a large number of steamers to prevent their falling into our possession.

abstract: Two of the regiments of New-York two year volunteers were mustered out of Gen. HOOKER'S army on Thursday last, and one of them (the Eighth New-York, or First German Rifles,) will probably arrive in this City today.
lead_paragraph: Two of the regiments of New-York two year volunteers were mustered out of Gen. HOOKER'S army on Thursday last, and one of them (the Eighth New-York, or First German Rifles,) will probably arrive in this City today. Other of these regiments will continue to arrive every few days until the 17th of June, when the last of them will be mustered out of the service. As is generally known, the first thirty-eight regiments from this State volunteered for two years; one of these -- the Eleventh, or First Fire Zouaves -- was mustered out of service nearly a year ago; of the remaining thirty-seven, eighteen belong to this City.

abstract: Important dispatches from the Mexican Government have been received by the Mexican Min- ...
lead_paragraph: Important dispatches from the Mexican Government have been received by the Mexican Minister in Washington, relating to the operations of the French at Puebla. These dispatches include several letters from Gen. ORTEGA, commanding the Mexican forces in the city, to Gen. COMONFORT, which we give in this morning's TIMES. They bring the official history of operations down to the 26th ult., on which day, after several days' bombardment, a direct assault upon the city by the French had been repulsed. On the 25th an active fire by shot and shell had destroyed a part of the Fort of St. Zavier, and on the morning of the 26th several assaulting columns of the French advanced to assail the work. These columns, in the words of the dispatch, were "repulsed and destroyed in less than an hour." This affair, magnified by travel, is probably the basis of the report which reached us a few days ago by way of Matamoras and New-Orleans, though the repulse of the French in that report was said to have taken place on the 27th.

abstract: The Legislature adjourned on Saturday, with more order and decorum than its previous experience had led us to expect. It has thus closed a very remarkable session,-- remarkable not so much on account of any very important action which it has taken, as ...
lead_paragraph: The Legislature adjourned on Saturday, with more order and decorum than its previous experience had led us to expect. It has thus closed a very remarkable session, -- remarkable not so much on account of any very important action which it has taken, as for the general tone and temper in which its business has been transacted. The Republicans had a very decided majority in the Senate, and made themselves substantially responsible for the action of the Assembly by securing its organization. But they do not seem to have acted with any concert or with any marked regard to the welfare and reputation of the party which will be held responsible for their conduct. A sharp and unscrupulous devotion to private and personal interests seems to have controlled a sufficient number of members to decide the action of the Legislature upon all important questions submitted to its action. The Broadway Railroad bill has been the main feature of the session; the fate of nearly every other bill of any consequence has turned upon this. It is a matter of surprise that the adjournment finds only one member under arrest for corruption in connection with the measure.

abstract: attempt was recently made by an American Importer, in this City, of Secesh proclivities, to evade the payment of Duties upon Imports in Gold and Silver by subdividing an invoice of Iron into bars or bundles, so as to make the Customs upon each a few cents under $5, and then tendering Postage change in place of small Gold Coin or Silver.
lead_paragraph: -- An attempt was recently made by an American Importer, in this City, of Secesh proclivities, to evade the payment of Duties upon Imports in Gold and Silver by subdividing an invoice of Iron into bars or bundles, so as to make the Customs upon each a few cents under $5, and then tendering Postage change in place of small Gold Coin or Silver. The record of the transaction is open to inspection at the office of the Cashier of Customs, and was exposed at the time in answer to the charge in a certain morning journal, which, from obvious sympathy made itself the organ of the Importer referred to, that the Government was repudiating its own obligations for Customs, because this trick was not suffered to go on. Previous to this affair, the Collector was disposed to accommodate the Merchants in making change for small odd sums in the course of business at his Cashier's office. But to allow the subdivision of entries for the express purpose of evading the Act of Congress requiring Gold and Silver for Customs could not of course be tolerated; and the Department at Washington, on learning the facts, was compelled to direct the general refusal of all paper change, to keep the law on the subject from being practically upset.

abstract: An extra night will be given on Wednesday at the Academy of Music, when all the leading opera people in the City volunteer to perform for the benefit of Mr. PALMO.
lead_paragraph: An extra night will be given on Wednesday at the Academy of Music, when all the leading opera people in the City volunteer to perform for the benefit of Mr. PALMO. The name of PALMO is associated with the very earliest efforts made to establish Italian opera in New-York. He it was who first sought to cultivate here a taste for the highest form of musical art, and he lost a fortune in the attempt. His circumstances now are far from flourishing. He wants and deserves the most generous aid which the profession and the public have it in their power to bestow, and it is to be hoped his claims will not be disregarded.

abstract: There is an article in the last number of the Cornhill Magazine, by a "British officer." giving the results of a trip of two months through the Southern States, closing in last December. He is evidently a cool observer, without any marked prejudices in favor of either North or South; but bears strong testimony, as usual, to the unanimity and de- ...
lead_paragraph: There is an article in the last number of the Cornhill Magazine, by a "British officer." giving the results of a trip of two months through the Southern States, closing in last December. He is evidently a cool observer, without any marked prejudices in favor of either North or South; but bears strong testimony, as usual, to the unanimity and determination of the Southern people. On his arrival at Richmond, immediately before the battle of Fredericksburgh, he hired a carriage, or something in the shape of a carriage, and went out to visit the battlefields of last Summer in front of the city. Strange to say, he was unable to discover any trace of the formidable earthworks which prevented Gen. MCCLELLAN's advance. He says:

abstract: give from New-Orleans relates to battles west of that city--of which there appears to have been three, one near Franklin, another at Vermillion Bayou, and a third at Bethel Place; ...
lead_paragraph: -- The news we give from New-Orleans relates to battles west of that city -- of which there appears to have been three, one near Franklin, another at Vermillion Bayou, and a third at Bethel Place; but the mails have not come in regular order, and we are yet without intelligence that can be comprehended of the chief of these engagements -- and, indeed, the whole of the movements are hard to be understood. The one thing that appears clear is, that in all the battles Gen. BANKS' troops were successful, whipping and driving the enemy, and capturing, it is said, 1,500 prisoners. We had it by telegraph, yesterday, that Gen. BANKS' army had appeared at "Point Coupee, on the south bank of Red River," which may, perhaps, be credited, in the light of the present news. Point Coupee is a town on the west bank of the Mississippi, eleven miles higher up the stream than Port Hudson, and if BANKS really has pushed over there, he would seem to be in a most advantageous position to operate, in conjunction with the iron-clad fleet, against the latter stronghold. But the news needs badly to be put in order and cleared up, which it doubtless will be by to-morrow.

abstract: The Democratic members of the State Legislature have issued an address to their constituents. It is a pretentious document, and its main object, as was natural under the ...
lead_paragraph: The Democratic members of the State Legislature have issued an address to their constituents. It is a pretentious document, and its main object, as was natural under the circumstances, is to assail the Administration. It rehearses, and makes the most of the proceedings at the election of Speaker, dwells with great emphasis upon the subject of arbitrary arrests, and denounces the attempt to establish banks under the authority of the United States within the jurisdiction of this State. It makes a faltering protest against the Conscription law of Congress, and dwells with just pride upon the patriotic spirit which has led this State to place its men and its money at the command of the National Government for the defence of the National flag. The Democrats are not warranted, it seems to us, in attributing the passage of the Conscription bill to any distrust on the part of the National Government of the patriotic spirit and devotion of the people. They have the right, however, to protest against it, and we accept their appeal to "the ballot-box, the judicial tribunals and the other organs of the sentiment of a free people," as the proper means of securing redress for any wrongs they may think they have sustained.

abstract: As the State of Missouri was the first to feel the shock of war, and the first to suffer its most blighting ravages, so is it likely to be the first to emerge from the slough of Slavery, ...
lead_paragraph: As the State of Missouri was the first to feel the shock of war, and the first to suffer its most blighting ravages, so is it likely to be the first to emerge from the slough of Slavery, and enjoy the liberty and prosperity that the war was needed to produce. Long before the commencement of the rebellion, it was foreseen by all intelligent citizens that Missouri would eventually be free. But, notwithstanding this fact, no present benefits resulted to the State. Its mines remained unopened, its fields untilled, and its railroads uncompleted. The best of property had only a nominal value, and the sellers always were largely in excess of buyers. Slavery might be doomed, but it still existed, and might exist for generations; and that was too long to afford any encouragement to investment in Missouri property, or emigration to the State.
