abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock P.M. yesterday, when resolutions in regard to the death of Col. EDMUND C. CHARLES were presented by Mr. FROMENT, and adopted. The Mayor's Message, announcing that he had signed the Broadway Railroad resolutions, and giving his reasons for approving them, was received, read and filed.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock P.M. yesterday, when resolutions in regard to the death of Col. EDMUND C. CHARLES were presented by Mr. FROMENT, and adopted. The Mayor's Message, announcing that he had signed the Broadway Railroad resolutions, and giving his reasons for approving them, was received, read and filed. The Comptroller reported that the balance in the City Treasury on last Saturday was $2,601,776 55. A proposition to pave the Third avenue with Belgian pavement, between Fifty-sixth and Eighty-sixth streets, elicited some debate. Some settled ratio of assessment upon property-owners and the City for this kind of pavement, Mr. FROMENT urged, should be decided upon. The Legislature, he said, reduced our appropriations for the work every year, and so kept the Croton Board from fulfilling the orders of the Common Council for laying the Belgian pavement. Meanwhile the expense of repairing the cobble-stone pavement amounted to about as much each year as was allowed for putting down new pavement. Mr. BOOLE wished to stop ordering any more Belgian pavement till it shall be definitely determined how much the City and the property-owners benefited by the improvement in each case shall respectively bear, for work had long been ordered far exceeding the amount of the appropriation for new pavement. Mr. HARDY showed that the work proposed to be done on Third-avenue was ordered by an ordinance passed in 1856, assessing half the cost upon the property-owners directly interested, and the remainder upon the City. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. to-day.

abstract: "I expect within a day or two to be out on an expedition, the character of which I surmise to be raid. Our regiment is all mounted on mules, and a pretty flapping of ears I assure you there is. We are called the "Jackass Brigade" by those who don't admire us, but we claim to be Mulish Lancers. However, I tell you this is the true mode of fighting these fellows down here. Celerity of movement is indispensable, and although it is no part of our intention to fight on the backs of these long-eared quadrupeds, they will carry us as many miles in a day as horses, and then we are fresh with our infantry drill, wherein we claim to beat 'em all."

abstract: -- The brief series of resolutions on the army and the war, which were adopted by acclamation by the State Legislature, on Friday, were perhaps not as comprehensive as might have been desired; but the two great merits appertain to them that they reach the main point very directly, and that they were adopted unanimously. The second resolution pledges the State of New-York to uphold the National arms in the field, "until the Union shall be restored, and until the flag of the Union shall float on every fort, and in every harbor, town, city and hamlet in the rebel States."

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. J.S. CLARKE commenced an engagement at the Winter Garden last night, appearing in "Luck, or the Gentleman of Nature," and a revised edition of "The Toodles." The first piece was rendered, by the really fine acting of Mr. CLARKE, a positive success. Without intrinsic merit as a dramatic work, it affords the chief comedian an opportunity to create an original character, and this is a faculty which Mr. CLARKE possesses to an extent unrivaled by any performer of the day, excepting, perhaps, Mr. JEFFERSON. He endued the piece with life and substance, and fairly forced it into the estimation of his audience. In "The Toodles" he had already established a great reputation, even when the humorous portion of it was overlaid by a great deal of stupid melodrama. This stupid element has now been entirely dispensed with, much to the satisfaction of all who may in future seek to derive enjoyment from its representation. Mr. CLARKE can now revel in the eccentricities of artistic intoxication and develop all the comic phases of conjugal bickering, without any disagreeable interference from quarrelsome brothers and misplaced churchyard sentiment. He takes every advantage of the opportunity thus afforded him, and gets called out between the scenes twice, to a dead certainty, besides narrowly escaping two or three encores. He will, undoubtedly, attract crowded houses for as long as it pleases him to remain in the City.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. J.S. CLARKE commenced an engagement at the Winter Garden last night, appearing in "Luck, or the Gentleman of Nature," and a revised edition of "The Toodles." The first piece was rendered, by the really fine acting of Mr. CLARKE, a positive success. Without intrinsic merit as a dramatic work, it affords the chief comedian an opportunity to create an original character, and this is a faculty which Mr. CLARKE possesses to an extent unrivaled by any performer of the day, excepting, perhaps, Mr. JEFFERSON. He endued the piece with life and substance, and fairly forced it into the estimation of his audience. In "The Toodles" he had already established a great reputation, even when the humorous portion of it was overlaid by a great deal of stupid melodrama. This stupid element has now been entirely dispensed with, much to the satisfaction of all who may in future seek to derive enjoyment from its representation. Mr. CLARKE can now revel in the eccentricities of artistic intoxication and develop all the comic phases of conjugal bickering, without any disagreeable interference from quarrelsome brothers and misplaced churchyard sentiment. He takes every advantage of the opportunity thus afforded him, and gets called out between the scenes twice, to a dead certainty, besides narrowly escaping two or three encores. He will, undoubtedly, attract crowded houses for as long as it pleases him to remain in the City.

abstract: Our cavalry engaged the enemy, yesterday, at Birmingham. The fight lasted two hours and a half. The enemy was completely routed, with 15 killed and a large number wounded. Col. HATCH, of the Twenty-fifth Iowa, was seen to fall from his horse, which ran into our lines and was captured. Our loss was one killed and twenty wounded. The destruction of a bridge prevented pursuit.

abstract: Yesterday was one of the greatest gala days ever known among the German population of the Metropolis. The return of the Seventh and Eighth regiments called out not only their immediate friends, relatives and acquaintances, but, thousands upon thousands of their countrymen, together with a mass of all nationalities seldom gathered at such short notice. The uncertainty as to the hour of the arrival of the regiments, of course made the reception much of an impromptu affair, but, in heartiness, in cordiality, in the whole-souled congratulations which it elicited, it could hardly have been surpassed. The friends of the two regiments collected respectively at the Steuben House, Bowery, and at Dramatic Hall. Houston-street, early in the day, and left about three o'clock, with the expectation of meeting the returning regiments immediately upon their landing. But, they were a little late, as the veterans had already arrived at Jersey City, where, exactly at 3 o'clock the whistle of the locomotive was heard, and in a few moments the train dashed into the depot, amid the cheers and shouts of the people, heartily responded to by the soldiers. As the latter left the cars they endeavored to fall into line; their ranks,however, were soon broken by the mothers, sisters, wives and sweethearts, rushing in eagerly, clasping their hands and, as might naturally be expected, embracing and kissing them. At last, with the greatest difficulty the men got on board the ferry-boat D[???]y, which soon started for the New-York shore, amid the blowing of steam-whistles from the boats in the river, the lowering of colors, and cheers from the crews of the various vessels in the river, and the firing of salutes. As the boat touched the stores, the crowd outside the gates broke through all restraint, and rushing through the gandway, welcomed the soldiers with "three times three" rousing cheers. The "Seventh" at once formed in line in Cortlandt-street, and were received by a detachment of the Third New-York cavalry, and by them escorted through Broadway. They were soon followed by the Eighth, escorted by a delegation of German citizens. On the left hand of Col. (Prince) SALM SALM, of the Eighth, was Gen. BLENKER, attired in citizens' dress. The meeting with the reception delegations in the angle formed by the junction of Park-row and Broadway, in front of the Astor House and Museum, was extremely interesting; for, soon after the arrival of the veterans at the front of the Museum, the head of the reception delegations made its appearance with a band of music, with bouquets, banners, ladies, war-worn veterans who had previously returned, citizen soldiers and citizens generally, to the number of thousands. Such a hurrahing and cheering as ensued baffle description. It was ordered that the reception procession should countermarch so as to take the lead in the triumphal march through the City, and a faint effort was made to carry out that programme. But the long pent-up feelings of separated friends could not be thus baffled. Crowds rushed from the ranks, and ran eagerly along the line of sun-burnt braves to catch the familiar features of loved ones -- familiar, though disguised with the hardships of two years' camp service, and bronzed by Summer suns and Winter storms. The reunions of the few moments thus occupied were enough to touch the heart of the most stoical bystander. It was the acme of human happiness -- the rejoining of husband and wife, of brother and sister, of parents and children. All was happiness. Joy beamed on every face, and the air was rent with the acclamations of the participants.

abstract: We find in the National Intelligeneer of yesterday morning, the announcement that Gen. HOOKER commenced a movement on Monday morning at daybreak, and that at sunrise heavy masses of artillery and other troops were crossing the river.
lead_paragraph: We find in the National Intelligeneer of yesterday morning, the announcement that Gen. HOOKER commenced a movement on Monday morning at daybreak, and that at sunrise heavy masses of artillery and other troops were crossing the river. No intelligence of this kind has reached us over the telegraph wires, but we have good reason to know that it is true. Indeed, the knowledge that the Army of the Potomac had commenced a movement, was in our possession on Monday evening, but in deference to the supposed wishes of the Government, we forbore to publish it.

abstract: The "McChesney's Zouaves," or Tenth regiment New-York volunteers arrived in this city yesterday, their term of service having expired. They numbered about 400 men, less than half of their orignal strength.
lead_paragraph: The "McChesney's Zouaves," or Tenth regiment New-York volunteers arrived in this city yesterday, their term of service having expired. They numbered about 400 men, less than half of their orignal strength. They have acquitted themselves with credit in all the Peninsular fights, before Richmond, at Antietam and Fredericksburgh. They have been for some time commanded by Col. BENDIX. They were received on their arrival by the Thirty-seventh regiment of this City, Col. R, with full ranks, and the popular welcome was most cordial. The men were well and generally jolly, and many of them will reinlist.

abstract: The steamship New-York, from Southampton on the l5th inst., and the Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 15th and Queenstown on the 16th, arrived at this port yesterday, with European advices four days later.
lead_paragraph: The steamship New-York, from Southampton on the l5th inst., and the Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 15th and Queenstown on the 16th, arrived at this port yesterday, with European advices four days later. By these arrivals we receive a full explanation of the manner in which the new rebel pirate Japan, or Virginia, received on board her supplies of provisions and munitions of war previous to her departure on her mission of plunder. The steamer Alar, which landed some men from the Japan at Plymouth, as announced by the Persia, it appears shipped a quantity of "provisions," etc., and a number of seamen at Folkestone. She was then directed to steer toward a certain part of the coast of France, and after some delay the Japan hove in sight, when the "provisions," among which were guns, arms and ammunition, were transhipped. The Japan then proceeded westward. She is said to be of great strength, and capable of a high rate of speed. She carries ten guns, in addition to two of WHITWORTH's 68-pounders on pivots. The British Government was still engaged in making inquiries into the case of the Alexandra. An engraver at Sheffield and one of his workmen had been arrested on a charge of forging American notes, known as "greenbacks." Large numbers of these notes, varying in value from $5 to $10, are said to have been forged in Sheffield and sent thence to New-York. The Polish revolution appears to be daily gaining strength. The offer of amnesty made by the Czar had been peremptorily rejected. Several successes of the revolutionists are reported. The Liverpool cotton market was firmer, with a slight advance. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. Consols 92 3/4@92 7/8 for money.

abstract: The Navy Department has purchased the fine iron steamer Granite City, which was recently condemned by the Prize Court, and the vessel has been brought to the Brooklyn Navy-yard, where she is at ...
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department has purchased the fine iron steamer Granite City, which was recently condemned by the Prize Court, and the vessel has been brought to the Brooklyn Navy-yard, where she is at once to be converted into a man-of-war. The Granite City is almost a new vessel, measures about 800 tons, is 200 feet long and some 40 feet beam. She was captured some time since in attempting to run the blockade. Naval Constructor DELANO has already put hands to work on her, and she will be ready for sea in about three weeks.

abstract: Advices one day later from New-Orleans by the steamship Empire City, are important. News had reached the city that Gen. BANKS was at Opelousas, having taken possession of the place and all rebel property there, and opened communication with Admiral FARRAGUT above Port Hudson.
lead_paragraph: Advices one day later from New-Orleans by the steamship Empire City, are important. News had reached the city that Gen. BANKS was at Opelousas, having taken possession of the place and all rebel property there, and opened communication with Admiral FARRAGUT above Port Hudson. It was also believed that a portion of his forces had reached Alexandria, on the Red River, where were a large number of steamers and other rebel property of immense value. Gen. BANKS had sent to New-Orleans for all the National flags that could be procured -- probably to be used in covering the property. A large number of prisoners had been captured, and when the steamer left they were arriving at New-Orleans at the rate of 600 per day.

abstract: The Georgia  Legislature has passed a bill making it penal to buy, sell, circulate or receive any note, bill or draft of the United States.
lead_paragraph: -The Georgia Legislature has passed a bill making it penal to buy, sell, circulate or receive any note, bill or draft of the United States. It has long been known that the Secessionists have much stronger confidence in the solvency and integrity of the United States Government than of their boasted Confederacy. This has been evidenced by their distrust of Confederate notes, and their anxiety to get hold of United States "greenbacks." There has been no time since the war began when United States legal-tender notes were not current in Richmond, or anywhere in the South, at a premium over the Confederate currency.

abstract: The obsequies of Col.EDMUND C. CHARLES, formerly of the Forty-second (Tammany regiment,) were observed yesterday. The body was taken to the Governor's Room, at the City Hall,on Monday, ...
lead_paragraph: The obsequies of Col. EDMUND C. CHARLES, formerly of the Forty-second (Tammany regiment,) were observed yesterday. The body was taken to the Governor's Room, at the City Hall,on Monday, where it lay in state, guarded by Company A, of theSeventy-first regiment, till 2 P.M. yesterday. During that interval the room was visited by a large number of friends and acquaintances of the deceased, also numerous citizens of this and other cities. The coffin rested in the middle apartment, and was draped with the American colors. Upon the lid were placed the sword, belt and cap of the Colonel; also, a beautiful cluster of white flowers, in the form of a circle and cross. At 1 1/2 o'clock, the Fifth regiment, N.Y.M., entered the Park, and formed in double line in the spare fronting the City Hall. The Fifth was followed by a detachment of the Fourth Regulars, and Co. A, Seventy-first (Light Guard) regiment, to which company Col. CHARLES was formerly attached. The Light Guards were drawn up in two lines at the base of the steps leading to the corridor of the Hall. At a little after 1 o'clock, the collin was borne from the Governor's Room to the hearse by the citizen pali-bearers, in the meantime the band of the Seventy-first regiment playing a dirge. The procession was then formed, and moved in the following order:

abstract: "Yesterday morning, the Montreal Company's fine steamship St. Andrew sailed from Kingstown with nearly 400 vigorous young men, reasonably believed to be recruits entrapped for the Federal armies. They were lodged and fed in the city by American agents, and kept together until the steamer arrived at Kingstown. They were then conveyed in a small steamer to Kingstown, and placed on board. Ostensibly they are engaged to construct a railway at Chicago."

abstract: If we are rightly informed, our army on the Potomac is once more on the move, and we may expect, within the next few days, a good deal of successful or unsuccessful fighting. We entertain confidence in Gen. HOOKER;
lead_paragraph: If we are rightly informed, our army on the Potomac is once more on the move, and we may expect, within the next few days, a good deal of successful or unsuccessful fighting. We entertain confidence in Gen. HOOKER; first of all, because he has shown himself, in a subordinate position, to be a man of ability; and, secondly, because he has that confidence in himself without which ability is useless. We are satisfied that he will fight and march with the expectation of winning uppermost in his mind, and will not pass the most momentous hours of great conflicts in making preparations for disastrous retreat. But we do most earnestly, for the sake of the nation as well as for his, beg of politicians and strategists, of all sects and parties, to let him severely alone for the next half year at least. If he achieves a great military reputation inside that period, he will have accomplished a very extraordinary feat, but there is not the smallest probability that one week less than that time will suffice for any such purpose.

abstract: The day of National Fast, appointed by the President, in conformity with the request of the Senate, will be sincerely observed throughout the loyal States.
lead_paragraph: The day of National Fast, appointed by the President, in conformity with the request of the Senate, will be sincerely observed throughout the loyal States. We doubt whether there has ever been a time in the history of the war when there was a more general sense of dependence upon Providence. All things denote that we are near the very crisis of the struggle; and there is a disposition in all true men to turn for help and guidance to the Power Supreme. Nothing can be more just and needful than that on the eve of commencing new and, as we trust, decisive movements, we should pause to invoke the Divine favor, without which all efforts are vain.

abstract: If this war were remarkable for nothing else, it would be made ever memorable by the severity with which it is testing the price and value of a vast number of doctrines and beliefs which were held at its breaking out by a large and influential portion of the Christian world.
lead_paragraph: If this war were remarkable for nothing else, it would be made ever memorable by the severity with which it is testing the price and value of a vast number of doctrines and beliefs which were held at its breaking out by a large and influential portion of the Christian world. With some of the delusions which it has exploded, our readers are very familiar. We were all of us more or less satisfied, when it began, that Cotton occupied such a place in the world that there was no baseness or violence of which France and England, at least, would not be guilty in order to procure it. We thought the South so demoralized by the habit of bullying and of idling, as to be incapable of organized and persevering effort. We thought self-interest so powerful in determining men's course of action, as to make a combined attempt on the part of any large body of its citizens to overthrow the Union an idle dream. We were so impressed by the skil and wisdom displayed in the construction of the Constitution, that we had ceased to attach much importance to the character of the men who were to administer it. We were perfectly certain that the mere fact that every able-bodied man nominally belonged to the militia of the United States, placed the Republic in possession of an army 2,000,000 strong, and ready for immediate action.

abstract: The President of the United States having set apart the last Thursday of April as a day of national prayer, fasting and humiliation. I. HORATIO SEYMOUR, Governor  of the State of New-York, do recommend that the day be observed throughout the State with suitable religious solemnities.
